name: Brown-Point Shield Skin
description: Aspidoras fuscoguttatus, also known as the brown-point shield skin longirostris, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a tropical environment with a pH of 5.5–6.8, water hardness of 12 dGH, and a temperature range of 22 to 25 °C (72 to 77 °F). They prefer a diet of worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. When breeding, they lay eggs in dense vegetation, but adults do not guard the eggs. Due to its similarity to other related species, it is not very common in the aquarium trade.

name: Aspidoras Cory-Cat
description: Aspidoras lakoi is a small tropical freshwater fish native to the upper Paraná River basin in Brazil. It grows up to 4.0 centimeters in length and feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plants. In a fish tank, Aspidoras lakoi would thrive in an environment with dense vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. They are peaceful and social fish that prefer to be kept in small groups. Providing hiding spots and a sandy substrate is essential for their well-being. Regular water changes and a well-maintained tank are also crucial for their health.

name: Loach catfish
description: Aspidoras rochai, also known as loach catfish, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. It grows up to 4.4 centimeters in length and thrives in a tropical climate with a pH of 6.0-7.5, water hardness up to 14 dGH, and a temperature range of 21-25°C. In a fish tank, Aspidoras rochai would do well in a setup with dense vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. It is a bottom-dweller that feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. This fish species does not guard its eggs, so a tank with suitable breeding conditions and hiding spots for the fry would be ideal for successful reproduction.

name: Sixray corydoras, false corydoras
description: The sixray corydoras, also known as false corydoras, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the upper Araguaia River basin in Brazil. It grows up to 2.9 centimeters in length and prefers a tropical environment with a pH of 6.0 – 7.2, water hardness of 12 dGH, and a temperature range of 22–25 °C (72–77 °F). This fish feeds on worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In an aquarium setting, the sixray corydoras would thrive in a well-maintained tank with dense vegetation for egg laying. It is a peaceful species that does well in a community tank with other non-aggressive fish. Providing hiding spots and a sandy substrate mimicking its natural habitat will help this fish feel secure and exhibit natural behaviors.

name: Britski's catfish
description: Britski's catfish, also known as Corydoras britskii, is a tropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the upper Paraguay River basin in Brazil. This species, formerly classified as Brochis britskii, stands out with a high number of dorsal fin rays and a unique physical appearance. It grows up to 8.8 centimeters in length and thrives in a tropical climate with water temperatures ranging from 20-24°C. Britski's catfish feeds on worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter, and reproduces by laying eggs in dense vegetation. In a fish tank, Britski's catfish would require a well-maintained tropical environment with ample vegetation and hiding spots. They are peaceful and social fish that prefer to be kept in small groups, making them suitable for community tanks with other non-aggressive species. Providing a sandy substrate and regular water changes are essential for their well-being.

name: Emerald catfish
remarks: The Emerald Cory Catfish is a very hardy and resilient fish.  Disease should not be a concern provided that you maintain the aquarium to standards.[6]
description: The emerald catfish, scientifically known as Corydoras splendens, is a tropical freshwater fish native to the Amazon Basin in South America. This species thrives in sluggish waters with dense vegetation along the banks. It grows up to 7.5 centimeters in length and has a metallic green or blue-green body coloration. In an aquarium, the emerald catfish is peaceful and undemanding, best kept in small groups with a soft, fine substrate and plenty of plants. They accept various foods, including live worms, and do well in a community tank without damaging plants. Breeding can be achieved in captivity by providing a breeding tank with a ratio of three males to two females, where the female collects and pastes eggs individually to plants. The eggs hatch in about four days, and the fry become free-swimming shortly after.

name: Hognosed brochis
description:
The hog-nosed catfish, scientifically known as Corydoras multiradiatus, is a tropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically found in the western Amazon basin in Ecuador and Peru. This species, previously classified under Brochis, has a distinctive long snout and about 17 dorsal fin rays. It can grow up to 6.7 centimeters in length and thrives in a tropical climate with a pH range of 6.0-7.2, water hardness of 15 dGH, and a temperature of 21-24°C. 

In a fish tank, the hog-nosed catfish would require a well-maintained environment with dense vegetation for egg laying. It feeds on worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. This species is commercially sought after in the aquarium trade industry, although it may be rare or mistaken for other species like C. splendens. Providing care for the hog-nosed catfish is similar to that of C. splendens, making it a suitable choice for aquarium enthusiasts looking to add a unique and visually appealing fish to their tank.

name: Adolfo's catfish/corydoras
description: Adolfo's catfish, also known as Corydoras adolfoi, is a tropical freshwater fish originating from South America. It grows up to 2.2 inches in length and has red coloration in front of its dorsal fin. In a fish tank, Adolfo's catfish would thrive in a well-maintained environment with a temperature around 78°F, low pH levels, and clean water with a conductivity of 7.0-8.3 microSiemens. They feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. Breeding them in an aquarium can be challenging as they spawn in open water and do not guard their eggs. The fry hatch after four days at 26°C and may require special care to raise successfully. Overall, providing a suitable habitat with proper water conditions and a varied diet is essential for the well-being of Adolfo's catfish in a fish tank.

name: Banded corydoras
description: The banded corydoras, also known as the bearded catfish, is a subtropical freshwater fish native to coastal drainages in South America. It can grow up to 9.8 centimeters in length and exhibits pronounced sexual dimorphism. In an aquarium, this species thrives in water with a pH of 6.0-8.0, a water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 68-82°F. They feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter, and reproduce by laying eggs in dense vegetation. While peaceful, they are larger than most Corydoras species and thus require a larger tank to thrive. The banded corydoras is commercially important in the aquarium trade industry but needs a well-maintained tank with suitable water parameters to ensure its well-being.

name: Masked corydoras, bandit corydoras
description: The masked corydoras, also known as bandit catfish, is a small freshwater fish native to the Meta River basin in Colombia. It has a maximum length of 4.8 cm and is recognized by the "mask" over its eyes. To thrive in a fish tank, the masked corydoras requires soft to hard water, with a pH range of 6.0-7.0, and a temperature between 22-26°C. It prefers a diet of fresh and thawed live foods, with sinking pellets recommended for feeding since it is a bottom feeder. Live foods like small worms are suggested for conditioning. This species would do well in a well-maintained tank with suitable water parameters and a varied diet to keep it healthy and active.

name: Barred-tail corydoras
description: The barredtail corydoras, also known as Cochu's catfish, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. In an aquarium setting, this fish would thrive in a tank with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature of 79°F (26°C). It is a peaceful species that prefers to live in groups and should be provided with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation. The barredtail corydoras feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. They are known to lay eggs in dense vegetation, and the adults do not guard the eggs. This fish species is commercially popular in the aquarium trade industry and can be a great addition to a community tank with other peaceful fish species.

name: Blackstripe corydoras
description: The blackstripe corydoras, also known as Bond's catfish, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. It grows up to 1.9 inches in length and thrives in a tropical aquarium environment with a pH of 6.0–8.0, water hardness of 2–25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72–79 °F. This fish species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a tank, they prefer dense vegetation for egg laying as they do not guard their eggs. The female holds 2–4 eggs between her pelvic fins, fertilized by the male, before attaching them to a suitable spot. The blackstripe corydoras is commercially popular in the aquarium trade and is classified as a least-concern species by the IUCN Red List.

name: Blacktop corydoras
description: The blacktop corydoras is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the Amazon River basin in Ecuador and Northern Peru. It grows up to 1.7 inches in length and thrives in a tropical climate with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature of 77-83 °F. This species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a fish tank, the blacktop corydoras would do well in a well-maintained aquarium with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation. They are peaceful and social fish that should be kept in groups of at least 6 individuals. Providing a sandy substrate is beneficial as they like to sift through the substrate for food. Additionally, a moderate water flow and regular water changes are essential for their well-being.

name: Blue corydoras
description: The blue corydoras, also known as Natterer's catfish, is a small tropical freshwater fish originating from coastal rivers in South America. It has a light body color with a dark stripe along its length, clear fins, and yellow ventrals. This fish grows up to 5.4 centimeters and thrives in a tropical tank environment with a pH of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 20-23°C. Blue corydoras feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. They prefer laying eggs in dense vegetation, and adults do not guard the eggs. In a fish tank, they are peaceful and social, making them suitable for community tanks with other non-aggressive fish species. Providing hiding spots and a well-maintained tank with clean water and suitable vegetation is essential for their well-being and thriving in captivity.

name: Bluespotted corydoras
description: The bluespotted corydoras, also known as the blacksail corydoras, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. It grows up to 5.1 centimeters in length and thrives in a tropical climate with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature of 22-26°C. This fish species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In an aquarium, bluespotted corydoras require dense vegetation for egg laying. They do not guard the eggs, with the female carrying and fertilizing 2-4 eggs at a time before attaching them to a suitable surface. This fish is popular in the aquarium trade industry and would do well in a tank with suitable water parameters and ample hiding spots.

name: Bronze corydoras, Emerald green cory
description: The bronze corydoras, also known as the green corydoras, is a freshwater fish species commonly kept in aquariums. It thrives in quiet, shallow waters with soft bottoms and a temperature range of 25-28°C, pH 6.0-8.0, and hardness 5-19 DGH. These sociable fish prefer being kept in groups of 5 or more and are ideal for a community tank. They feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In captivity, they are easy to feed with flake, pelleted, live, and frozen foods. They exhibit unique mating behavior, with females spawning 10-20 egg-clutches with multiple males. The species is not particular about water composition, but appreciates a dense plant growth for hiding. They are hardy and useful aquarium fish, constantly combing the bottom for food. The bronze corydoras is easily bred in captivity and is produced in commercial quantities worldwide.

name: Caracha
description: Corydoras atropersonatus is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the upper Amazon River basin in Ecuador and Peru. It grows up to 1.8 inches in length and thrives in a tropical climate with a pH of 6.0–8.0, water hardness of 2.0–25 dGH, and a temperature range of 70–75 °F (21–24 °C). In a fish tank, this species would do well in a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots and soft substrate. They are peaceful and social fish that do best in groups, so it is recommended to keep them in a school of at least 6 individuals. Providing a varied diet consisting of worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter will help them thrive.

name: Ehrhardt's corydoras
description: Corydoras ehrhardti is a small tropical freshwater fish native to Brazil. In a fish tank, they are peaceful and social, thriving in groups of at least six. They prefer a well-planted tank with soft, slightly acidic water and a temperature range of 72-79°F. They feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. This species would do well in a community tank with other peaceful fish species.

name: Evelyn's cory
description: Corydoras evelynae is a small freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the Amazon River basin in Brazil. It grows up to 1.6 inches and thrives in tropical water conditions with a pH of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-79°F. In a fish tank, Corydoras evelynae would do well in a setup with dense vegetation and soft substrate to mimic its natural habitat. They are peaceful and social fish that should be kept in groups of at least 6 individuals. They are bottom-dwellers and will appreciate a diet of worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. The fish is known for its unique breeding behavior where the female carries and attaches sticky eggs to surfaces. Overall, providing a well-planted tank with suitable tank mates and proper water parameters will help Corydoras evelynae thrive in a home aquarium.

Corydoras geoffroy is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. It grows up to 2.8 inches in length and thrives in a tank with a pH of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature of 72-79 °F. This species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a fish tank, Corydoras geoffroy would do well in a setup with dense vegetation for egg laying. They are peaceful and social fish that prefer to be kept in groups of at least six individuals. Providing a sandy substrate and regular water changes are essential for their well-being.

Corydoras latus is a small tropical freshwater fish originating from South America. In a fish tank, they thrive in a tropical environment with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature of 72-79°F (22-26°C). They are peaceful bottom-dwellers that grow up to 2.0 inches (5.2 cm) in length. Corydoras latus feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. They prefer a tank with dense vegetation for egg-laying, as adults do not guard the eggs. To ensure their well-being, provide them with a suitable tank setup that mimics their natural habitat and maintain water conditions within the specified parameters.

name: Loxozonus cory
description: Corydoras loxozonus is a small tropical freshwater fish originating from South America. It grows up to 1.9 inches and thrives in a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature of 70-75°F. In a fish tank, they would do well in a well-planted environment with hiding spots and soft substrate. They are peaceful bottom-dwellers that should be kept in groups of at least 6 to feel secure. They are omnivores, feeding on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. Breeding involves the female carrying eggs between her pelvic fins for fertilization by the male. They are not aggressive and can coexist with other peaceful fish species in a community tank.

name: Corydoras nain
description: Corydoras nanus is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically found in creeks with moderate current and sandy-muddy bottoms. In captivity, they thrive in well-planted aquariums with hiding spots, round gravel, and smooth sand to protect their delicate barbels. They prefer a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature of 72-79°F. These peaceful fish are best kept in groups of at least six and are relatively easy to care for. They feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. Breeding occurs in dense vegetation, with females laying up to 600 eggs. Their coloring is typically silver with black stripes, sometimes with amber or purple highlights.

name: Long nosed arched cory
description: Corydoras narcissus, also known as the long nosed arched cory, is a freshwater fish native to the Amazonian Brazil. It has a unique longer, concave nose and can grow up to 6.5 cm in length. This species feeds on worms, small crustaceans, insects, and plant matter, and lays eggs in dense vegetation without parental care. In a fish tank, Corydoras narcissus would thrive in a well-planted environment with hiding spots and soft substrate. They prefer to be in small groups and can be aggressive towards each other, especially during the breeding period. It is essential to provide a peaceful tank with suitable tank mates to ensure the well-being of Corydoras narcissus.

The ornate corydoras, a tropical freshwater fish from South America, thrives in a tank with a pH of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature of 74-79°F. Growing up to 1.9 inches, it feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plants. This fish lays eggs in dense vegetation without parental care. In an aquarium, they are peaceful and social, best kept in groups of 6 or more. Provide hiding spots and soft substrate to mimic their natural habitat. Regular water changes and a varied diet will help them thrive.

Corydoras osteocarus is a small tropical freshwater fish originating from South America. It grows up to 1.6 inches in length and thrives in a tank with a pH of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 70-77°F. This fish species is peaceful and best kept in groups of at least 6 individuals. They are bottom-dwellers and prefer a well-planted tank with hiding spots and soft substrate. Corydoras osteocarus is a scavenger and feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. They are known to lay eggs in dense vegetation, with adults not guarding the eggs. In captivity, they can lay up to 300 eggs, usually attaching them to plants. Overall, Corydoras osteocarus is a hardy and social fish that requires a well-maintained tank with suitable tank mates to thrive.

Corydoras polystictus is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the Paraguay River basin in Brazil. It grows up to 1.3 inches in length and thrives in a tropical environment with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-83°F. This fish species feeds on worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a fish tank, Corydoras polystictus would do well in a setup with dense vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. They are peaceful and social fish that prefer to be kept in groups, so a tank with other peaceful fish species would be suitable. Providing hiding spots and a sandy substrate is also recommended as they are bottom-dwellers. Regular water changes and a well-maintained tank are essential for their health and well-being.

Scleromystax prionotos is a small tropical freshwater catfish found in South America. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a tropical environment with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-78°F (22-26°C). They prefer a tank with dense vegetation to lay their eggs. This fish species feeds on worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. It is a peaceful fish that would do well in a community tank with other non-aggressive species.

Corydoras semiaquilus is a small tropical freshwater catfish native to the Amazon Basin. It grows up to 6 cm in length and thrives in water with a pH of 6.0-8.0, hardness of 2.0-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 22-26 °C. This species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plants. In a fish tank, Corydoras semiaquilus would do well in a well-planted aquarium with hiding spots and soft substrate. They are peaceful and social fish that should be kept in groups of at least 6 individuals. Providing a clean environment with regular water changes is essential for their well-being.

Corydoras septentrionalis is a small tropical freshwater fish originating from South America, specifically the Orinoco River basin in Colombia and Venezuela. It thrives in streams with water current and grows up to 1.9 inches in length. In a fish tank, this species would require a tropical environment with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature between 68-77°F. They feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. When breeding, the female holds 2-4 eggs between her pelvic fins for the male to fertilize before attaching them to vegetation. To thrive in a fish tank, Corydoras septentrionalis would need ample hiding spots, smooth substrate to protect their barbels, and a well-maintained environment with suitable water parameters.

Corydoras simulatus is a small tropical freshwater fish originating from South America. It thrives in clean, clear water with a gentle current. In a fish tank, it would require a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature of 68-77 °F (20-25 °C). This fish species grows up to 1.9 inches (4.9 centimeters) and feeds on worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. When breeding, it lays eggs in dense vegetation without parental care. To thrive in a tank, provide Corydoras simulatus with a well-maintained environment resembling its natural habitat, including suitable water parameters and ample hiding spots.

Corydoras undulatus is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. It grows up to 1.7 inches in length and thrives in a tropical climate with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-79°F. This fish species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a fish tank, Corydoras undulatus would do well in a setup with dense vegetation for egg laying. They are peaceful and social fish that prefer to be kept in groups of their own kind or with other peaceful fish species. Providing a well-maintained tank with hiding spots and a sandy substrate would help them thrive.

name: Dwarf corydoras
description: The dwarf corydoras, also known as Corydoras hastatus, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. It is typically found in the Amazon River and Paraguay River basins. This fish species thrives in a (sub)tropical climate with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 5-19 dGH, and a temperature range of 68-82 F (20-28 °C). The dwarf corydoras is a schooling fish that prefers midwater areas with dense plant cover. In an aquarium setting, it should be kept in groups of at least six individuals in a tank of at least 5 gallons. This fish is a good community tank member when housed with peaceful tankmates like tetras, rasboras, and danios. The tank should be well-aerated, densely planted, and have a moderate current. The water should be slightly alkaline with a temperature range of 24° to 29 °C. The dwarf corydoras is an omnivore that accepts a variety of foods, including freeze-dried, flake, frozen, and live foods. In terms of breeding, the fish can be spawned in a small tank with aged water, a sponge filter, and plants. Conditioning with live foods is essential for successful spawning, and the fry can be fed newly hatched brine shrimp or microworms.

name: Elegant corydoras
description: The elegant corydoras, also known as the elegant catfish, is a tropical freshwater fish native to South America. It is characterized by dark double longitudinal stripes and a body with gray and black markings on an olive background. This fish grows up to 5.1 centimeters in length and thrives in a tropical climate with a pH of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 22-26°C. In a fish tank, the elegant corydoras prefers a well-planted environment with roots and leaves for egg attachment. It feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. This species tends to swim in the upper levels of the aquarium and is not as disruptive to the sediment as other Corydoras species. The male can be territorial during prespawning activities, while the female typically hides among plant roots. Overall, the elegant corydoras is a visually striking and commercially valuable fish in the aquarium trade industry.

name: False network catfish
description: The false network catfish, also known as Corydoras sodalis, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. It grows up to 1.9 inches long and is found in the Amazon River in Loreto, Peru, and Amazonas, Brazil. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a tropical environment with a pH of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-79°F. They feed on worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. When breeding, they lay eggs in dense vegetation, but adults do not guard the eggs. To keep false network catfish healthy and happy in a tank, provide them with a well-maintained tropical setup with suitable water parameters and hiding spots.

name: False spotted catfish
description: The false spotted catfish, also known as Corydoras leucomelas, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. It grows up to 1.7 inches long and thrives in a tropical climate with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-79°F. This fish species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a fish tank, false spotted catfish would do well in a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation. They are peaceful and social fish that prefer to be kept in small groups. Providing a sandy substrate and gentle filtration is ideal for their well-being.

name: Gold laser cory
description: The green gold catfish, also known as Corydoras melanotaenia, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. In a fish tank, it would thrive in a tropical environment with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature between 73-77°F (23-25°C). This fish species grows up to 2.3 inches (5.8 cm) long and feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. When breeding, they lay eggs in dense vegetation, with adults not guarding the eggs. In captivity, the eggs are typically attached to broad plant leaves and hatch after five days. The green gold catfish is commercially significant in the aquarium trade industry.

name: Guapore corydoras
description: The Guapore corydoras is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the Guaporé River basin in Brazil. It grows up to 1.6 inches long and thrives in a tropical climate with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature of 70-75°F. In a fish tank, it would do well in a setup with dense vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. This fish species feeds on worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. It lays eggs in dense vegetation, and the adults do not guard the eggs. The Guapore corydoras is commercially popular in the aquarium trade industry, making it a sought-after addition to freshwater tanks.

name: Mosaic corydoras, reticulated corydoras
description: Corydoras haraldschultzi is a small tropical freshwater fish native to Brazil and Bolivia. It grows up to 7 centimeters and thrives in a tropical climate with a pH of 6.0 – 8.0, water hardness of 2 – 25 dGH, and a temperature range of 75 – 83 °F (24 – 28 °C). In a fish tank, it would do well in a setup with dense vegetation and a sandy substrate. This fish species feeds on worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. When breeding in captivity, the female lays eggs in her ventral fin pouch, which are then placed on cleaned sites where they adhere to the substrate. Corydoras haraldschultzi is popular in the aquarium trade industry and is known for its distinctive black dots on a gold background pattern on the head.

name: Mosaic corydoras, reticulated corydoras
description: The reticulated corydoras is a small tropical freshwater fish originating from South America. It grows up to 2.4 inches in length and thrives in a tropical environment with a pH range of 6.0–8.0, water hardness of 2–25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72–79 °F. This fish species feeds on worms, benthic crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a fish tank, the reticulated corydoras would do well in a setup with dense vegetation where they can lay their eggs. They are peaceful and social fish that prefer to be kept in groups of at least 6 individuals. Providing hiding spots and a sandy substrate is ideal for their well-being. This fish is popular in the aquarium trade industry due to its attractive appearance and peaceful nature.

name: Panda corydoras
description:
Corydoras panda, also known as the panda corydoras or panda catfish, is a popular aquarium species native to South America, specifically Peru and Ecuador. This fish species thrives in clear, fast-flowing rivers with well-oxygenated water and soft sand or fine gravel substrates, often surrounded by various aquatic plants. In captivity, they prefer cooler temperatures ranging from 20°C to 25°C and water conditions similar to their natural habitat, which includes neutral to slightly acidic pH levels. 

In a fish tank, Corydoras panda should be kept in groups of at least eight individuals, as they are highly social and thrive when surrounded by their own kind. The aquarium should be well-furnished with live plants, caves, and hiding spots to provide security for the fish. Water quality and substrate cleanliness are crucial for their well-being, as they are sensitive to poor maintenance and can succumb to stress and disease quickly. 

Feeding primarily on animal matter, Corydoras panda requires a high-quality and varied diet that includes live foods like bloodworms, daphnia, and brine shrimp, as well as high-quality flake foods containing shrimp. They can live for over ten years with proper care. Breeding in captivity is possible with the addition of clean, oxygenated water as a stimulus. Females lay eggs on fine-leaved aquatic vegetation, with up to 25 eggs produced in a single spawning. Fry are sensitive to water chemistry and temperature changes, requiring careful attention during their development.

name: Pastaza corydoras
description: The Pastaza corydoras is a small tropical freshwater fish native to the Pastaza River basin in Ecuador. It grows up to 6.1 centimeters in length and thrives in a tropical aquarium environment with a pH of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 22-26°C. This fish species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a fish tank, it would do well in a setup with dense vegetation for egg-laying and prefers a peaceful community tank with other non-aggressive species. Providing hiding spots and a sandy substrate mimicking its natural habitat would help the Pastaza corydoras thrive in captivity.

name: Peppered corydoras, salt and pepper catfish
description: Corydoras paleatus, also known as blue leopard corydoras or peppered catfish, is a peaceful and hardy fish species originating from the lower Paraná River basin. In a fish tank, they thrive in a planted environment with temperatures between 16 to 24 °C (61 – 75 °F) and prefer dim lighting and hiding places like bogwood. They feed on sinking pellets, algae wafers, live and frozen foods, and may enjoy blanched spinach. These catfish are bottom feeders and may dart to the top of the tank to supplement oxygen when stressed. They exhibit unique courtship behaviors and can lay eggs all over the aquarium. Peppered corydoras reach sexual maturity at around 8-12 months and can breed successfully, with juveniles reaching adult size at about 1 year of age. It's important to monitor water quality as they may dart to the top when it deteriorates.

name: Pink corydoras
description: The pink corydoras is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the Meta River basin in Colombia. It grows up to 4.2 cm in length and is named after Herbert R. Axelrod. In a fish tank, pink corydoras are peaceful and social creatures that thrive in groups of their own kind. They prefer a well-planted tank with soft, sandy substrate to mimic their natural habitat. These fish are bottom-dwellers and appreciate hiding spots like caves or driftwood. Providing a clean environment with stable water parameters and a varied diet will help them thrive in captivity.

name: Pygmy corydoras
remarks: A very peaceful species, that does not make an ideal community fish due to its small adult size. It is easily intimidated by larger tank mates and will not compete well with them for food.[10]
description: The Pygmy Corydoras is a small, peaceful freshwater fish native to South America. It has a silver color with distinct black markings. In an aquarium, they thrive in a community tank with smaller fish like ember tetras, small shrimp, and snails. They prefer a pH of 6.5-7.0, a temperature range of 22-26°C, and soft to moderately hard water. They are best kept in groups of at least four, preferably more, and enjoy swimming in mid to lower tank levels. Providing a fine-grained substrate like sand is essential to prevent injury to their barbels. Offering a varied diet including sinking foods, flakes, frozen food, and live foods like microworms or brine shrimp will help them thrive. They are not suited for aggressive tankmates and do best in a planted tank or with shrimp species.

name: Sailfin corydoras
description: The sailfin corydoras is a subtropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically Brazil. It can grow up to 3.4 inches in length and thrives in water with a pH of 6.0-8.0, hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 64-70 °F. In a fish tank, sailfin corydoras would do well in a setup with plenty of vegetation for egg laying and hiding spots. They are peaceful and social fish that do best in groups of their own kind or with other peaceful species. Providing a well-maintained tank with a sandy substrate, moderate water flow, and a varied diet including worms, crustaceans, and plant matter will help them thrive.

name: Salt and pepper catfish/corydoras
description: The salt and pepper catfish, also known as Corydoras habrosus, is a small tropical freshwater fish originating from South America. In the wild, they are found in the Upper Orinoco River basin in Venezuela and Colombia, inhabiting areas with abundant leaf litter and plant life. These bottom-dwelling fish are peaceful and thrive in a community aquarium with smaller fish species. They should be kept in groups of at least 6 individuals in a tank of at least 14 gallons. Salt and pepper catfish feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter, and can be fed sinking pellets, flake food, and frozen foods like baby brine shrimp. Breeding in captivity can be challenging, but it can be stimulated by large water changes with relatively cold water. During spawning, males exhibit protective behaviors towards females, who deposit eggs on plants near the substrate. Overall, the salt and pepper catfish requires a well-maintained tank with suitable tank mates, proper feeding, and potential breeding stimulation for optimal thriving in a home aquarium.

name: Schwartz's catfish
description: Schwartz's catfish, also known as Corydoras schwartzi, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the Purus River basin in Brazil. It grows up to 1.5 inches in length and thrives in a tropical aquarium environment with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-79 °F (22-26 °C). This species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a tank, they prefer dense vegetation for breeding as the female holds 2-4 eggs between her pelvic fins, fertilized by the male. The female then attaches the sticky eggs to a suitable surface. They are not aggressive and can be kept in a community tank with other peaceful fish species. Providing a well-planted tank with hiding spots and a sandy substrate mimicking their natural habitat will help Schwartz's catfish thrive and display their natural behaviors.

name: Spotted corydoras, longnose corydoras
description: The spotted corydoras, also known as longnose corydoras, is a small freshwater fish native to South America. It grows up to 1.9 inches long and thrives in tropical aquariums with a pH of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 70-75°F. This species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a fish tank, the spotted corydoras would be a peaceful bottom-dwelling fish that enjoys a well-planted tank with hiding spots and soft substrate. It is a social species that should be kept in groups of at least six individuals. Regular water changes and a varied diet will help this fish thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Sterba's corydoras
description: Sterba's corydoras, a popular freshwater aquarium catfish, is known for its attractive markings and white spots on a black background on its head. This species thrives in groups of 5 or more in soft, acidic water but can adapt to various water conditions. They are not good algae eaters but help clean up leftover food and detritus. These peaceful catfish grow to about 2-2.6 inches and accept a variety of foods. They should be housed with peaceful tank mates like tetras or dwarf cichlids and provided with a fine substrate, shade, and hiding spots. Breeding can be achieved with the right conditions, but raising fry is challenging due to their sensitivity. During transportation, care must be taken as they can secrete a toxin when stressed.

name: Sychr's catfish
description: Sychr's catfish, a tropical freshwater fish from South America, thrives in a tank with a pH of 6-8, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-79°F. Growing up to 1.7 inches, it feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plants. In a tank, it would need ample hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. Sychr's catfish is peaceful and should be kept in groups of at least 6 to promote social behavior. They are bottom-dwellers and would benefit from a sandy substrate to sift through. Regular water changes and a well-maintained tank are essential for their well-being.

name: Tailspot corydoras
description: The tailspot corydoras is a small freshwater fish originating from South America. In a fish tank, it would thrive in a tropical environment with a pH range of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 2-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-79°F. This fish species grows up to 1.6 inches in length and feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. It reproduces by laying eggs in dense vegetation, with the female carrying the eggs in a pouch formed by the pelvic fins. In an aquarium, the tailspot corydoras would require a well-planted tank with hiding spots and a peaceful community of fish to thrive.

name: Threestripe corydoras, leopard catfish, false julii cory
description: The three stripe corydoras, also known as Corydoras trilineatus, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to South America. It grows up to 2.5 inches long and thrives in a tropical environment with a pH of 6.0–8.0, water hardness of 5–19 dGH, and a temperature range of 72 to 79 °F. This fish species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a fish tank, they prefer dense vegetation for egg laying, as adults do not guard the eggs. The female carries and fertilizes eggs with the male before attaching them to a suitable spot. The three stripe corydoras is often confused with Corydoras julii due to similar horizontal stripes, but can be distinguished by the solid and pronounced stripes on its body. This species is popular in the aquarium trade industry and is hardy and adaptable, making it suitable for various tank setups.

name: Xingu corydoras
description: The Xingu corydoras is a small freshwater fish native to the upper Xingu River basin in Brazil. It grows up to 1.5 inches and thrives in a tropical aquarium environment with a pH of 6.0–8.0, water hardness of 2–25 dGH, and a temperature range of 72–79 °F. This fish feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. It lays eggs in dense vegetation and does not guard them. In a fish tank, the Xingu corydoras would do well in a setup with plenty of hiding spots and live plants to mimic its natural habitat. It is a peaceful species that does best in a group of its own kind or with other non-aggressive fish.

name: Julii corydoras
description: Corydoras julii, also known as the julii cory or leopard catfish, is a small freshwater catfish native to eastern Brazil. They are peaceful shoaling fish that should be kept in groups in captivity. These fish are relatively small, growing up to 52 millimeters in length, with a whitish-gray skin and fine black spotting across their body. In a fish tank, Corydoras julii would thrive in a peaceful community tank with soft, sandy substrate and plenty of hiding spots like plants and caves. They are bottom-feeders and should be fed sinking pellets rich in insect proteins and live or frozen invertebrates. Breeding Corydoras julii may be triggered by changes in temperature and diet, with females laying eggs on plant leaves. It is important to note that adult corydoras may eat their own eggs.

name: Flagtail catfish
description: The flagtail catfish, also known as the stripedtail catfish, is a tropical freshwater fish found in the Amazon Basin in South America. It can grow up to 12.5 cm in length and thrives in water with a pH range of 6.0 to 8.0, hardness of 5-19 DH, and a temperature of 25°-28°C. In a fish tank, the flagtail catfish would prefer a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots like plants or caves. They are peaceful and social fish that do well in groups, so it is recommended to keep them with other non-aggressive tank mates of similar size. Providing a sandy substrate and regular water changes will help them thrive in captivity.

name: Cascarudo
description: The Callichthys callichthys, also known as cascarudo or armored catfish, is a subtropical freshwater fish found in South America. It grows up to eight inches in length and thrives in various water conditions, from anoxic to slightly turbid streams. It can adapt to pH levels of 5.8 to 8.3, water hardness of 0–30dGH, and temperatures of 64–83 °F (18–28 °C). This fish species is known to feed on fish, insects, and plant matter, with juveniles consuming rotifers and aquatic insect larvae. During reproduction, the male builds a bubble nest and guards it fiercely. In an aquarium, it is recommended to keep more than five individuals in a group to thrive. The cascarudo is commercially popular in the aquarium trade industry and is also consumed as a minor food source.

name: Spotted hoplo
description: The Spotted Hoplo Catfish, also known as Megalechis thoracata, is a hardy and peaceful species that thrives in captivity. They require a tank with a soft sand substrate to prevent irritation to their sensitive barbels. A minimum tank size of 55 US liquid gallons is recommended, with larger tanks being even better. These semi-social creatures prefer to be kept in groups of at least five and need hiding places like rocks, wood, and plants. They prefer water temperatures between 24–28 degrees Celsius and a mature, cycled tank with correct parameters. The Spotted Hoplo Catfish is an opportunistic feeder and may eat anything that fits in its mouth. They are bottom dwellers that forage for food and are found in slow-flowing, low-oxygen habitats in the Amazon, Orinoco, and upper Paraguay River basins. In the tank, they should be kept away from potentially aggressive fish that may harm them.

name: Bristlenose pleco, bushynose pleco
remarks: The bristlenose genus has at least 59 identified species and many others yet to be named.[14] Males and female both have long "bristles" on their nose, the males having distinctly longer ones.
description: Ancistrus, also known as bushynose or bristlenose catfish, is a nocturnal freshwater fish native to South America and Panama. In an aquarium, they prefer flowing water and a substrate like gravel, dirt, or clay. They are bottom-dwellers and do not school, often hiding when not feeding. Ancistrus species are hardy and can survive in various water conditions. They feed on algae, aufwuchs, and detritus, and can also accept algae wafers, vegetables, and frozen bloodworms. These fish are territorial, with males guarding eggs and fry in caves. They are relatively small, reaching up to 15 cm in males and 12 cm in females. Bristlenoses are compatible with most freshwater fish and can breed easily in captivity. They have a lifespan of up to 12 years and prefer temperatures between 23-27°C. Albino variants are common, and sexing is easy based on the presence of bristles on the head. Breeding involves males attracting females to a cave, guarding eggs, and caring for the young until they are free-swimming.

name: Gold nugget pleco
description: Baryancistrus is a genus of freshwater Loricariid catfish found in the Amazon and Orinoco river basins. They prefer clearwater and flowing river sections. These fish can grow up to 34 cm in length and are mainly herbivores and detritivores. In an aquarium, they may require time to adjust but will eventually become active during the day. Providing hiding places is crucial due to their nocturnal behavior. Breeding in captivity is challenging, and sexing adults is difficult. There are eight recognized species in this genus, with some varieties known only by their L-number designation, such as the popular Gold Nuggets. Overall, Baryancistrus fish need a well-oxygenated tank with ample hiding spots and a varied diet to thrive.

name: Whiptail catfish
remarks: It is a peaceful fish that is best kept in good sized groups (6+) in a mature tank with plenty of shady hiding spots amongst plants, driftwood, slate caves, and PVC pipes.[15]
description: Rineloricaria is a genus of freshwater tropical catfish known for their long filament on the caudal fin. They are native to rivers in northern and central South America and are commonly seen in the aquarium trade. These catfish thrive in environments with sand or rock bottoms, including large rivers, streams, and lagoons. They have an adaptive capacity to tolerate various habitats and temperature gradients. Rineloricaria catfish are around 13 cm long, slender, with no visible barbels, and a sucker disk mouth. They have a light brown color with darker blotches and bony plates covering their bodies. These fish are cavity brooders, with males brooding the eggs. In a fish tank, Rineloricaria would need a spacious tank with sand or rock substrate, ample hiding spots, and a stable temperature. They are peaceful fish but may exhibit territorial behavior, so providing enough space and hiding spots is crucial for their well-being.

name: Twig catfish
description: Farlowella is a genus of fish native to South America, found in various rivers in the region. These fish have a unique body shape resembling a thin stick of wood, with a slender and elongated body, often brownish in color with two dark lateral stripes. They are commonly kept in aquariums due to their distinctive appearance. In a fish tank, Farlowella would thrive in an environment that mimics their natural habitat, including ample hiding spots like driftwood and plants to provide cover. They are peaceful fish that prefer a well-maintained tank with clean water and a gentle water flow. Providing them with algae-based foods is essential for their diet, as they are herbivores. Overall, Farlowella would behave well in a community tank with other peaceful fish species, given the right conditions for their well-being.

name: Panaque
description: Panaque catfish are small to medium-sized South American fish known for feeding on wood, algae, and aufwuchs. They are popular aquarium fish that require a mixed diet including green algae and vegetables. Panaque catfish need driftwood in their tank to graze upon, as they are argued to be xylophagous. They are peaceful, nocturnal bottom-dwellers that thrive in community tanks but can be territorial. A high-capacity tank and filter are essential due to their size and waste production. They prefer somewhat soft, slightly acidic water but can tolerate a range of water chemistry.

name: Pineapple pleco, orange cheek pleco
description: Pseudorinelepis genibarbis, also known as the "Pineapple Pleco," is a large and bulky armored catfish native to Brazil, Peru, and Ecuador. In an aquarium, this species is peaceful, sociable with its own kind, non-territorial, and omnivorous. It thrives in soft water with a pH range of up to 7.5 and a temperature between 23-27°C (73-81°F). P. genibarbis can adapt its coloration based on the substrate color but changes occur gradually. It can gulp air to become neutrally buoyant when disturbed, indicating low tank aeration. This fish is not an obligate air-breather and has fully functional gills. It is recommended to provide a suitable environment with plenty of hiding spots and a varied diet to ensure its well-being in a fish tank.

name: Common pleco, suckermouth catfish, Amazon sailfin catfish
description: The Amazon sailfin catfish, also known as Pterygoplichthys pardalis, is a freshwater tropical fish native to the Amazon River Basin of Brazil and Peru. It can grow up to 43 centimeters in length and prefers a pH range of 7.0-7.5. This species is a bottom-dwelling fish but has the ability to breathe air from the water's surface. In a fish tank, the Amazon sailfin catfish would thrive in a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like caves or driftwood. It is important to provide a well-maintained tank with clean water and a balanced diet to ensure the fish's health and well-being. Additionally, due to its potential size, aquarists should consider the long-term space requirements before keeping this species in a home aquarium.

name: Common pleco, suckermouth catfish
description: Hypostomus punctatus, also known as the suckermouthed catfish, is a freshwater tropical fish native to South America. It belongs to the armored suckermouth catfish family and is commonly referred to as "plecostomus" or "common pleco" by aquarists. This species has a light brown coloration with darker brown spots and reaches about 30 centimeters in length. In a fish tank, H. punctatus would thrive in an environment with fast-flowing water, temperatures between 22-28°C, pH levels ranging from 5-8, and dH levels between 0.5-25. They are herbivorous and feed on algae, detritus, plants, and roots. Due to their suckermouth, armor plates, and strong fins, they need ample space and hiding spots in the tank to mimic their natural habitat.

name: Common pleco, suckermouth catfish
remarks: Adults can become very territorial and aggressive towards each other. It is difficult to keep 2 adult common plecos together.[16]
description: Hypostomus plecostomus, also known as the suckermouth catfish or common pleco, is a tropical freshwater fish from South America. In a fish tank, they prefer water temperatures between 72-86 degrees Fahrenheit and a pH of 6.5-7.5. They have a sucker-like mouth that allows them to adhere to surfaces and feed on algae, plants, and small crustaceans. These fish are bottom feeders and nocturnal, often purchased for their algae-cleaning abilities. They can grow up to 15 inches in captivity and are known for their thick armor, making them less susceptible to harassment from other fish. However, they contribute a significant amount of waste to the tank's nitrogen cycle. It's important to provide them with enough space and hiding spots in the tank to thrive.

name: Leopard sailfin pleco, clown sailfin pleco
description: Pterygoplichthys gibbiceps, also known as leopard sailfin catfish, is a large armored catfish species native to South America. In an aquarium, they are peaceful towards other fish but may have territorial disputes with other plecos and similar-sized fish. They prefer well-aerated water and a large tank with good filtration due to their potential size of up to 2 feet. They are primarily herbivorous but will also consume dead animals. Their diet can include vegetables, meat, and prepared foods like sinking algae wafers. They are active at night and tend to hide during the day. Breeding involves females laying eggs in caves or hollows, with a high mortality rate until the spawn are around two inches long. They have a mild camouflage ability and can adjust their scales' coloration.

name: Zebra pleco, L-046
remarks:
One of the most popular Hypancistrus species.
Endangered.[17]
description: The zebra pleco (Hypancistrus zebra) is a critically endangered catfish species native to the Rio Xingu in Brazil. In captivity, they require a minimum tank size of 30 gallons with water temperature between 79–88 °F and pH levels of 6.5-7.0. They are predators needing a high protein diet of small invertebrates. These fish are nocturnal, territorial, and prefer plenty of hiding spots in a tank that mimics their natural environment with caves, rocks, and a highly oxygenated, fast-moving current. They should not be kept in community tanks and thrive with small dither fish that do not compete for food. The species is commercially bred for the aquarium trade due to restrictions on wild collection. Breeding involves the male guarding the eggs until they hatch, with the fry absorbing their yolk sac in two weeks. The zebra pleco is regulated under CITES Appendix II to control international trade.

name: Sailfin catfish
description: Pterygoplichthys multiradiatus, also known as the Orinoco sailfin catfish or plecostomus, is a tropical fish belonging to the armored catfish family. This species is mottled brown/black and prefers freshwater streams and lakes with warm water temperatures between 23–27 °C, a pH range of 6.5–7.8, and a dH range of 4–20. In an aquarium setting, P. multiradiatus thrives in large tanks with plenty of rocks and driftwood for hiding. It is a nocturnal bottom-dweller that feeds on benthic algae, aquatic weeds, worms, insect larvae, and other bottom-dwelling invertebrates. This fish is relatively peaceful and does well with cichlids and other large fish. However, it should be kept in solitude due to its size, growing up to 50.0 centimeters (19.7 inches) TL. P. multiradiatus has been introduced to various locations outside its native habitat, where it is considered an invasive species due to its disruptive burrowing activities and competition with native species.

name: Golden dwarf sucker, golden oto
description: Otocinclus macrospilus, also known as the common otocinclus or dwarf otocinclus, is a small catfish species native to South America, specifically the Amazon River basin. It reaches a size of about 3.5 cm (1.4 inches) and is popular in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, Otocinclus macrospilus is a peaceful and social fish that thrives in a well-established aquarium with plenty of plants and hiding spots. They are known to be great algae eaters, making them beneficial for maintaining tank cleanliness. It is important to provide them with a well-maintained environment with stable water parameters and a varied diet to ensure their health and longevity.

name: Zebra dwarf sucker, zebra oto
description: The zebra oto, also known as the tiger oto, is a small fish originating from Peru, specifically found in mid-sized creeks with clear water and marginal vegetation. This species has a distinctive appearance with vertical stripe-like blotches and a W mark on its caudal fin. In a fish tank, zebra otos would thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of vegetation and hiding spots. They are peaceful and social fish that do well in groups, so it is recommended to keep them in a small school. Due to their small size and peaceful nature, they can be housed with other small, non-aggressive fish species. It is important to note that the zebra oto is listed as endangered in the wild, so it is crucial to source them from responsible breeders in the aquarium trade.

name: Clown Pleco ( L104, L162, and LDA22)[18]
remarks: primary diet consists of wood, in aquaria this is provided in the source of drift wood. Will appreciate blanched vegetables, and/ or algae (wafer or live)[18]
description: The Clown Panaque, also known as Panaqolus maccus, is a small loricariid fish native to Venezuela and Colombia. In the wild, they are found in driftwood tangles near riverbanks. In an aquarium setting, they thrive with ample driftwood, fresh vegetables, spirulina, and occasional frozen foods like bloodworms. They are peaceful and suitable for community tanks, but require good filtration due to their wood-based diet. Clown Panaques prefer softer, more acidic water and are hardy enough to tolerate various water parameters. They are best kept in tanks of at least 15 gallons. Breeding them in captivity can be challenging, requiring a tank environment and water conditions similar to their natural habitat, including soft driftwood and cave formations for hiding places. Simulating seasonal changes by adjusting pH and temperature may encourage breeding behavior.

name: Bolt catfish
description: The Bolt Catfish, also known as Aguarunichthys torosus, is a benthopelagic catfish native to the Cenepa River basin in the Amazon River drainage of Peru. It can grow up to 346 mm in length and is primarily found in the upper Amazon basin of Peru. In a fish tank, the Bolt Catfish would thrive in a well-maintained environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a sandy substrate with plenty of hiding spots like caves or driftwood. They prefer peaceful tank mates and a diet of sinking pellets or live foods. Providing clean water with moderate flow and regular water changes is essential for their well-being.

name: Gold Zebra catfish
description: The zebra catfish, scientifically known as Brachyplatystoma juruense, is a species native to the Amazon and Orinoco River basin. It can grow up to 60.0 cm in length and is characterized by broad dark vertical bands on its body. In an aquarium setting, the zebra catfish would thrive in a larger tank with a sandy substrate and plenty of driftwood for hiding spots. This fish prefers deeper river channels and is entirely piscivorous, meaning it preys on other fish species. To ensure its well-being, it is essential to provide a suitable environment that mimics its natural habitat and offer a diet rich in loricariids and bottom-dwelling fish.

name: Zebra shovelnose
description: The zebra shovelnose, or tigerstriped catfish, is a large piscivorous species native to the Amazon basin. It can grow up to 85 cm in length and 5.2 kg in weight. This fish prefers fast-flowing sections of whitewater rivers but can adapt to clearwater rivers as well. In a fish tank, the zebra shovelnose would require a spacious tank with strong water flow to mimic its natural habitat. It is important to provide hiding spots and ample swimming space. Due to its predatory nature, tank mates should be chosen carefully to avoid aggression and ensure they are not small enough to be seen as prey. A varied diet of meaty foods would be necessary to keep this fish healthy and thriving in captivity.

name: Vulture Catfish, zamurito
description: Calophysus macropterus, also known as the Piracatinga or Vulture Catfish, is a small and hardy species of catfish originating from the Amazon and Orinoco basins. It can reach up to 40 centimeters in length and is known to be adaptable in a large aquarium setting. However, tankmates should be carefully selected as this fish has the ability to bite and tear off pieces of flesh, although aggression levels may vary. Providing a spacious environment with hiding spots and suitable water conditions mimicking its natural habitat will help this species thrive in a fish tank.

Leiarius, a genus of long-whiskered catfish native to South America, includes species like L. marmoratus and L. pictus, popular in the aquarium hobby. These fish can grow quite large, with L. marmoratus reaching over 100 cm and L. pictus up to 60 cm. They have distinctive features like long barbels and sail-like dorsal fins. In a tank, they need a spacious environment with hiding spots and peaceful tankmates. Leiarius species are active during dawn, dusk, and night, preferring to rest over rocks or tree trunks during the day. They have a voracious appetite and grow quickly, so a large aquarium is necessary for their well-being. These fish are not recommended for beginner aquarists due to their size and care requirements.

Leiarius is a genus of long-whiskered catfish native to South America, with species like L. marmoratus and L. pictus commonly kept as ornamental fish in aquariums. These fish can grow quite large, with L. marmoratus reaching over 100 cm and 12 kg, while L. pictus grows up to 60 cm. They have a peaceful temperament towards other large fish but need a very large aquarium with hiding spots for daytime retreats. Leiarius species are active during sunrise, sunset, and night, preferring to lay over rocks and tree trunks. They have a voracious appetite and grow rapidly, requiring a dedicated environment to thrive, making them unsuitable for average aquarists.

name: Redtail catfish
tank_size: Needs at least a 2,600 US gallons (9,800 L) tank when mature, even though this does not provide them with the space to show their natural behaviour.[22]
description: The redtail catfish, also known as Phractocephalus hemioliopterus, is a large and colorful catfish species native to South America. In an aquarium, they require a tank of at least 10,000 liters when fully mature due to their massive size, which can reach up to 1.8 meters in length and 80 kilograms in weight. They are bottom-dwellers that move slowly and are territorial. Redtail catfish are carnivorous, feeding on live and dead fish and other meat, so they need a diet heavy in protein. Overfeeding can be harmful to them. They should be housed with other large fish as they have a habit of swallowing smaller tank mates. These fish are not suitable for all but the largest aquariums and need a well-fed environment to thrive.

name: Spotted pimelodus, pictus, pictus catfish
description: Pimelodus pictus, also known as the pictus catfish, is a small catfish species native to the Amazon and Orinoco river basins. In an aquarium, they are active swimmers and nocturnal bottom feeders, requiring a larger tank due to their agility. They prefer soft water and are omnivorous, consuming bloodworms, beef heart, insects, vegetables, and prepared fish foods. Pictus cats are non-aggressive and can coexist with other fish species. They have sharp spines on their fins, making handling challenging. Despite being mildly venomous, they pose no threat to humans. These fish have silver bodies with black spots and stripes, and they exhibit little sexual dimorphism.

name: Ornate Pimelodus
remarks: Similar to catfish but not in the same genus
description: The ornate pimelodus, also known as Pimelodus ornatus, is a species of fish that can grow up to 24-28 cm in length. They are found in various countries in South America including Colombia, Venezuela, Brazil, and Argentina. In a fish tank, ornate pims would thrive in a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like caves or plants. They are known to be peaceful but may show territorial behavior, so providing ample space and suitable tank mates is essential for their well-being. Additionally, they prefer clean water with moderate flow and a sandy substrate to mimic their natural habitat.

name: Sturgeon catfish
description: Platystomatichthys sturio, also known as the sturgeon catfish, is a species found in the Amazon Basin. It can grow up to about 40.0 centimeters in length. This fish belongs to the catfish family Pimelodidae and is the only species in the genus Platystomatichthys. In a fish tank, Platystomatichthys sturio would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like caves or plants to mimic its natural habitat. They are peaceful fish but can be territorial, so it's best to keep them with similar-sized tank mates. Providing a diet of sinking pellets or live foods would help them thrive in captivity. Maintaining good water quality with regular water changes is essential for their well-being.

name: Barred sorubim
description: The Pseudoplatystoma fasciatum, also known as the barred sorubim or barred catfish, is a nocturnal predator native to Suriname, Corantijn, and Essequibo. It feeds on other fish and crabs and can grow up to 90 cm in length. In a fish tank, this species would require a large tank with plenty of hiding spots and a sandy substrate to mimic its natural habitat. They prefer dim lighting and should be fed a diet of freshly hatched artemia nauplii and later transitioned to high-quality pelleted food. Reproduction in captivity can be achieved with hormonal injections and careful monitoring of larvae development. Overall, providing a suitable environment and proper feeding schedule is crucial for the P. fasciatum to thrive in a fish tank.

name: Tiger sorubim
description: The tiger sorubim, also known as Pseudoplatystoma tigrinum, is a long-whiskered catfish found in the Amazon Basin. It can grow up to 130 cm in length. In a fish tank, tiger sorubim would need a large tank with plenty of space to swim due to its size. They prefer clean water with good filtration and hiding spots like caves or driftwood. They are carnivorous and would thrive on a diet of live or frozen meaty foods. It is important to provide a suitable environment that mimics their natural habitat to ensure their well-being in a tank setting.

name: Firewood catfish, (planiceps) shovelnose catfish
description: The firewood catfish, also known as peixe-lenha, is a large South American catfish found in the Orinoco and Amazon Basins. It thrives in whitewater high in suspended sediments. This species can grow up to 150 cm in length and is known for its unique appearance that changes as it matures. Firewood catfish are nocturnal and highly predatory, feeding on other fish. In a fish tank, they would require a spacious environment with hiding spots and suitable tank mates that are not small enough to be seen as prey. They would prefer dim lighting to mimic their natural habitat and a diet of meaty foods to meet their predatory nature.

name: Cuckoo squeaker
description: Synodontis multipunctatus, also known as the cuckoo catfish, is a small catfish species native to Lake Tanganyika in Africa. It grows up to 27.5 centimeters in length and is a brood parasite that uses mouthbrooding cichlids to care for its young. In an aquarium, they should be kept in groups of at least 3 to avoid territorial issues and provided with ample cover and cave-like structures. They are active both during the day and night and can be quite lively. Suitable hosts from Lake Malawi and Lake Victoria can also be used for breeding. This species thrives in a tank environment that mimics their natural habitat with proper hiding spots and companions to reduce aggression.

name: Decorated squeaker
description: Synodontis decorus, also known as clown catfish, is a visually striking upside-down catfish species native to Cameroon, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and the Republic of the Congo. It is known for its long dorsal fin extension and attractive body coloration, making it a popular choice among catfish enthusiasts. In a fish tank, Synodontis decorus would thrive in a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like caves or driftwood. They are peaceful fish but may exhibit territorial behavior, so providing ample space and companions of similar size and temperament is essential. It is important to maintain good water quality and offer a varied diet to ensure the well-being of this species.

name: Even-Spotted squeaker
description: Synodontis petricola, also known as the cuckoo catfish or pygmy leopard catfish, is a species of upside-down catfish found in Lake Tanganyika in Africa. This fish species thrives in rocky shorelines in the littoral zone with a maximum depth of 30 meters. In a fish tank, they would require a rocky environment to mimic their natural habitat, with plenty of hiding spots and caves. They prefer a temperature range of 23 to 26°C, pH of 8.5 – 9, and dH range of 4-15. They are carnivorous, feeding on water mites, seed shrimp, insect larvae, and algae. The growth rate is rapid in juveniles, slowing down as they age. Interestingly, they practice brood parasitism by depositing their eggs in cichlid nests for them to raise. Overall, providing a rocky setup, suitable water parameters, and a varied diet would help these fish thrive in a tank environment.

name: Featherfin squeaker
description: The featherfin squeaker, also known as Synodontis eupterus, is a catfish species known for its ability to produce noises and its distinctive feather-like fin. This fish is native to the basins of the White Nile, Volta, Niger Rivers, and the Chad Basin. In a fish tank, featherfin squeakers are peaceful and social creatures that thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots like caves, driftwood, and plants. They prefer soft, slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 75-82°F (24-28°C) and a pH level between 6.5-7.5. Providing a varied diet of sinking pellets, frozen, and live foods will help keep them healthy and active. It is essential to keep them in a group of at least three to prevent any aggression and ensure their well-being.

name: Lake Malawi syno
description: The Malawi squeaker is a species of upside-down catfish found in Lake Malawi. It grows up to 19.2 centimeters in length and is a minor catch for local fisheries and popular in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, the Malawi squeaker would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat in Lake Malawi. This includes a spacious tank with rocky hiding spots, sandy substrate, and good water quality. They are peaceful fish but may exhibit some territorial behavior, so providing adequate hiding spots and territories within the tank is essential for their well-being. Additionally, they are omnivores, so a varied diet of high-quality pellets, live, and frozen foods would be ideal for their health and vitality.

name: Polka dot syno
description: Synodontis angelicus, also known as the polkadot squeaker, is a species of upside-down catfish native to the Congo Basin. Adult specimens are grey to dark violet with reddish-yellow to brown-red blotches. Juveniles display striking white blotches on a red-violet background. This species grows up to 25 centimeters in length and is commercially popular in aquariums. In a fish tank, they are mostly nocturnal, may excavate the substrate, and nibble on plants. They prefer a water temperature of 24-28°C, a pH of 6.0-8.0, and a hardness of 5-19 dGH to thrive.

name: Common syno, false upside-down catfish
description:
Synodontis nigrita, also known as the false upside-down catfish, is a species of upside-down catfish found in northern Africa. It has a distinct bony head capsule with a unique humeral process and three pairs of barbels. This fish species has hardened spines on its dorsal and pectoral fins, with a deeply forked caudal fin. It has a premaxillary toothpad with chisel-shaped teeth and s-shaped teeth on the mandible. The body color is brown or olive with black spots, and juveniles have black spots. It can grow up to 33.5 centimeters in length.

In a fish tank, Synodontis nigrita would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat in northern Africa. This includes providing hiding spots like caves, driftwood, and plants to create a sense of security. The tank should have a sandy substrate to allow for natural behaviors like sifting through the substrate for food. Being omnivores, they should be fed a varied diet including insect larvae, algae, and crustaceans. They are peaceful fish but may exhibit territorial behavior, so providing enough space and hiding spots for each fish is essential. Maintaining good water quality and regular water changes are crucial for their well-being.

name: Upside-down catfish
remarks: S. nigriventris prefers bottom feeding on Tubifex (or similar worms), but its main diet consists of algae.[23] The blotched upside-down catfish is well suited to aquariums because of its small size (typically 9 or 10 cm or less) and peaceful demeanor.[citation needed]
description: The blotched upside-down catfish, Synodontis nigriventris, is a small fish species native to the Congo Basin. These fish have adapted to spend most of their time swimming upside down, with their bellies darker than their backs for camouflage. They are mostly nocturnal and feed on insects, crustaceans, and plant matter. In an aquarium, they thrive in a peaceful environment with plenty of hiding spots and objects to swim around. They prefer to swim either at the bottom or surface of the tank and swim faster when upside down, especially around objects. Their small size and peaceful nature make them well-suited for aquariums.

name: Three-striped African catfish
description: The three-striped African catfish, Pareutropius buffei, is a small fish species native to Nigeria, Niger, Mali, Benin, and Guinea. It grows up to 8 centimeters in length and has a silvery body with three lateral stripes and black spots on its caudal fin. In an aquarium, this species would thrive in a setup that mimics its natural habitat, such as a tank with ample space to swim, hiding spots like rocks or plants, and clean freshwater. They are peaceful fish that can be kept with other non-aggressive species of similar size. Providing a varied diet of small live or frozen foods would help them thrive in a tank environment.

name: Giraffe catfish
description: The giraffe catfish, Auchenoglanis occidentalis, is an African catfish found in lakes and rivers across Africa. It feeds on plants, insects, and a variety of foods. In a fish tank, it requires a spacious environment with muddy bottoms to mimic its natural habitat. This fish grows up to two to three feet in size and has a unique giraffe-like pattern that fades with age. It practices interspecific brood care, guarding its scattered eggs. While occasionally imported for aquariums, its large size and scavenging behavior make it unsuitable for smaller tanks. It is tolerant of various water conditions but may uproot plants while foraging. Additionally, the giraffe catfish is an important food source in Africa.

name: Electric catfish
description: Malapterurus electricus, also known as the Electric Catfish, is a robust fish with unique features such as mouth barbels and the ability to generate up to 450 volts of electricity. In a fish tank, this species would require a minimum tank size of 55 US gallons with hiding spots like bogwood or PVC pipes. They are active burrowers and prefer a temperature of at least 75°F. Electric Catfish are compatible with snails but should not be kept with other fish due to their predatory nature. They feed on stunned prey at night and are hardy eaters. Despite their fascinating traits, it is illegal to own Electric Catfish in Florida.

name: Black lancer catfish
description: The black lancer, a species of bagrid catfish, is native to various Southeast Asian countries and can grow up to 25.0 cm in length. It is commonly traded for aquariums, but often imported in poor condition. To thrive in a fish tank, it is recommended to acclimate them at a high temperature of around 29°C. Despite being nocturnal, they can be trained to eat in light and even from the owner's hand. They exhibit territorial behavior but can coexist better when a male is placed with multiple females. These fish are adaptable to different pH and water hardness levels, as long as extreme conditions are avoided.

name: Harlequin lancer catfish
description: The harlequin lancer catfish, also known as Bagroides melapterus, is a slender catfish species with a maximum length of 34.0 cm. It has a silver coloration with distinctive black spots and markings. This species is native to Asia, particularly found in countries like Thailand, Malaysia, Brunei, and Indonesia. In a fish tank, the harlequin lancer catfish would thrive in a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like caves or driftwood. They prefer soft, acidic water conditions and a sandy substrate. Due to their peaceful nature, they can be kept with other non-aggressive fish species. It is important to provide them with a varied diet that includes sinking pellets or frozen foods to ensure their optimal health and well-being.

name: Crystal-eyed catfish
description: Hemibagrus wyckii, also known as the crystal-eyed catfish or black devil catfish, is a black fish with white markings on its fins and striking sky-blue eyes. It can grow up to 71 centimeters in length and is native to various river systems in Asia. In an aquarium setting, this species is aggressive and predatory, known to attack other fish and even objects in the tank. Due to its behavior, it is recommended to keep Hemibagrus wyckii alone to prevent harm to other tank mates. They require a spacious tank with hiding spots and a diet consisting of insects, prawns, and fish to thrive.

name: Asian redtail catfish
description: The Asian redtail catfish, Hemibagrus wyckioides, is a large catfish species native to the Mekong basin and other river systems in Thailand. It can grow up to 130 centimeters in length and weigh up to 80 kilograms. In an aquarium, these fish are known to rearrange decorations and are not picky eaters, consuming insects, prawns, fish, and crabs. However, they are considered one of the most aggressive freshwater fish and should be kept alone. They thrive in large tanks with rocky bottoms and irregular depths, mimicking their natural habitat in upland rivers. It is important to note that this species is an invasive species in Malaysia and should not be kept in net cages or released into rivers.

name: Shadow catfish
description: Hyalobagrus flavus, also known as the yellow catfish, is a species native to Indonesia, specifically found in the Batang Hari drainage in Sumatra and the Mentaya River basin in southern Borneo.
