These catfish thrive in brown water habitats closely linked to blackwater peat swamps. They are known to form large shoals, sometimes mingling with other shoaling catfish species. In a fish tank, Hyalobagrus flavus would require an environment that mimics their natural habitat, including brown water conditions and ample space for shoaling behavior. Providing hiding spots and vegetation would also be beneficial for their well-being. It is essential to maintain water quality and ensure a balanced diet to help them thrive in captivity.

Mystus bimaculatus, also known as the Mystus catfish, is a near-threatened species with a red-brown body and distinctive dark markings on its shoulder and caudal peduncle. This catfish species is native to Indonesia, particularly Java and the Lesser Sunda Islands. In a fish tank, Mystus bimaculatus would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a well-decorated tank with hiding spots like caves or plants. They prefer soft, slightly acidic water with a sandy substrate. These catfish are peaceful and social, so they can be kept in small groups. Providing them with a varied diet of sinking pellets, live or frozen foods will help them thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Glass catfish
description: The glass catfish, scientifically known as Kryptopterus vitreolus, is a small transparent freshwater catfish native to Thailand. It is commonly found in the aquarium trade but was only accurately classified in 2013. This species typically grows up to 8 cm in length and has a unique transparent appearance due to its scaleless body. In a fish tank, glass catfish thrive in a peaceful environment with plenty of hiding spots like plants and caves. They prefer soft, slightly acidic water with a stable temperature between 75-80°F. Due to their sensitivity, it is essential to maintain high water quality and provide a varied diet including live or frozen foods. Glass catfish are known to be sensitive to changes in water parameters, so regular monitoring and maintenance are crucial for their well-being.

name: Striped wallago catfish
description: The Great Tapah, also known as Wallagonia leerii, is a large catfish species native to Southeast Asia. It can grow up to 2 meters in length and weigh up to 150 kilograms. In a fish tank, the Great Tapah would require a very large tank due to its size and swimming habits. It is a piscivore, primarily feeding on small fish, so a diet rich in protein would be essential for its health. The tank should have plenty of hiding spots and open swimming areas to mimic its natural habitat. Due to its vulnerability to stress and specific environmental conditions, maintaining water quality and providing adequate filtration is crucial for its well-being. Additionally, mimicking its breeding migration pattern by creating suitable spawning areas in the tank may be challenging but beneficial for its overall health and behavior.

name: Chocolate frogmouth catfish
description: Chaca bankanensis, also known as the angler catfish, is a species native to the Sundaland region, specifically found in countries like Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. These catfish thrive in peat swamps and streams in their natural habitat. In an aquarium setting, Chaca bankanensis would require a tank with ample space and hiding spots like caves or plants to mimic its natural environment. They are known to grow up to 20.0 cm (7.9 in) in length and are occasionally found in the aquarium trade. To thrive, they would need a well-maintained tank with clean water, suitable hiding spots, and a diet that replicates their natural feeding habits.

name: Asian banjo catfish
description: Acrochordonichthys rugosus, a catfish species from the Akysidae family, is commonly found in clear, fast-flowing forested streams in Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a well-oxygenated tank with plenty of hiding spots like rocks, driftwood, and plants. Providing a sandy substrate and maintaining good water quality is essential for the well-being of Acrochordonichthys rugosus. Due to its natural habitat preferences, it is important to ensure strong water flow and a well-aerated tank to replicate its native environment.

name: Walking catfish
remarks: The albino form is common in the aquarium trade. This fish can survive out of the water and "walk" as long as kept wet, for a very long time.[25]
description: The walking catfish is a freshwater airbreathing catfish native to Southeast Asia known for its ability to "walk" across dry land using its pectoral fins. In a fish tank, it would need a large environment with well-rooted plants and structures for shade. This species thrives in stagnant, hypoxic waters and feeds on smaller fish, molluscs, invertebrates, detritus, and aquatic weeds. It spends most of its time at the bottom of the tank, occasionally coming up to gulp air. Due to its voracious eating habits, it can quickly deplete food supplies, making it harmful when invasive. Tankmates should be chosen carefully as the walking catfish may prey on smaller fish.

name: Stinging catfish
description: Heteropneustes fossilis, also known as the Asian stinging catfish or fossil cat, is an airsac catfish found in various Asian countries. It thrives in ponds, ditches, swamps, and marshes, as well as muddy rivers, and can tolerate slightly brackish water. This omnivorous species breeds during the monsoon season in confined waters or rainwater-filled ponds. In a fish tank, H. fossilis would require a spacious environment with ample hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. It is important to note that this species can deliver a painful sting to humans, so caution is advised when handling. Providing a varied diet and suitable water conditions would be essential for this catfish to thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Sun catfish
description: The Horabagrus brachysoma, also known as the sun catfish, is a species of catfish native to the rivers of the Western Ghats in India. It has a large head, wide mouth, and yellowish body with distinct markings. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a setup that mimics its natural habitat - smooth flowing areas with plenty of vegetation. They prefer lowland areas with mud or sand substrate and can also be found in deep pools and hill streams. H. brachysoma is an unspecialized feeder, consuming a variety of meaty foods including crustaceans, mollusks, fish, and even terrestrial insects and frogs. Their diet flexibility helps them adapt to varying food availability, especially during monsoons. Breeding occurs before the monsoon season, with increased feeding rates during this time. Due to overexploitation, habitat alteration, and pollution, this species is considered vulnerable or endangered. In a fish tank, providing a well-planted environment with a diverse diet and suitable water conditions would help this species thrive.

name: Iridescent shark
description: The iridescent shark, also known as the Siamese shark catfish, is a freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia. Despite its name, it is not a shark but a species of shark catfish. It is popular among fishkeeping hobbyists for its striking appearance and iridescence. This omnivorous fish prefers a tropical climate with a pH of 6.5–7.5, water hardness of 2.0–29 dGH, and a temperature range of 22–26 °C (72–79 °F). They require large tanks, at least 12 meters in length, to thrive and develop naturally. Iridescent sharks are schooling fish that need space to swim and are sensitive to stress, which can lead to injuries in an aquarium environment. Proper care, adequate space, and a balanced diet can help them reach their full size of up to 1 meter in length and live into their teens.

name: Chao Phraya giant shark, giant pangasius
description: The giant pangasius, also known as the Paroon shark or Chao Phraya giant catfish, is a critically endangered freshwater fish found in the Chao Phraya and Mekong basins in Indochina. This species prefers to live in the bottom of deep depressions in freshwater rivers and is tolerant of poor water quality, mainly in brackish waters. In a fish tank, the giant pangasius would require a large tank with plenty of space to swim and hide, as well as a sandy substrate to mimic its natural habitat. They are carnivorous and feed on crustaceans, fish, and larger animal carcasses, so a varied diet would be necessary for their well-being. Due to their large size, reaching up to 9.8 feet in length and 660 pounds in weight, they would need a very large tank or pond to thrive. It's important to note that this species is highly protected and critically endangered, so it is crucial to ensure that they are sourced ethically and legally if kept in captivity.

name: Colombian shark catfish
description: The Tete sea catfish, also known as Ariopsis seemanni or Colombian shark catfish, is a species native to Central and South America. It is occasionally found in the pet trade under various names. However, it is not suitable for most aquariums as it needs to be acclimated from freshwater to saltwater as it grows. This fish requires a very large tank due to its size and active swimming habits. To thrive, the Tete sea catfish would need a spacious tank with both freshwater and saltwater environments to accommodate its changing needs as it matures.

name: Banjo catfish
description: The Guitarrito, scientifically known as Bunocephalus coracoideus, is a banjo catfish native to the Amazon River basin. In an aquarium, this species would thrive in a setup resembling its natural habitat, such as ponds or creeks with ample plant debris. The Guitarrito is a peaceful fish but can be predatory towards small fish like fry. It is largely nocturnal and a bottom-feeder, feeding on debris and smaller fish. To replicate its natural behavior, providing sandy substrate for egg-laying and hiding spots would be beneficial. This species grows up to 12 centimeters in length and is popular in the aquarium trade.

name: Striped raphael catfish
description: The striped Raphael catfish is a peaceful and nocturnal species native to South America, popular in aquariums for its pleasant temperament and curious nature. It thrives in soft river bottoms and sandy environments, feeding on mollusks, crustaceans, and organic debris. This catfish is sociable with other fish but may feed on smaller ones, so caution is advised when introducing it to a tank. It is best not to catch them with a net due to their rigid pectoral fin spines. They are known to make grunting noises out of water and are challenging to breed in captivity. To thrive, they require a spacious tank with hiding spots and a sandy substrate to mimic their natural habitat.

name: Spotted raphael catfish
description: Agamyxis pectinifrons, also known as the spotted talking catfish, is a small thorny catfish native to the Amazon basin. In an aquarium, this species requires a dark refuge to hide during the day due to its shy nature. It is recommended to handle them by hand instead of using a net to avoid damaging their spines. The spotted talking catfish is popular in aquariums and is known to make audible clicking sounds. To thrive, they need a well-maintained tank with ample hiding spots and a peaceful environment.

name: Bottlenose catfish
description: The Ageneiosus inermis, also known as mandubé, is a species of driftwood catfish found in South America. It is known for its piscivorous diet, preying on catfishes from the Loricariidae and Doradidae families. In a fish tank, the mandubé would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like driftwood and plants to mimic its natural habitat. It is important to provide a varied diet that includes live or frozen fish to meet its predatory nature. Additionally, maintaining good water quality and providing adequate filtration is crucial for the well-being of the mandubé in a tank setting.

name: Gulper catfish
description: The gulper catfish, also known as the ogre catfish, is a carnivorous species native to the Rio Negro and Orinoco basins in Brazil, Colombia, and Venezuela. It thrives in slow-moving waters with many submerged structures. In an aquarium, the gulper catfish would require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and structures to mimic its natural habitat. Due to its carnivorous nature, it should be fed a diet of live prey such as small fish. The gulper catfish has a unique feeding behavior of swallowing prey whole, sometimes even larger than itself, due to its ability to greatly expand its mouth. It is a nocturnal and crepuscular species in the wild, so providing a dimly lit environment in the tank would be ideal. Despite its predatory nature, the gulper catfish is known for its slow and unobtrusive approach to catching prey, making it an intriguing addition to a well-prepared aquarium setup.

name: Midnight catfish
description: The Leguia, also known as Auchenipterichthys coracoideus or zamora woodcat, is a small driftwood catfish native to Peru. In an aquarium, this species prefers to hide in small spaces during the day and may not be very active in the light. They are robust and suitable for community tanks but may prey on smaller fish. To thrive, the Leguia needs a tank with plenty of hiding spots like driftwood or caves to mimic its natural habitat in the Amazon River basin.

name: Oil catfish
description: Centromochlus perugiae, also known as honeycomb catfish, is a small benthopelagic fish with a striking skin pattern. They are peaceful and prefer to hide in crevices in driftwood, making them ideal for community tanks. These fish thrive in water temperatures between 26-28°C with a pH of 6-7. They are nocturnal and seek hiding spaces and shade. To ensure their well-being in a fish tank, provide ample hiding spots and driftwood for them to anchor themselves.

name: Jaguar catfish
description: The jaguar catfish, also known as Liosomadorsa oncinus, is a species native to Brazil, specifically in the Branco River and Trombetas River. This fish is popular in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, the jaguar catfish would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a tank with plenty of driftwood, rocks, and hiding spots. They prefer dim lighting and soft, slightly acidic water conditions. Jaguar catfish are peaceful and nocturnal creatures, so they would do well in a community tank with other non-aggressive fish species. It is important to provide them with a varied diet that includes sinking pellets, frozen foods, and live foods to ensure their health and well-being.

name: Pygmy driftwood catfish
description: Trachelyichthys exilis, also known as the driftwood catfish, is a small fish species native to Peru, specifically in the Nanay River basin. It typically grows up to 8.0 cm in length. In a fish tank, Trachelyichthys exilis would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, which includes plenty of driftwood and hiding spots. They are peaceful and prefer to be in groups, so it is recommended to keep them in small schools. Providing a sandy substrate and gentle water flow would also be beneficial for their well-being. Overall, Trachelyichthys exilis is a low-maintenance fish that can add a unique touch to a freshwater aquarium setup.

Trachelyopterus fisheri, also known as Fisher's woodcat or driftwood catfish, is a slender freshwater demersal fish native to the Sucio River in Colombia. It has a terminal mouth, distinguishing it from other Trachelyopterus species. This fish is not very popular in the tropical aquarium trade but is listed as "least concern" on the IUCN Red List. In a fish tank, Trachelyopterus fisheri would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a tank with ample hiding spots like driftwood and rocks, soft and slightly acidic water, and a sandy substrate. They are peaceful and prefer to be in groups, so it's best to keep them with similar-sized non-aggressive tank mates.

name: Black phantom tetra
remarks: The black phantom tetra enjoy being in groups of 6 or more and a slightly shaded tank. Males may claim small territories and occasionally minor battles may occur. The Phantom tetra goes well with other tetras of similar size. They also prefer floating plants.[27]
description: The black phantom tetra, also known as Hyphessobrycon megalopterus, is a small freshwater fish native to Brazil and Bolivia. In an aquarium, they display territorial behavior, with males defending their space by extending their fins and intensifying their dark coloration. They can be kept in smaller groups of four or five individuals but still need space for territorial behavior. To thrive, they require a well-conditioned environment with live or frozen foods for breeding stimulation. Breeding tanks should have plants, low light, and a pH of 5.5-6. The female can produce around 300 eggs, which hatch after five days. The fry should be fed infusoria initially and later transitioned to suitable-sized live foods for optimal growth.

name: Black neon tetra
description: The black neon tetra is a freshwater fish native to southern Brazil, commonly found in the aquarium trade. It grows up to 4 cm in length and has a plain coloration with two distinct stripes. To thrive in a fish tank, they require soft acidic water, live plants, a darker substrate, and open swimming space. It is recommended to keep them in groups of at least 6 in a tank of at least 15 gallons. They should be fed a variety of foods including flakes, frozen, and live foods like worms and brine shrimp to enhance their colors. Breeding black neon tetras requires acidic water with low hardness levels. They are egg scatterers and can lay hundreds of eggs, but parents tend to eat them, so they should be removed after spawning. Raising the fry can be challenging due to their small size, starting with protozoa and gradually moving to larger fry food. Live food is beneficial for all stages of their development.

name: Black tetra, skirt tetra
remarks: A highly spirited fish that may occasionally chase its own species as well as harass slow moving fish with long fins. This fish is very hardy and can stand a variety of water qualities. Disease is not a big problem with the black tetra. The black tetra is also known as the black skirt tetra. The female black tetra is more robust and larger than the male.[29]
description: The black tetra, also known as the black skirt tetra, is a freshwater fish native to South America. It grows up to 7.5 cm in length and has a greyish color with prominent black vertical bars. This shoaling fish feeds on small crustaceans, insects, and worms. In an aquarium, the black tetra thrives in a shoal and prefers a well-planted tank with hiding spots. It is recommended to provide live foods like Daphnia and mosquito larvae, as well as frozen foods such as bloodworms. The species reaches sexual maturity at about two years of age and spawns by releasing and fertilizing eggs among plants. Keepers should remove the fish after spawning to prevent them from eating their own eggs. The black tetra has a lifespan of 3 to 5 years in captivity and is a common and widely available fish for aquarium enthusiasts.

name: Bleeding heart tetra
remarks: The bleeding heart tetra is distinguished by the small red spot on both sides of the fish. This fish is very prone to diseases, and can grow larger than most tetra species.[30]
description: The bleeding heart tetra is a freshwater tropical fish native to the Upper Amazon River basin, reaching a size of 2.5 inches and living for about five years. In a fish tank, a group of 6 would thrive in a 15-gallon tank, but a larger tank of preferably 30 gallons with more fish is recommended. They prefer soft, acidic water with a temperature range of 73-82°F and a pH of 5.6-6.9. Their diet should consist of prepared foods and small live foods. Adding peat to the filter can help maintain suitable water conditions. Males have elongated dorsal and anal fins, while females are more full-bodied with shorter fins. Both sexes have a striking blood-red spot in the pectoral area and a black and white patch on the dorsal fin.

name: Bloodfin tetra
description: The bloodfin tetra is a South American characin known for its silver body and striking blood-red fins. Growing up to 5.5 cm, they are hardy and ideal for beginner fish keepers. These sociable fish thrive in schools of five or more in community tanks, but may nip at fish with long fins. They prefer soft, slightly acidic water and can adapt to various water conditions if dechlorinated. Bloodfin tetras are known to spawn by leaping above the water surface, depositing 300-500 eggs that fall to the tank floor. They can also thrive in cold-water tanks as long as the temperature remains above room temperature.

name: Blue tetra
description: Knodus borki, also known as the blue tetra, is a small characin fish native to Peru. It thrives in freshwater environments such as rivers, streams, and tributaries, typically found in the vicinity of Iquitos. This species requires a tropical habitat and prefers a benthopelagic depth range. In a fish tank, Knodus borki would do well in a setup that mimics its natural environment, with plenty of plants and hiding spots. It is a peaceful fish that can be kept in a small group. Providing a well-maintained tank with stable water parameters and a varied diet will help Knodus borki thrive in captivity.

name: Bucktooth tetra
description:
The bucktooth tetra, also known as Exodon paradoxus, is a freshwater fish native to the Amazon Basin and Guyana. It has an elongated tetra appearance with a light tan color, two black spots, and a bright red dorsal fin. Despite its name, it does not have buckteeth. This species grows up to 12 cm long and feeds on small invertebrates, other fish, and plants. 

In a fish tank, the bucktooth tetra should be kept alone or in large planted tanks with protective coverage for other species. They thrive best in shoals of eight or more to prevent stress and aggression. They are not suitable tank mates for small or large fish due to their predatory nature. Overall, they are hardy fish that can live for over ten years in home aquariums.

name: Buenos Aires tetra
description:
The Buenos Aires tetra is a tropical fish native to South America, specifically the La Plata region of Argentina, Paraguay, Uruguay, and southeastern Brazil. In the wild, they are found in rivers, ponds, lakes, and streams. This freshwater fish is known for its flashy red coloration and silver metallic body. They are social fish that swim in schools and are relatively large for tetras, growing up to 7.5 cm (3 inches) and living up to 5 or 6 years. 

In a fish tank, Buenos Aires tetras are hardy community fish suitable for beginners. They require a maintained freshwater tank and a varied diet consisting of live, fresh, and flake foods. Regular meals of live and frozen foods like bloodworms, Daphnia, and brine shrimp, along with vegetables, will help keep them healthy and colorful. It's important to feed them several times a day and only what they can consume in 3 minutes or less at each feeding to prevent aggression and ensure their well-being.

When breeding, a separate breeding tank with slightly acidic water is recommended to increase the chances of successful reproduction. Once the eggs hatch, it's advisable to remove the parents to prevent them from eating the fry. The fry will hatch in about 24 hours and become free-swimming after consuming their egg sac for three to four days. Overall, Buenos Aires tetras are low-maintenance fish that thrive in a peaceful community tank with proper feeding and care.

name: Cardinal tetra
remarks: Similar to the Neon Tetra, but slightly larger and doesn't prefer to school as much. They need much larger tanks, although their temperament is similar.[31]
description: The cardinal tetra is a small freshwater fish native to South America, known for its striking iridescent blue line and vivid red coloration. In an aquarium, cardinal tetras thrive in a setup that mimics their natural habitat - slow-moving, shallow waters with plenty of plants and roots. They are predatory, feeding on tiny animals like larvae and microcrustaceans. To breed them successfully, replicating their natural spawning conditions is key. Cardinal tetras are sensitive to water conditions, requiring temperatures between 19.6°C to 33.7°C and a pH level between 2.9 and 8.8. Supporting the sustainable capture of cardinal tetras in the Amazon Basin is crucial for the local economy and conservation efforts.

name: Cave tetra, blind tetra
remarks: The cave tetra is the blind cave form of the Mexican tetra. This tetra prefers low to moderate lighting.[32]
description: The Mexican tetra, also known as the blind cave fish, is a freshwater fish native to Texas and Mexico. It is a peaceful species that prefers midlevel water above rocky and sandy bottoms. In a fish tank, they thrive in water with a pH of 6.5-8, hardness up to 30 dGH, and a temperature range of 20-25°C. They are omnivorous, feeding on crustaceans, insects, and annelids. The blind cave form, known for its lack of eyes and pigment, is popular among aquarists. Despite their blindness, they navigate using their lateral lines. In captivity, they prefer subdued lighting and a rocky substrate. They are hardy and can adapt well to aquarium conditions. They become semi-aggressive as they age and are schooling fish. Selectively bred blind cave tetras are widely available in the aquarium trade and are known for their troglomorphic traits.

name: Diamond tetra
description: The diamond tetra is a small freshwater fish found in Venezuela, South America. It exhibits sexual dimorphism with males having longer dorsal fins and brighter colors. In an aquarium, they thrive in soft acidic water with a pH of 5.5-6.5 and a temperature of 26-29°C. They prefer a shaded area for spawning, with fine-leaved plants or a spawning mop. They are omnivores, eating standard fish foods like flakes and pellets, as well as live daphnia or frozen bloodworms. They are best kept in pairs or groups and should be well-conditioned with nutritious food before spawning. The fry grow quickly and can feed on pre-made fry foods or suitably sized live foods.

name: Ember tetra
remarks: Ember tetras have been known to live ten years or more. May become stressed by the presence of larger fish.[33]
description: The Ember tetra is a small freshwater fish native to Brazil, known for its striking orange and reddish coloration. In an aquarium, they thrive in acidic water with a pH near 6.6, a temperature range of 23–29 °C, and a wide range of water hardness. They should be kept in groups of at least 6, ideally 9-10, to promote schooling behavior. A minimum tank size of 10 gallons with live plants, a darker substrate, and open swimming space is recommended. Ember tetras swim in the middle level of the tank and should be kept with bottom-dwelling fish to clean up leftover food. They have a varied diet including flakes, frozen, and live foods. With proper care, they can live for over ten years in a well-maintained heavily planted aquarium.

name: Emperor tetra
description: The Emperor Tetra, Nematobrycon palmeri, is a characid fish native to Colombia. In an aquarium, they thrive in a well-planted tank with floating plants and subdued lighting to bring out their purple hue. They are sexually dimorphic, with males having blue eyes and distinct tail features. Emperor tetras are omnivores and will eat a variety of foods including flakes, live food, and frozen options. They can breed in a large, well-planted tank without extra stimulation. These placid fish prefer a pH of 6.5, hardness of 3-6 dKH, and a temperature of 23–27 °C. They do not school as readily as other tetras but may school briefly in larger groups with fresh cool water. A pair or small group of Emperor Tetras will be happier in a tank rather than with more boisterous species.

name: Flame tetra
description: The flame tetra, a small freshwater fish native to Southeast Brazil, is a popular choice in the aquarium trade. It reaches about 2.5 cm in length and has a striking red coloration with dark vertical bars. In a fish tank, flame tetras thrive in groups in a well-maintained environment with shallow, slow-flowing water, vegetation, and a temperature range of 22-28°C. They are peaceful schooling fish that will do well in a community tank. Their omnivorous diet and breeding behavior make them a fascinating addition to a freshwater aquarium.

name: Garnet tetra, pretty tetra
description: Hemigrammus pulcher, also known as the pretty tetra, garnet tetra, or black wedge tetra, is a popular aquarium species originating from the Peruvian Amazon. This fish has a pale-lemon body with a black area on its flanks, appearing iridescent under subdued lighting. It grows up to 4 cm (1.5 in) and can be distinguished by the shape of the swim bladder between males and females. In an aquarium, they thrive in soft, acidic water with temperatures between 23°C to 27°C (73°F to 81°F). They are peaceful and social fish that do well in groups of 6 or more. Feeding them a diet of prepared foods and small live foods is recommended. Breeding can be challenging as parents may eat their eggs, but if successful, eggs usually hatch within 20-24 hours. Providing a well-planted tank with hiding spots and a school of their own kind will help these fish thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Glass bloodfin tetra
description: The glass bloodfin tetra, native to the Amazon River basin, is a community tank fish that thrives in groups of at least 8 individuals. They adapt well to commercial dry foods but benefit from a varied diet including live and frozen options like daphnia and bloodworms. To thrive, they require a well-planted aquarium of at least 15 gallons with a pH of 7.3 and 10 degrees of hardness. They breed successfully in harder and more alkaline water than most tetra species but are known to eat their own eggs.

name: Glowlight tetra
description:
The glowlight tetra, Hemigrammus erythrozonus, is a peaceful, shoaling fish that thrives in a community tank environment. It is larger than neon tetras and prefers to be kept in a group of at least four, ideally eight or more, with similar-sized, non-aggressive tank mates. To thrive, they require a well-planted tank with open water for swimming and a minimum length of 60 cm. They are most active and aesthetically pleasing when in a shoal and prefer subdued lighting with a dark substrate. The water should be soft to slightly hard, slightly acidic, with a temperature range of 22° – 28° °C. 

In terms of behavior, glowlight tetras tend to swim in tighter groups when sensing a potential predator and swim more freely when comfortable. They are commonly used to complement neon tetras in aquariums and can sometimes shoal alongside cardinal tetras. Breeding them requires a separate tank with soft water, dim lighting, and fine-leaved plants for spawning. The fry should be raised in a dark environment and fed a variety of live foods for optimal growth. Regular water changes are crucial during the rearing period to maintain water quality for the fry's health and development.

name: Golden pristella tetra
description: Pristella maxillaris, also known as the X-ray fish or X-ray tetra, is a small characin species that thrives in groups in home aquariums. This fish, with its translucent body, is adaptable and can be found in various water conditions, including slightly brackish water. It is a peaceful shoaling species that should be kept in groups of at least six individuals in a tank of at least 15 gallons. They feed on small insects and planktonic animals and can tolerate a pH range of 6-8 and water hardness up to 20 dGH. Pristella maxillaris is best kept away from aggressive or predatory tankmates in a community tank setting.

name: Green neon tetra
remarks: Similar to Neon Tetras and Cardinal Tetras, they are the same to Neon Tetras beside having a green tiny near their top dorsal fin[35]
description: The green neon tetra is a small freshwater fish native to South America. It is similar in appearance to the neon tetra but slightly smaller with a less pronounced red patch and more brilliant blue-green areas on its body. In an aquarium, these fish thrive in soft, acidic water with temperatures between 24 to 29°C. They prefer highly stained water from peat, subdued lighting, and shade from plants. When breeding, they require extremely soft water with a pH of around 6 and a temperature of 77°F. They spawn in schools, with one female often paired with multiple males, laying about 130 light-sensitive eggs. The parents should be removed after spawning, and the eggs hatch in 24 hours. Feeding the tiny fry with infusoria is crucial initially, gradually transitioning to fine commercial fry foods as they grow. These fish can breed again after a few weeks.

name: Head and tail light tetra
description: Hemigrammus ocellifer, also known as beacon fish or head-and-tail light tetra, is a small South American freshwater fish found in various rivers. In a fish tank, they thrive in planted community aquariums, preferring to be kept in groups of six or more. Providing floating plants for dim lighting, hiding spots, and open swimming areas is essential. They showcase their best colors in tanks with dark substrates and backgrounds. These fish adapt well to a range of water conditions with a pH of 6-8, dH up to 18°, and a temperature of 72 to 79 °F (22 to 26 °C). Hemigrammus ocellifer readily accepts flake, micropellets, and frozen foods. Breeding them is relatively easy in a separate breeding aquarium with soft, slightly acidic water and higher temperatures. Spawning can be triggered by morning sunlight, resulting in the laying of 200 to 1000 eggs that hatch within 24 hours.

name: January tetra
description: The Costello tetra, also known as the January tetra or green neon, is a characin species native to the Amazon basin in Brazil and Peru. In aquariums, they thrive on a diet of flakes, pellets, and live foods. These fish are suitable for community tanks and are peaceful in nature, making them compatible with other non-aggressive fish species. To thrive, Costello tetras require a well-maintained tank with ample hiding spots, plants for cover, and a pH level around 6.0-7.0. They prefer soft, slightly acidic water and a temperature range of 75-82°F. Providing a natural environment that mimics their Amazonian habitat will help these fish display their vibrant colors and exhibit their natural behaviors.

name: Lemon tetra
description: The lemon tetra is a small, tropical freshwater fish native to South America, popular in aquariums since 1932. It grows up to 5 cm in length and has a translucent yellow body with black and yellow fins. In a tank, lemon tetras thrive in planted environments with open swimming spaces. They prefer to be kept in schools of at least six individuals and do well with peaceful tankmates like other tetras, small barbs, and rasboras. They are hardy fish that can adapt to a wide range of water conditions but prefer slightly acidic, mineral-deficient water with a pH of 6.0 to 7.4 and a temperature range of 21 to 28°C. Lemon tetras exhibit interesting behaviors in aquariums, such as males displaying to establish social rankings and courtship rituals with females. Breeding lemon tetras require specific conditions like fine-leaved plants, egg traps to prevent egg-eating, and a temperature of 28°C. With proper care, lemon tetras can live up to 8 years in an aquarium, adding vibrancy to a home aquatic ecosystem.

name: Neon tetra
remarks: Neon tetras must be kept in groups of at least a half-dozen, as they are a shoaling species. With peaceful dispositions, they are also able to be kept with other species of non-aggressive fish.[36]
description: The neon tetra, a popular freshwater fish native to the Amazon basin, is known for its vibrant colors and is a favorite among aquarium enthusiasts. In a fish tank, neon tetras thrive in a densely planted environment resembling their natural habitat. They prefer soft, acidic water with a pH range of 6.0 to 7.0 and a temperature of 72–76 °F. These shoaling fish should be kept in groups of at least six for optimal activity. Neon tetras are omnivores and can be fed flake foods, brine shrimp, bloodworms, and micropellets. Breeding neon tetras can be challenging, requiring specific water conditions and tannins. They are susceptible to neon tetra disease, a fatal condition caused by a parasite. Preventive measures and immediate isolation of infected fish are crucial. Overall, neon tetras are relatively easy to care for and make a colorful addition to a community aquarium.

name: Ornate tetra
description: The Bentos tetra, also known as the ornate tetra or candy cane tetra, is a small characin fish native to the Amazon Basin in Brazil and Peru. In an aquarium setting, Bentos tetras thrive in a well-planted tank with plenty of hiding spots and subdued lighting to mimic their natural habitat in sluggish tributaries. They are peaceful and social fish that do best in schools of 6 or more. These omnivorous fish feed on small invertebrates, so a varied diet including high-quality flakes, pellets, and occasional live or frozen foods is recommended for their optimal health. Providing a stable water temperature between 72-78°F (22-26°C) and slightly acidic to neutral water conditions will help them thrive. Additionally, regular water changes and a well-maintained filtration system are crucial for keeping these colorful tetras healthy and vibrant in a home aquarium.

name: Penguin tetra, blackline penguinfish
description: Thayeria boehlkei, also known as blackline penguinfish or hockey-stick tetra, is a popular choice for aquarium hobbyists. This species thrives in tropical freshwater community tanks with other peaceful fish. They prefer acidic water for breeding and tolerate a range of pH levels. In captivity, they form pairs and scatter their adhesive eggs among plants, with clutch sizes of up to 1000 eggs. The eggs hatch in about 20 hours, and the fry become free-swimming after 4 days. It is best to keep Thayeria boehlkei in groups to allow them to school, mimicking their natural behavior in the wild.

name: Red Eye tetra
description: The redeye tetra is a popular freshwater fish in the aquarium hobby due to its schooling behavior and ease of care. It grows up to 7 cm in length and has a bright silver body with a red circle around its eye. This species thrives in a tank with a volume of about 110 liters, temperatures of 23-28°C, hard water, and neutral pH. They are peaceful but may nip fins if kept alone. It is recommended to keep them in groups of six or more. In the wild, they feed on worms, insects, crustaceans, and plant matter, while in captivity they eat live, fresh, and flake foods. Breeding them requires a separate tank with soft water and dense planting. The redeye tetra is free-spawning, and the eggs need to be cared for separately to ensure survival. Overall, this fish is an excellent choice for beginner aquarists in a community tank setup.

name: Red phantom tetra
description: Hyphessobrycon sweglesi, also known as the red phantom tetra, is a small tetra species native to the Orinoco River drainage basin in South America. It grows up to 4 cm in length and has distinct features like a black spot behind the gill-plate and red fins. In a fish tank, this species thrives in soft and acidic water with a temperature range of 20-23°C. Regular water changes are crucial for maintaining its coloration and overall health. Red phantom tetras are sensitive to water chemistry, so a stable environment is essential. They feed on worms, small insects, and crustaceans but can also be fed prepared foods and small live foods in captivity. When breeding, they can lay up to 400 eggs that require protection from light to prevent fungus growth. Overall, providing a suitable environment with proper water conditions and a varied diet will help these fish thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Rosy tetra
description: The rosy tetra is a small characin species native to South America, particularly found in Guyana and Suriname. It is a popular choice in the aquarium trade due to its light pink-white body with red fins and distinctive markings. In a fish tank, rosy tetras are peaceful and social fish that thrive in schools of their own kind. They prefer a well-planted tank with soft, slightly acidic water and subdued lighting. Providing them with plenty of hiding spots and open swimming space will help them feel secure and display their natural behaviors. Rosy tetras are egg scatterers, so if breeding is desired, a separate breeding tank with fine-leaved plants is recommended. Overall, they are a great addition to a community tank and will flourish in a peaceful and well-maintained environment.

name: Royal tetra
remarks: Possesses an adipose fin allowing it to be differentiated from the Emperor tetra [38]
description:
The royal tetra, also known as Inpaichthys kerri, is a vibrant and active fish species native to Brazil. In its natural habitat, it thrives in sunny and moving waters with a pH range of 6.0 to 6.8. This species is very bold and active, often found schooling with other fish species. In the wild, it mainly feeds on insects that fall on the water surface. 

In a fish tank, royal tetras require soft and slightly acidic water conditions to thrive. They should be kept in a school of similar-sized, non-aggressive fish to prevent stress and disease. Providing a well-planted tank with ample swimming space and hiding spots will mimic their natural habitat and ensure their well-being. It is essential to maintain water quality and monitor their behavior closely to ensure they remain healthy and vibrant in a captive environment.

name: Rummy-nose tetra
remarks: This common name is used for three different species of schooling fish with similar patterns: Hemigrammus rhodostomus, Hemigrammus bleheri, and Petitella georgiae.
description: The rummy-nose tetra, also known as Petitella rhodostoma, is a small tropical freshwater fish originating from South America. It is popular among fishkeepers for its vibrant red head and schooling behavior. In a fish tank, rummy-nose tetras thrive in groups of at least six individuals in a minimum 25-gallon tank with soft, acidic water (pH 6.4-7.0, hardness no higher than 6° dH). They prefer temperatures between 24-31°C (75-88°F) and are compatible with other small, peaceful fish like gouramis, tetras, and catfish. These tetras enjoy a planted aquarium and feed on a variety of prepared and live foods. Breeding rummy-nose tetras is challenging due to their sensitivity to water parameters and slow growth rate of fry. Successful breeding requires soft, acidic water, antifungal treatment, and careful monitoring of the fry's development. Overall, rummy-nose tetras are a beautiful and engaging addition to a well-maintained aquarium.

name: Splash tetra
description: The splash tetra, also known as Copella arnoldi, is a small freshwater fish native to South America. It thrives in tropical river basins, particularly in shallow streams with overhanging foliage. In a fish tank, the splash tetra would require a well-planted aquarium with ample hiding spots and low-hanging leaves for breeding. They have a unique reproductive behavior where the male cares for the eggs by splashing water on them to keep them damp. Their diet consists of worms, crustaceans, and small insects that fall onto the water's surface. Overall, to thrive in a fish tank, the splash tetra needs a peaceful environment with suitable vegetation and space for their distinctive breeding habits.

name: Serpae tetra
description: The Serpae Tetra, also known as the red minor tetra, is a tropical freshwater fish native to the Amazon River drainage in South America. It thrives in slow-moving or still backwaters with a temperature range of 72–81°F. These tetras grow to about 5 cm and have a distinctive red body with a black spot near their gills. They are omnivores, feeding on flake and blood worms. Serpae tetras prefer soft, slightly acidic water and should be kept in schools of at least six fish in a well-planted tank to provide shelter and hiding spots. They exhibit a unique 'sputtering' swimming style and may show aggression towards conspecifics, especially in large groups. Breeding can be challenging, but males are slimmer and smaller than females. Breeding tanks should have fine-leaved plants for egg-laying. Overall, Serpae Tetras have an average lifespan of about seven years and require a peaceful tank environment to thrive.

name: Silvertip tetra
description: The silvertip tetra is a small, slightly aggressive freshwater fish native to Brazil but commonly kept in aquariums. They are transparent with gold colors and a black stripe along their bodies. These social fish thrive in schools and prefer slightly acidic waters with temperatures between 72–82 °F. They can be territorial and may nip at other tetras. Silvertip tetras are relatively easy to care for but can be prone to parasites and infections. Breeding involves the male fertilizing scattered eggs among vegetation, with the eggs hatching after 1.5 days. In a fish tank, they would do well in a school with similar-sized fish, ample vegetation, and stable water conditions to thrive.

name: X-ray tetra
remarks: Also just called the X-ray fish.
description: Pristella maxillaris, also known as the X-ray fish or X-ray tetra, is a small and adaptable characin species commonly found in the Amazon and Orinoco basins. This fish, with its translucent body, thrives in large groups in slightly brackish water and can tolerate a variety of water conditions (pH 6-8; hardness up to 20 dGH). In a home aquarium, it is best kept in groups of at least six individuals and away from aggressive tankmates. A tank size of at least 15 gallons is recommended for these peaceful community fish. They primarily feed on small insects and planktonic animals, making them easy to care for with most fish foods.

name: Congo tetra
remarks: Peaceful but may scare shy species with its active swimming and large adult size. Recommended for most community tanks however. Do not keep congo tetras with fin-nipping species as the spectacular fins of the males will be destroyed.[39]
description: The Congo tetra is a vibrant and full-bodied fish species native to the central Congo River Basin in Africa. In an aquarium, they require a well-maintained environment that mimics their natural habitat with slightly acidic and soft water, a stable pH level of 6.0 to 7.5, and temperatures between 72°F and 82°F. They thrive on a varied diet including quality flake food, frozen or live brine shrimp, and bloodworms. Congo tetras are moderately hardy but are unsuited for smaller tanks due to their large size and active behavior. It is important to maintain good water quality, prevent diseases like Ich and fin rot through regular water changes and proper feeding, and quarantine new fish to ensure their health and vitality. Overall, providing proper care and attention to their environmental needs will help Congo tetras flourish in an aquarium setting.

name: Jellybean tetra
description: Ladigesia roloffi, also known as the Sierra Leone dwarf characin, is a small African tetra species that thrives in soft, acidic water environments. These social fish prefer to live in schools at mid depths and surface levels in freshwater tanks. With a lifespan of five years, they are peaceful and lively, making them suitable for community tanks. They are commonly referred to as "jellybean tetras" in the aquarium trade. To ensure their well-being, maintain a temperature range of 22-26°C (72-79°F) in the tank and provide them with standard flake food. Due to their small size of 3 to 4 centimeters (1.2 to 1.6 inches), they are considered a dwarf species, making them a delightful addition to a well-maintained aquarium.

name: Long-fin tetra
description: The African long-finned tetra, also known as Brycinus longipinnis, is a fish native to the western coastal regions of Africa. It typically grows to around five inches in length and can be found in big rivers, small streams, and estuarine waters. In an aquarium, this species thrives in freshwater but can also adapt to brackish environments. They have a varied diet, consuming insect larvae, crustaceans, algae, and various fish foods. To thrive in a fish tank, provide Brycinus longipinnis with a spacious tank with ample swimming space and hiding spots. Maintain a stable water temperature and quality, and offer a diverse diet including live or frozen foods for optimal health and vibrancy.

name: Niger tetra
description: The Niger tetra, Arnoldichthys spilopterus, is a unique characin fish native to Nigeria. It is the sole member of its genus and is typically found in the Ogun and Niger rivers. This tropical freshwater species grows to an average length of 9.6 centimeters and feeds on worms, insects, and crustaceans. In captivity, female Niger tetras can lay around 1,000 eggs that hatch within 30-34 hours. Due to its limited range, aquarium trade demand, and habitat destruction, the species is classified as endangered by the IUCN. In a fish tank, Niger tetras would thrive in a well-maintained environment with ample space for swimming and hiding spots. They prefer soft, slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 75-82°F (24-28°C) and appreciate a well-planted tank to mimic their natural habitat. It is important to provide a varied diet to ensure their health and vitality.

name: Yellow-tailed Congo tetra
description: The yellow-tailed African tetra is a freshwater fish native to the Congo River basin. In an aquarium, it thrives on a diet of daphnia, bloodworms, artemia, and high-quality dried flakes with plant or algal content. It prefers water temperatures of 22–26 °C, a pH of 5.0-7.5, and softer water. Males are more colorful and grow faster than females, developing distinctive white-tipped fins. This species is an egg scatterer with no parental care, making breeding possible by monitoring and hatching eggs in separate containers. The yellow-tailed African tetra is classified as a species of least concern by the IUCN Red List, with stable wild populations.

name: Common hatchetfish
remarks: Requires a varied diet including fruit flies[40][41]
description: The common hatchetfish, a tropical freshwater fish from South America, is known for its distinctive hatchet-shaped belly and jumping behavior. In a tank, they thrive in groups of five or more, prefer the top level of the water, and need a pH of 6-7, water hardness up to 15.0 dGH, and a temperature range of 23-27 °C (73-81 °F). They are peaceful towards other fish but may bicker among themselves. As carnivores, they eat small worms, insects, crustaceans, and flake foods. To prevent them from jumping out of the tank, ensure a sealed top or lower water level, and provide floating plants for cover. A planted aquarium is recommended for their well-being.

name: Marbled hatchetfish
remarks: Requires a varied diet including fruit flies[41][40]
description: The marbled hatchetfish is a small freshwater fish native to South America, known for its distinctive gold line and marble-like pattern. In an aquarium, they thrive in soft, acidic water and are best kept in peaceful community tanks or species tanks. They are shy and easily intimidated by larger or fast-moving fish, so a calm environment is essential. These fish are known to jump when startled, so a tank with a tight lid is necessary. Marbled hatchetfish are egg scatterers and often kept in small schools. They are adapted to mimic dead leaves floating on the water's surface, moving very little and relying on currents for movement. Their unique appearance helps them blend in and avoid predators in their natural habitat.

name: Black-winged hatchetfish
description: The black-winged hatchetfish is a small freshwater fish with a convex body and distinctive wing-like pectoral fins. It typically reaches up to 2.8 cm in length and has a silver coloration with black patches and stripes. This species is native to the calm streams and pools of the Orinoco and Negro region in South America, specifically Brazil and Venezuela. Black-winged hatchetfish are omnivorous, feeding on insects and crustaceans at the water's surface. In an aquarium, they are peaceful and can coexist with smaller tropical fish like catfish and tetras. To thrive, they require a tank with small floating plants and covered holes at the top to prevent them from jumping out, mimicking their natural hunting behavior.

name: Pygmy hatchetfish
description: The pygmy hatchetfish, scientifically known as Carnegiella myersi, is a small species of hatchetfish originating from Peru. Named after George S. Myers, a prominent ichthyologist, this fish typically reaches a size of around 2.2 centimeters (0.9 inches). Pygmy hatchetfish are known for their peaceful nature, making them suitable for community tanks. They thrive in environments that mimic their natural habitat, which includes densely planted tanks with subdued lighting and floating vegetation. Providing a well-maintained tank with ample hiding spots and a peaceful community of fish will help these hatchetfish thrive and display their natural behaviors.

name: Golden pencilfish
description: Nannostomus beckfordi, also known as the golden pencil fish, is a small freshwater fish found in swamps and slow-moving waters in South America. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a well-planted aquarium with subdued lighting and gentle water flow. They prefer a peaceful environment with plenty of hiding spots among plants. Golden pencil fish are known to be peaceful and social, so they should be kept in small groups to reduce stress. Providing a varied diet of small live or frozen foods will help them thrive in captivity.

name: Hockeystick pencilfish
description: Nannostomus eques, also known as the diptail pencilfish, is a small freshwater fish with prominent horizontal stripes. It is popular in the aquarium trade due to its unique habit of swimming at a 'snout-up' angle. In a fish tank, Nannostomus eques would thrive in a well-planted environment with subdued lighting and gentle water flow. They prefer a peaceful community tank with other small, non-aggressive fish. Providing them with a varied diet including small live or frozen foods will help them thrive. It is important to maintain stable water parameters and keep the tank clean to ensure the health and well-being of Nannostomus eques.

name: Barred pencilfish
description: Nannostomus espei, also known as Espe's pencilfish, is a freshwater fish species from the characin family Lebiasinidae. It is unique for its body pattern of five broad, comma-like patches, unlike the horizontal stripes seen in other species of the genus. In a fish tank, N. espei would thrive in a well-planted environment with subdued lighting and gentle water flow. They are peaceful and prefer to be kept in schools, so a group of at least six individuals is recommended to reduce stress. Providing them with a varied diet of small live or frozen foods will help them thrive. It is important to maintain stable water parameters and keep tank mates that are not aggressive to ensure the well-being of Espe's pencilfish.

name: Dwarf pencilfish
description: Nannostomus marginatus, also known as the dwarf pencilfish, is a small freshwater fish species with prominent horizontal stripes. It is one of the smallest members of its genus, reaching a maximum size of 35 mm. This fish is native to South America and is popular in aquariums due to its small size and striking appearance. In a fish tank, N. marginatus would thrive in a well-planted environment with subdued lighting and gentle water flow. They are peaceful and social fish that do well in small groups, so a tank with other peaceful species would be ideal. Providing them with a varied diet and stable water conditions will help them thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Coral-red pencilfish
description: The coral red pencilfish, scientifically known as Nannostomus mortenthaleri, is a vibrant freshwater fish with a striking coral red coloration and jet black stripes. This species, belonging to the Lebiasinidae family, is relatively small, reaching a maximum length of 29mm. In a fish tank, the coral red pencilfish would thrive in a well-planted aquarium with subdued lighting and gentle water flow. They prefer a peaceful community tank with other small, non-aggressive fish. Providing them with a diet rich in small live or frozen foods will help maintain their health and vibrant coloration. It is important to recreate their natural habitat by adding driftwood and leaf litter to mimic their native environment. Overall, the coral red pencilfish is a beautiful and peaceful species that would add color and elegance to a carefully curated aquarium setup.

name: Three-lined pencilfish
description: Nannostomus trifasciatus, also known as the three-lined pencilfish, is a small freshwater fish popular in the aquarium trade for its beautiful color pattern and hardiness. This species thrives in soft, slightly acidic water with temperatures between 72 and 82 °F. They are omnivorous, feeding on insects and biofilm, making them suitable for community tanks with similar-sized and peaceful tankmates. Males establish territories and spawn during the daytime among plant leaves, with eggs being adhesive and typically placed on plants. The eggs hatch within 24-72 hours, and fry can be found among floating plants if well-fed and provided with sufficient plant cover. It is important to note that this species is rarely bred in captivity, and specimens in the aquarium trade are typically wild-caught.

name: One-lined Pencilfish
description: Nannostomus unifasciatus, also known as the one-lined pencilfish, is a small freshwater fish popular in the aquarium trade for its beautiful color pattern and unique swimming posture. This species thrives in soft, mildly acidic water with low nitrate levels and temperatures between 72F and 82F. They are omnivorous, feeding on insects, small crustaceans, and algae. In a community aquarium, they do well with similar-sized tankmates and tend to establish small territories. N. unifasciatus prefers the mid to lower reaches of the tank and is relatively hardy. Despite being admired in the aquarium trade since the 1920s, successful spawning in captivity has not been recorded for this species.

name: Silver dollar
remarks: The name "silver dollar" may also refer to Metynnis hypsauchen, Metynnis maculatus, or other related fishes.
description: Metynnis argenteus, also known as the "silver dollar," is a peaceful shoaling fish species endemic to the Tapajós River Basin in Brazil. In a fish tank, they thrive in shoals with plenty of room to move and hide, as they can be skittish if left without shelter. They are not demanding in terms of water quality but prefer warm, clear, well-aerated, and well-filtered water. Silver dollars are herbivores but also consume animal matter, accepting a varied diet including dried flake food, live and frozen foods, and vegetables. They are compatible with smaller and larger fish species and are known for their prolific group-spawning behavior. Breeders often use marbles on the tank bottom to protect the eggs during spawning. Overall, providing a spacious tank with hiding spots and a varied diet will ensure the well-being of Metynnis argenteus in a home aquarium.

name: Schreitmuller's metynnis
description: Metynnis hypsauchen, also known as the "silver dollar" fish, is a serrasalmid species found in the Amazon and Paraguay river basins and rivers of the Guiana Shield. It can grow up to 15 cm in length. In a fish tank, Metynnis hypsauchen would thrive in a spacious environment with plenty of room to swim. They prefer a well-planted tank with driftwood and rocks to mimic their natural habitat. These fish are peaceful and should be kept in groups to prevent aggression. They are herbivores, so their diet should include a variety of plant-based foods to keep them healthy and vibrant. Regular water changes and proper filtration are essential for their well-being.

name: Red-bellied pacu
description: The pirapitinga (Piaractus brachypomus) is a large pacu species native to the Amazon basin in tropical South America. It is often confused with the red-bellied pacu due to its appearance in juveniles. In a fish tank, pirapitingas would require a spacious environment with plenty of vegetation and hiding spots to mimic their natural habitat in flooded forests and floodplains. They are omnivorous, feeding on fruits, seeds, nuts, zooplankton, insects, crustaceans, and small fish, so a varied diet is essential for their well-being. Pirapitingas are known to be migratory and may exhibit spawning behavior during the flood season. They can grow up to 88 cm in length and 25 kg in weight. It is important to note that proper research and care are necessary when keeping pirapitingas in a tank due to their size and specific environmental needs.

name: Red piranha
description: The red-bellied piranha, a native of South America, is an omnivorous fish that feeds on insects, worms, crustaceans, and fish. In an aquarium, they require a spacious tank with clean water, hiding spots, and dim lighting. They are known to be messy eaters and should not be fed rotten meats or live prey to prevent disease transmission. Red-bellied piranhas may exhibit fin-nipping behavior, especially when young, but fins grow back quickly. They are primarily scavengers and foragers, not aggressive hunters, and will mainly eat plants and insects when food is abundant. Breeding occurs during the rainy season, with females laying eggs on submerged vegetation. These fish are social and often travel in shoals for protection against predators. Despite their fierce reputation, red-bellied piranhas are generally timid scavengers and can coexist peacefully with other fish in a well-maintained aquarium.

name: Disk tetra
description: The Myleus schomburgkii, also known as the Disk tetra, is a serrasalmid fish species found in the Amazon and Orinoco River basins. In an aquarium, this fish can grow up to 40 cm and prefers a pH of 5.0 to 7.0 and a temperature of 23 to 27 °C. They are related to pacus and piranhas and primarily feed on fruits, small fish, crustaceans, clams, and snails. It is important to note that they are capable of delivering serious bites. To thrive in a fish tank, the Disk tetra would need a spacious tank with ample hiding spots and a varied diet to mimic its natural habitat. It is essential to monitor water parameters closely to ensure their well-being.

name: African pike characin
description: The African pike characin, Hepsetus odoe, is a predatory freshwater fish found in western sub-Saharan Africa. It has a pike-like body due to convergent evolution and can grow up to 28 cm in length. This species prefers quiet and deep waters with dense vegetation. In a fish tank, it would thrive in a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. Hepsetus odoe is a diurnal ambush predator that preys on smaller fish like cichlids and mormyrids. It spawns in bubble nests and guards the eggs until the young attach themselves to the nest. This fish is mainly piscivorous and uses its coloring and vegetation to avoid detection. In a tank, it would require a varied diet of small fish to thrive and should be kept with caution due to its predatory nature.

name: Goliath tigerfish
description: The Hydrocynus goliath, also known as the goliath tigerfish, is a large predatory freshwater fish found in the Congo River Basin and Lake Tanganyika. It can grow up to 1.5 meters in length and weigh up to 50 kg, with large teeth that can reach 2.5 cm in size. This fish is a piscivore, preying on smaller fish using its keen sight and ambush tactics. In a fish tank, the goliath tigerfish would require a large tank with plenty of space to swim and replicate its natural habitat. It would need a strong filtration system and regular water changes to maintain water quality. Tankmates should be carefully selected as the goliath tigerfish is aggressive and may prey on smaller fish. Providing hiding spots and a varied diet would be essential for its well-being in captivity.

name: Hujeta gar
description: Ctenolucius hujeta, also known as silver gar, is a medium-sized freshwater fish native to Venezuela and Colombia. It can grow up to 30 cm in length and is a carnivorous predator that primarily feeds on small fish. In a fish tank, the silver gar would behave as a fast yet timid predator that prefers to stay in the upper layer of the water, near the surface. It is recommended to keep them in small schools initially, but as they grow, they tend to separate. To thrive, the silver gar would require a spacious tank with plenty of open swimming space and hiding spots. Additionally, a diet rich in small fish or meaty foods would be essential for their well-being.

name: Kissing prochilodus, flagtail Prochilodus
description: The kissing prochilodus, also known as the flag-tailed prochilodus, is a migratory freshwater fish native to the Amazon basin. In an aquarium setting, they require a relatively large tank due to their size, reaching up to 27.5 cm in length. They are important in fisheries and are sometimes found in the aquarium trade. These fish prefer a diverse environment with access to both whitewater and blackwater or clearwater rivers, as well as flooded forests. They are known for moving in large groups for spawning and would thrive in a tank that mimics their natural habitat with plenty of space to swim and explore.

name: Marbled headstander
description: The marbled headstander, also known as Abramites hypselonotus, is a peaceful fish species that thrives in a rocky, heavily planted aquarium with fast-flowing waters. They are predominantly herbivorous and should be fed a high vegetation diet, including lettuce leaves and peas. It's recommended to keep them either alone or in groups of seven or more to prevent aggression among themselves. They prefer slightly acidic water with a pH of 6-7.5, soft water ranging from 2-15 dH, and a temperature of 73–82 °F (23–28 °C). Providing hiding places with roots and stone structures is essential to prevent quarrels and allow them to explore. Additionally, they have a tendency to devour aquarium plants if not enough vegetation is included in their diet.

name: Banded leporinus
description: The banded leporinus, also known as Leporinus fasciatus, is a characin fish native to the Amazon Basin in South America. It reaches up to 30 centimeters in length and has a yellow body with black stripes and orange markings. This species is omnivorous, feeding on vegetative matter, fish, worms, and crustaceans. In a fish tank, banded leporinus would thrive in a spacious tank with strong tops to prevent jumping when startled. They can eat algae, vegetative matter, flake food, worms, insects, and crustaceans. They are considered hardy and can coexist with other fish species. It is essential to replicate their natural habitat with fast-flowing waters to ensure their well-being in captivity.

name: Striped headstander
description: Anostomus anostomus, also known as the striped headstander, is a fish species native to South America, specifically found in the Orinoco River and the Upper Amazon. It has a pale peach to pinkish color with long black lateral stripes and can grow up to 20 cm long. This species is a limnivore and omnivore, feeding on a variety of food sources. In a fish tank, Anostomus anostomus would thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of swimming space and hiding spots. They prefer a tank with clean water, moderate lighting, and a varied diet to ensure their health and well-being. It is important to provide them with a balanced diet to mimic their natural feeding habits and to prevent any aggressive behavior towards tank mates.

name: Six-banded distichodus
description: The six-banded distichodus, also known as Distichodus sexfasciatus, is an African freshwater fish with a high-backed body, reaching up to 76 cm in length. It has a reddish-brown to reddish-yellow color with six dark vertical bands and a conical-shaped snout. This species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. In a fish tank, the six-banded distichodus would thrive in a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. It prefers water temperatures between 22-26°C and would do well in a tank with other peaceful fish of similar size. It is known to swim in swarms and schools, so having companions of its own species may also be beneficial for its well-being.

name: Payara
description: The payara, also known as the saber tooth barracuda or vampire fish, is a predatory species found in the Amazon Basin. It has two long fangs used to impale prey, mainly smaller fish. Typically growing up to 30 cm but can reach 51 cm in length, it requires a large aquarium with other large species as tank mates. Smaller fish may be viewed as prey. The environment should mimic its natural habitat with ample space to swim and hide, as well as a varied diet to ensure its well-being.

name: Pink-tail chalceus
description: The pinktail chalceus is a freshwater fish found in South America, known for its small, light-colored body with a distinctive dark red to pink tail. In a fish tank, pinktail chalceus would thrive in a larger aquarium of at least 55 gallons with ample swimming space. They are fast-moving, active fish that prefer to stay near the surface and tend to school together. Pinktail chalceus are skittish and known to jump out of tanks if startled, so it's essential to provide them with plants or driftwood for cover. Keeping a shoal of at least 6 to 8 specimens can help prevent squabbling. While they don't require elaborate tank decor, providing hiding spots can help them feel more secure and relaxed.

name: Red wolf fish
description: The red wolf fish (Erythrinus erythrinus) is a small freshwater fish native to South America, specifically found in the Amazon and Orinoco basins, as well as rivers in the Guianas. It can also be found in the Paraná—Paraguay basin and the Pantanal. This species thrives in creeks and marshes with a pH of 5.6–7.8. Red wolf fish can grow up to 20-25 cm and primarily feed on small fish, insects, and benthic crustaceans. Juveniles of this species are known for mimicking female killifish to catch male killifish. While not a major target for fisheries, it is sometimes used as bait and can be found in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, the red wolf fish would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and a varied diet to thrive. It is important to provide suitable tank mates that are not small enough to be considered prey by the red wolf fish due to its predatory nature.

name: Red tail barracuda
description: Acestrorhynchus falcatus is a fish species found in the Orinoco and Amazon Rivers in regions like Suriname, Guyana, and French Guiana. It can grow up to 30 cm in length and 255 g in weight, primarily feeding on finfish. In a fish tank, Acestrorhynchus falcatus would require a spacious environment with ample swimming space due to its active nature. It is best kept in a tank with similar-sized tank mates to avoid aggression. Providing hiding spots like plants or caves would also be beneficial for this species. Water quality should be closely monitored, with regular water changes to mimic its natural habitat conditions. Overall, Acestrorhynchus falcatus would thrive in a well-maintained tank with a suitable diet and appropriate tank mates.

name: Spotted headstander
description: Chilodus punctatus, also known as the spotted headstander or pearl headstander, is a peaceful community fish that thrives in a group of three or four individuals. This fish species is known for its distinctive head-down swimming position and can grow up to 7 cm in length. To thrive in a fish tank, Chilodus punctatus requires soft and slightly acidic water with a temperature around 26°C. It prefers subdued lighting and places to shelter. When breeding, it is recommended to remove the parents after spawning among floating plants as they can lay around 200 eggs. The fry of this species swim head-down from birth and can be fed brine shrimp as their first food. Chilodus punctatus is omnivorous, consuming vegetables, small live foods like Daphnia, and flake foods.

name: Sunshine peacock cichlid
description: The Nkhomo-benga peacock, also known as the new yellow regal peacock, is a species of haplochromine cichlid endemic to Lake Malawi. In a fish tank, it would thrive in a minimum tank size of 50 gallons with a temperature range of 78°F and a pH range of 7.0-8.0. This semi-aggressive fish prefers a peaceful environment but may become territorial, especially during spawning. It is carnivorous, preferring live foods like blood worms and brine shrimp. The Nkhomo-benga peacock is known to inhabit sandy areas with rocks where it hunts small invertebrates. Males are territorial and display their breeding colors year-round, while females live in small schools. Breeding involves the female mouthbrooding the eggs for four weeks before releasing the fry. This critically endangered species is threatened by capture for the aquarium trade.

name: Pale usisya aulonocara
description: The pale Usisya aulonocara, also known as Aulonocara steveni, is a type of haplochromine cichlid found in Lake Malawi. It is primarily found in freshwater lakes in Malawi. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in an environment that replicates its natural habitat, such as a tank with plenty of rocks and caves for hiding spots. They prefer a sandy substrate and warm water with a stable pH level. The pale Usisya aulonocara is known to be peaceful but can be territorial, so it is best kept with other non-aggressive fish of similar size. Providing a well-balanced diet and maintaining good water quality are essential for the health and well-being of this fish species in a tank setting.

name: Red fin hap
description: Copadichromis borleyi, also known as redfin hap or goldfin hap, is a small haplochromine cichlid fish native to Lake Malawi in East Africa. In aquariums, males can grow up to 13-16 centimeters while females are slightly smaller. They exhibit sexual dimorphism, with males displaying vibrant colors and larger fins compared to the more subdued females. These fish thrive in warm, hard, and alkaline water typical of Lake Malawi, with temperatures between 24-29°C. They primarily feed on zooplankton using specialized suction feeding action. In a fish tank, they require a spacious environment with large rocks and boulders to mimic their natural habitat. Males claim territories near or on top of rocks for spawning, and some variants build sand bowers for courtship. They are polygamous and maternally mouthbrooding, with breeding occurring year-round. Overall, Copadichromis borleyi is a colorful and active fish species suitable for a well-maintained aquarium with appropriate water conditions and ample hiding spots.

name: Eureka red peacock
description: The Aulonocara jacobfreibergi, also known as the eureka red peacock, is a colorful fish species that can grow up to 15 cm in length. Endemic to Lake Malawi, it comes in various color morphs such as red or yellow. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and caves to mimic its natural habitat. They are peaceful fish but can be territorial, so it's best to keep them in a tank with other peaceful species of similar size. Providing a sandy substrate and maintaining water quality is crucial for their well-being.

name: Spilo
description: Champsochromis spilorhynchus, a species of haplochromine cichlid, is native to Lake Malawi, Lake Malombe, and the upper Shire River in Malawi, Mozambique, and Tanzania. In a fish tank, this species would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and rocky structures to mimic its natural habitat. They are known to be territorial and may exhibit aggression towards other fish, especially during breeding periods. Providing a well-filtered tank with stable water parameters and a varied diet will help Champsochromis spilorhynchus thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Blue dolphin cichlid, lumphead cichlid
description: Cyrtocara moorii, also known as the hump-head cichlid or blue dolphin cichlid, is a species of haplochromine cichlid found in Lake Malawi. It prefers sandy substrates and can grow up to 20 centimeters in length. In an aquarium, this fish is relatively tame except during spawning. It thrives in temperatures between 75-78°F and should be housed in a tank of at least 48 gallons, with size increasing as the fish grows. The hump-head cichlid is known for its varying shades of blue and the distinctive hump on its forehead, with males typically being brighter than females. This species would do well in a tank with sandy substrate and plenty of swimming space, along with appropriate water parameters to mimic its natural habitat in Lake Malawi.

name: Afra cichlid, dogtooth cichild
description: The afra cichlid, also known as the dogtooth cichlid, is a small cichlid fish native to Lake Malawi in East Africa. It thrives in rocky habitats and prefers a pH range of 7.5–8.5 and a temperature range of 23–27 °C. This fish has an elongated body with vertical blue and black bars, but its coloration can vary depending on its region of origin. Males can grow up to 10 cm, while females are usually smaller. As a mouthbrooder, males defend territories near caves and feed on algae, while females feed on plankton in mid-water. The afra cichlid is aggressive and territorial, making it suitable for a species-only or mixed mbuna tank. It is recommended to keep one male with several females in a tank with open spaces, hiding spots, and shelters to mimic its natural rocky habitat.

name: Rusty cichlid, lavender cichild
description: The Rusty Cichlid, also known as Iodochromis sprengerae, is a species of cichlid native to Lake Malawi. It grows up to 10.8 centimeters and has a unique coloration where juveniles and females are rusty brown, while mature males display a lavender purple hue. This fish is a mouthbrooder, with females holding fertilized eggs and fry in their mouths for protection. In an aquarium, Rusty Cichlids prefer a temperature range of 24-26°C and need hiding places and space to thrive. They are considered one of the least aggressive mbuna cichlids, making them suitable for aquarists with less experience. However, they can be bullied by more aggressive tank mates if not provided with adequate hiding spots. Rusty Cichlids are omnivorous but should avoid meaty foods to prevent digestive issues.

name: Fuelleborn's cichlid, Blue mbuna
description: The blue mbuna, also known as Labeotropheus fuelleborni, is a cichlid species native to Lake Malawi, preferring rocky substrates. It can grow up to 30 centimeters in length. In an aquarium setting, the blue mbuna would thrive in a tank with plenty of rocks for hiding spots and territories. They are known to be territorial and aggressive, so providing ample space and hiding spots for each fish is crucial to prevent aggression. Additionally, maintaining water quality and providing a balanced diet rich in vegetable matter is essential for their well-being.

name: Electric yellow cichlid
