description: Labidochromis caeruleus, also known as the electric yellow cichlid, is a popular species among aquarium enthusiasts. These cichlids are native to Lake Malawi and are best kept in specialist cichlid aquariums with other Mbuna species. They prefer water with a pH between 7.8 and 8.9 and a temperature range of 23–26 °C. Electric yellows are peaceful compared to other African cichlids but should not be kept with freshwater community species due to their territorial behavior. In an aquarium, they thrive in an environment that mimics their natural habitat with rocks, caves, and a sandy substrate. Their diet should consist of prepared cichlid pellets or flakes, supplemented with krill, bloodworms, brineshrimp, and Spirulina flakes. It is important to avoid feeding them feeder goldfish to prevent diseases. These fish exhibit maternal mouthbrooding behavior, with females carrying and protecting their eggs in their mouths.

name: Electric blue cichlid
description: Sciaenochromis fryeri, also known as the Electric Blue Hap, is a cichlid species native to Lake Malawi. It typically inhabits rocky coastal areas at depths of 10 to 40 meters. This fish can grow up to 11.5 centimeters in length. In a fish tank, Sciaenochromis fryeri would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a tank with plenty of rocks for hiding spots and territories. They are relatively peaceful for cichlids but can be territorial, so providing enough space and hiding spots is crucial to prevent aggression. Additionally, maintaining good water quality and providing a varied diet will help ensure the well-being of Sciaenochromis fryeri in a tank setting.

name: Malawi eyebiter
description: The Malawi eyebiter, Dimidiochromis compressiceps, is a predatory cichlid native to Lake Malawi in East Africa. It can grow up to 23 centimeters in length and has a narrow, laterally compressed body with a large mouth. While once believed to feed on the eyes of other fish, this behavior has not been observed in the wild. In an aquarium, they prefer open swimming spaces and can be aggressive during spawning. It is recommended to keep a single male with multiple females to reduce aggression. A tank of at least 100 gallons is necessary due to their size and behavior. They should be kept with larger, less assertive fish and avoid similarly colored species. Like all Lake Malawi cichlids, they thrive in hard, alkaline water conditions.

name: Hongi, Red-top kimpumpa
description: Labidochromis sp. "Hongi" is an undescribed cichlid species from Eastern Africa, popular in the aquarium trade. This fish reaches up to 5 inches for males and 3.5 inches for females. It is an omnivore and a maternal mouthbrooder. The Hongi cichlid is mildly aggressive and territorial, particularly during breeding. In a fish tank, it thrives in a rocky environment with caves to mimic its natural habitat along the Tanzanian coast of Lake Malawi. It is essential to provide hiding spots and territories to reduce aggression and ensure the well-being of this species in captivity.

name: Yellow Top Mbamba
description: The Labidochromis sp. "Mbamba" is a small maternal mouthbrooding cichlid fish from Lake Malawi. As a member of the mbuna group, they are rock dwellers and typically grow to 3-4 inches in size. In a fish tank, the "yellow top mbamba" would thrive in an environment that mimics their natural habitat, with plenty of rocks for hiding places and territories. They are known to be territorial and may exhibit aggression towards other fish, especially if they feel their space is being invaded. Providing multiple hiding spots and a well-structured tank layout can help reduce aggression. Additionally, maintaining good water quality and a balanced diet rich in protein will contribute to their overall health and well-being in a home aquarium.

name: Auratus cichlid, Malawi golden cichlid
description: The auratus cichlid, also known as the golden mbuna, is a popular freshwater fish native to Lake Malawi. It grows up to 11 centimeters and displays striking color variations between males and females. In an aquarium, auratus cichlids thrive in a rocky environment mimicking their natural habitat. They are best kept in a species-only tank due to their aggressive behavior, especially males. Provide plenty of hiding spots and territories to reduce aggression. They are mouthbrooders, with females carrying fertilized eggs and fry in their mouths. Regular water changes and a balanced diet will help maintain their health and vibrant colors.

name: Chipokee cichlid
description: Aulonocara chipokae, also known as Melanochromis chipokae, is a cichlid species endemic to Lake Malawi, specifically found at Chipoka. This fish prefers habitats with patches of sand among rocks. It is a piscivorous species that can grow up to 12 centimeters in length. In the aquarium trade, it faces a significant threat, leading to a 90% decline in its population and a Critically Endangered status by the IUCN. To thrive in a fish tank, Aulonocara chipokae would require a setup resembling its natural habitat with sandy areas and rocks for hiding spots. It would also need a varied diet that includes live or frozen foods to mimic its piscivorous nature. Additionally, maintaining good water quality and providing adequate space for swimming and territorial behavior would be essential for the well-being of this species in a tank.

name: Blue johanni cichlid, Maingano
description: Pseudotropheus cyaneorhabdos, also known as Maingano, is a species of cichlid found in Lake Malawi around Likoma Island. It prefers rocky substrates at depths of 5 to 10 meters. This fish can grow up to 7.5 centimeters in length. It is often confused with Pseudotropheus johannii, but can be distinguished by the lack of vertical stripes and the absence of orange coloration in females. Both male and female P. cyaneorhabdos exhibit similar coloring, with males potentially displaying more intense colors, especially when dominant or during mating. In a fish tank, P. cyaneorhabdos would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, with rocky substrates for hiding and territorial behavior. It is recommended to provide ample space for swimming and establish a hierarchy within a group to prevent aggression. A well-maintained tank with appropriate water parameters and a balanced diet would help this species thrive and display its vibrant colors.

name: Pearl of Likoma
description: The pearl of Likoma, also known as Pseudotropheus joanjohnsonae, is a small fish species native to Lake Malawi. In an aquarium setting, these fish would thrive in rocky environments resembling their natural habitat around Likoma Island. They prefer a diet of crustaceans, insects, and larvae. Males display a blue coloration, while females are greenish blue with yellowish spots. To ensure their well-being, provide them with ample hiding spots among rocks and maintain a stable water quality in the tank.

name: Red zebra cichlid
description: Maylandia estherae, also known as the Red Zebra Cichlid, is a rock-dwelling fish from Lake Malawi. It is an aggressive and territorial species that should be kept in a large tank with other African cichlids. They prefer rocky terrain with hiding places and will rearrange tank decor to suit their needs. Red Zebras are mouthbrooders, with females holding fertilized eggs and fry in their mouths. They require a pH of 7.5-8.5, hard water, and temperatures between 72-82 degrees F to thrive. Their diet consists of algae, plant life, cichlid foods, and occasional treats like vegetable greens and freeze-dried aquatic fauna. Live foods should be avoided to prevent bloating. It is essential to provide a smooth substrate to prevent injuries caused by their habit of rearranging the tank. Overall, Red Zebra Cichlids are hardy fish that can adapt to various water conditions but will thrive best in a well-maintained tank environment that meets their specific needs.

name: Cobalt blue cichlid, cobalt zebra cichlid
description: Maylandia callainos, also known as cobalt zebra cichlid, is a species of cichlid native to Lake Malawi. It can grow up to 8 centimeters in length and is popular in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a rocky environment that mimics its natural habitat in Lake Malawi. They are territorial and can be aggressive, so providing plenty of hiding spots and territories within the tank is essential to prevent aggression among tank mates. Additionally, maintaining a stable water quality with a pH around 7.8-8.6 and a temperature of 75-82°F (24-28°C) is crucial for their well-being.

name: Kenyi cichlid
description: Maylandia lombardoi, also known as kenyi cichlid, is a popular freshwater fish in the aquarium hobby. It is endemic to Lake Malawi in east Africa and is highly sexually dimorphic, with females and juvenile males being pale white-blue and adult males turning bright yellow with faint brown bars. In a fish tank, kenyi cichlids thrive in rocky environments resembling their natural habitat. They are best kept in single-species tanks or with other similar Mbunas. Being maternal mouthbrooders, females may defend small territories and exhibit male coloration while mouthbrooding. Providing a well-aerated tank with plenty of hiding spots and a balanced diet will help these fish thrive and display their vibrant colors.

name: Fusco
description: Nimbochromis fuscotaeniatus, also known as spothead hap or fuscotaeniatus hap, is a cichlid native to Lake Malawi and Lake Malombe. This species can grow up to 25 centimeters for males and 20 centimeters for females. In an aquarium, they behave as ambush predators, preying on smaller cichlids. The females are smaller and brownish, while the males are larger and blue. They are mouthbrooders and readily spawn in aquariums. To thrive, this fish species would require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and suitable tank mates that are not small enough to be seen as prey. A well-maintained environment with appropriate water parameters and a varied diet would be essential for their health and well-being.

name: Livingston's cichlid
description: Livingston's cichlid, or Nimbochromis livingstonii, is a freshwater mouthbrooding cichlid native to Lake Malawi. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as sandy substrates and ample space for swimming. They are known for their unique hunting method where they mimic a dead fish to attract prey. Livingston's cichlid is a laterally compressed fish with a large mouth, typically mottled brown and white in color. Breeding males exhibit brilliant blues and greens, while females lack the yellow "egg spot" markings on the anal fin. They are carnivorous and primarily feed on small fish. In captivity, they can be fed a diet of small fish or high-quality cichlid pellets. It is important to provide hiding spots and caves in the tank for this species to establish territories and feel secure. Overall, Livingston's cichlid is a fascinating fish to keep in a well-maintained aquarium with suitable tank mates and proper water parameters.

name: Kaligono
description: Nimbochromis polystigma is a cichlid species native to Lake Malawi in Africa. It prefers areas with rock/sand substrate or abundant vegetation. This fish can grow up to 23 centimeters in length and is a piscivorous predator, often preying on juvenile cichlids. Nimbochromis polystigma employs a hunting technique where it lies motionless on the bottom, sometimes on its side, to attract small fish before pouncing on them. In an aquarium, this species requires a large tank of at least 300 liters with rocks for hiding and ample swimming space. They are relatively peaceful but should not be housed with small tank mates. Nimbochromis polystigma is an enthusiastic feeder and can be kept with other haplochromines and most mbuna.

name: Venustus cichlid, giraffe cichild
description: Nimbochromis venustus, also known as venustus hap or giraffe hap, is a Haplochromine cichlid native to Lake Malawi in Africa. This fish prefers deeper waters and has a unique hunting technique where it hides in the sand and ambushes smaller juvenile cichlids. In a fish tank, Nimbochromis venustus would require a spacious environment with sandy substrate to mimic its natural habitat. It is a popular freshwater aquarium fish known for its yellow coloration with dark blotches, and males develop blue coloration on their head and body as they mature. Providing ample space, hiding spots, and a varied diet would help this fish thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Red empress cichlid
description: Protomelas taeniolatus, also known as the Red Empress cichlid, is a colorful and relatively peaceful fish species native to Lake Malawi in Eastern Africa. In an aquarium setting, they thrive in a spacious tank of at least 55 gallons with a pH level of 8.2 and a temperature range of 26-28 °C (82.4 °F). These fish prefer sediment-free, rocky habitats similar to their natural environment. They mainly feed on algae and small invertebrates. While generally peaceful, males can become territorial during breeding times, guarding their territory and displaying aggression towards other males. However, they return to their peaceful nature once breeding is over. The Red Empress cichlid is popular in freshwater aquariums due to the vibrant colors of adult males, adding variety and beauty to the tank.

name: Bumblebee cichlid, hornet cichlid
description: The Pseudotropheus crabro, or bumblebee cichlid, is a species of cichlid native to Lake Malawi. It has an elongated body with distinctive yellow-and-black "bumblebee" bars that can change color rapidly. This fish thrives in large caves or near boulders in its natural habitat. In an aquarium, the bumblebee cichlid is best suited for a species tank or a mbuna tank with one male and multiple females. They are hardy and aggressive, requiring a well-structured environment with hiding spots and caves to establish territories. Feeding them a varied diet is essential for their health. Breeding is relatively easy, with females holding eggs and fry in their mouths for up to three weeks before releasing healthy fry.

name: Yellow-tail acei
description: The Gephyrochromis sp. "acei" Pseudotropheus sp. "acei" is a Mbuna cichlid from Lake Malawi, growing up to 6 inches in length. It is known for its blue body and yellow tail. This fish prefers sandy and rock-filled shorelines with access to sunken logs for algae consumption. In a fish tank, they thrive in a pH above 7.5 and a temperature of 78–82 °F (26–28 °C) in a tank size of 55 gallons or more. They are peaceful and do not require a specific male to female ratio. They are omnivorous but prefer plants and algae in their diet, and can be fed African cichlid food or vegetable matter. Females are ovophile mouth brooders, holding the fry until they are ready to fend for themselves. They are at high risk for Malawi bloat, caused by stress or an improper diet. These fish have bicuspid teeth and are well-suited for a community tank with appropriate tank mates and a suitable diet to thrive.

name: Johanni cichlid
description: Melanochromis johannii, also known as the bluegray mbuna or electric blue johanni, is a highly sexually dimorphic African freshwater fish popular in the fishkeeping hobby. This species thrives in cichlid aquariums with alkaline water (pH 7-9) and temperatures between 22-28°C (72-82°F). They require water hardness ranging from 10-20 and are best kept with other aggressive African cichlids, with one male to multiple females. Due to their aggressive nature, it is recommended to provide plenty of hiding spots if keeping more than one male in a larger tank.

name: Dwarf Mbuna
description: Pseudotropheus demasoni is a small cichlid species native to Lake Malawi, specifically found at Pombo Rocks in Tanzanian waters. It can grow up to 10 centimeters in length and is popular in the aquarium trade. The fish has a dark blue color with black vertical stripes and lighter stripes of blue to white. Males have egg-spots on the anal fin and are larger than females. In a fish tank, Pseudotropheus demasoni would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, with plenty of rocks and caves for territorial behavior. They are highly territorial and exhibit parental care, making them suitable for a species-only tank with other Mbuna cichlids. It is essential to provide hiding spots and maintain water quality to ensure their well-being and reduce stress-induced color changes.

name: Saulosi
description: Chindongo saulosi, also known as Pseudotropheus saulosi, is a dwarf-mbuna cichlid species native to Lake Malawi in East Africa. In the wild, it thrives in rocky substrate areas, particularly in Taiwan Reef. This fish species can reach up to 8.6 cm in length and is popular in the aquarium trade. Males of this species transition from yellow to blue with black vertical bars as they mature, while females remain yellow. They are maternal mouthbrooders, with females holding eggs in their mouths until the fry are ready to swim, typically within 13-18 days. In a fish tank, Chindongo saulosi would require a rocky environment to mimic its natural habitat. It is essential to provide hiding spots and territories to prevent aggression, especially among males. Maintaining a stable water quality and temperature is crucial for their well-being. Due to their endangered status in the wild, efforts are being made to breed and reintroduce captive-bred individuals back into their natural habitat.

Tyrannochromis macrostoma, also known as the big-mouth hap, is a cichlid species native to Lake Malawi. It thrives in rocky shallows and can grow up to 30 centimeters in length. In a fish tank, this species would require a setup resembling its natural habitat with plenty of rocks for hiding spots and territorial boundaries. Providing a spacious tank with good water quality and a varied diet would help the big-mouth hap thrive in captivity. It is important to monitor the tank for aggression, as this species can be territorial, especially during breeding periods.

Benthochromis tricoti, also known as Haplotaxodon tricoti, is a cichlid fish species endemic to Lake Tanganyika in Africa. It can reach a maximum length of 16.5 cm and feeds on small crustaceans and plankton. This species is a mouthbrooder, like many other cichlids. In an aquarium setting, Benthochromis tricoti would thrive in a setup that mimics its natural habitat in Lake Tanganyika. This includes a spacious tank with rocky structures for hiding spots and territories, as well as sandy substrate to mimic the lake bottom. It is important to provide good water quality and maintain proper tank parameters to ensure the well-being of Benthochromis tricoti in captivity.

The giant cichlid, also known as the emperor cichlid, is a large fish species endemic to Lake Tanganyika in Africa. It can reach lengths of up to 90 cm for males and 75 cm for females, making it one of the largest cichlids. In the wild, adults are mainly piscivorous while juveniles are omnivores, and they exhibit habitat preferences based on age. They are commonly found in coastal areas of Lake Tanganyika up to depths of 100 m. While occasionally available in the aquarium trade, their massive size makes them suitable only for very large tanks. In a fish tank, giant cichlids would need ample space, rocky structures for cover, and a diet that mimics their natural feeding habits to thrive. They are best suited for experienced aquarists with the capacity to provide a suitable environment for their size and behavior.

name: Frontosa cichild
description: Cyphotilapia frontosa, also known as the front cichlid, is an east African fish species found in Lake Tanganyika. It can grow up to 33 cm in length and has distinctive black vertical bars on a white or blue body with a prominent forehead hump. In captivity, they can live over 25 years. These fish prefer depths of 30-50 meters in the wild but rise to shallow waters for feeding. In a fish tank, they require temperatures between 25-30 degrees Celsius and plenty of caves for hiding. They are best kept in groups and need a spacious tank with ample hiding spots to thrive.

The featherfin cichlid is a species of cichlid native to Lake Tanganyika, where it inhabits rocky slopes and feeds on plankton. In an aquarium setting, this fish would thrive in a tank with rocky structures to mimic its natural habitat. It is important to provide ample space for swimming and hiding spots. The featherfin cichlid can grow up to 21 centimeters in length and is commonly found in the aquarium trade. It is a peaceful species but can be territorial, so it is best kept with other non-aggressive fish of similar size. Maintaining water quality and providing a varied diet will help this fish thrive in a home aquarium.

Variabilichromis moorii is a small ovate freshwater cichlid found in Lake Tanganyika, Africa. It reaches about 10.3 centimeters in length and is dark brown to black in color as an adult, while juveniles are yellow. In a fish tank, V. moorii would thrive in a rocky environment with relatively shallow water (less than 10 meters deep). They are substrate-breeders, exhibiting biparental care for their eggs and young. They show social monogamy but not genetic monogamy, with males engaging in parasitic spawning. V. moorii are territorial and defend their feeding territories aggressively against intruders, especially fry-eating fish. They exhibit lunar synchronicity in spawning, laying eggs before the full moon to reduce predation risk. V. moorii parents provide care for their fry for up to 100 days. It is important to provide hiding spots and ample space for territories in the tank to mimic their natural habitat and behavior.

name: Frontosa cichild
description: Cyphotilapia gibberosa is a maternal mouth brooder fish species native to Lake Tanganyika in East Africa. In a fish tank, they would require a spacious environment with ample hiding spots and rocky structures to mimic their natural habitat. They are best kept in groups and prefer a water depth of 30-40 meters or deeper. Providing them with a sandy substrate and maintaining water conditions similar to Lake Tanganyika, such as alkaline water with a high pH level, will help them thrive. These fish are known for their social behavior and would do well in a community tank with other non-aggressive species of similar size.

name: Julie cichlid
description: Julidochromis dickfeldi is a cichlid species found in Lake Tanganyika, Africa. It prefers areas with rock or rubble substrates and establishes territories around crevices or cracks. In a fish tank, Julidochromis dickfeldi would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, with plenty of rocks and hiding spots. It is recommended to provide multiple hiding places to accommodate their territorial behavior. They are relatively small in size, reaching up to 11 centimeters, making them suitable for medium-sized tanks. Overall, Julidochromis dickfeldi is a fascinating fish species that would do well in a well-decorated tank with appropriate hiding spots and territories.

name: Masked Julie
size: 15 cm (5.9 in) fem / 10 cm (3.9 in) male
description: Julidochromis marlieri, also known as Marlier's Julie, is a cichlid species native to Lake Tanganyika. In the aquarium, they prefer rocky environments mimicking their natural habitat. They are relatively small, reaching up to 15 centimeters in length, with females being larger than males. To thrive, they require a well-decorated tank with plenty of hiding spots among rocks and caves. They are territorial and may exhibit aggressive behavior towards other fish, especially during breeding. Maintaining stable water parameters and providing a varied diet will help ensure the well-being of Julidochromis marlieri in a fish tank.

name: Golden Julie
description: The golden julie, a cichlid species native to Lake Tanganyika, thrives in rocky environments along the lake's northern and southern shorelines. It grows up to 8.5 centimeters in length. In a fish tank, the golden julie would prefer a setup mimicking its natural habitat, with plenty of rocks and hiding spots. It is recommended to keep them in pairs or small groups to reduce aggression. Providing a sandy substrate and maintaining water quality similar to Lake Tanganyika would help this species thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Julie cichlid
size: 15 cm (5.9 in) fem / 10 cm (3.9 in) male
description: The Convict Julie (Julidochromis regani) is a small cichlid species found in Lake Tanganyika, known for its slender body with a pale to golden yellow color and distinct black stripe patterns. In a fish tank, they require hard alkaline water with a pH of 8.5 - 9.0 and a hardness of 12-14 kH. They are best kept in tanks no smaller than 60-80 liters with rocky decorations to create caves and shelter. Convict Julies are territorial and somewhat aggressive, so it is recommended to keep them with other cichlids to minimize conflicts. They are secretive biparental substrate spawners, retreating to caves for breeding. Breeding is facilitated by acquiring juveniles and letting them grow together until pair-bonds are established. Fry can be fed protein-rich foods like baby brine shrimp, and parents may lead their fry around the aquarium. Overall, Convict Julies are relatively easy to care for if their basic needs are met in a suitable tank environment.

name: Julie cichlid
description: The masked julie, a cichlid species native to Lake Tanganyika, thrives in rocky substrate areas along the lake's northwestern shore. In the wild, they feed on zooplankton and benthic invertebrates found in algae growth. In a fish tank, masked julies would require a setup mimicking their natural habitat, including rocky structures for hiding and breeding. They are relatively small, reaching about 7 centimeters in length, making them suitable for smaller aquariums. Providing a well-oxygenated environment with stable water parameters and a varied diet would be essential for their health and well-being in a home aquarium.

name: Herring cichlid, sardine cichlid
description: Cyprichromis leptosoma is a mouthbrooding cichlid endemic to Lake Tanganyika in Zambia and Tanzania. It grows up to 3 inches in length and has a silvery to blue body color with males displaying yellow or blue tails. In a fish tank, they would thrive in a spacious environment with rocky areas for protection and deep water for swimming. They are schooling fish that prefer to live in mid-water. Their unique breeding strategy involves females choosing males to mate with, after which the female broods the eggs in her mouth until the fry hatch. They feed on pelagic zooplankton using their protrusible mouth. It is important to provide a suitable tank setup that mimics their natural habitat to ensure their well-being and reproduction in captivity.

Ectodus descampsii is a small cichlid fish native to Lake Tanganyika in East Africa. It thrives in aquariums with coarse sand substrates and prefers areas with micro-organisms, algae, and diatoms for feeding. This species grows up to 10.4 centimeters in length and is commonly found in the aquarium trade. To thrive in a fish tank, Ectodus descampsii would require a well-maintained environment mimicking its natural habitat with appropriate water parameters and hiding spots. It is essential to provide ample space for swimming and territorial behavior, as this fish can be territorial, especially during breeding. Overall, Ectodus descampsii would do well in a peaceful community tank with other Lake Tanganyika cichlid species of similar size and temperament.

Chalinochromis is a small cichlid genus endemic to Lake Tanganyika in Africa, known for their bridle-like markings and specialized jaws for feeding on sponges. In an aquarium, Chalinochromis require care similar to Julidochromis. They are secretive during spawning and often choose small caves or crevices to spawn. These fish prefer a tank with flat pieces of slate for spawning. Chalinochromis are popular aquarium fish and thrive in environments that mimic their natural habitat in Lake Tanganyika, with plenty of hiding spots and suitable spawning areas.

The Neolamprologus multifasciatus, also known as "multies," is a small shell-dwelling cichlid species native to Lake Tanganyika. They are one of the smallest cichlids globally, with males reaching 5 cm and females 2.5 cm in length. In the wild, they form large colonies in Neothauma shell beds. These fish exhibit unique behaviors related to their affinity for shells, such as burrowing sand, seeking refuge, and breeding in shells. They have a pale white color with black vertical bars along their bodies. In an aquarium, they require a sandy substrate for burrowing and shells for shelter. Each fish should have at least one shell, ideally two. They are suitable for smaller tanks and are prolific breeders, making them readily available in fish stores. Neolamprologus multifasciatus is sexually monomorphic, making it challenging to differentiate sexes based on appearance. Stores often sell similar species like N. similis and N. brevis as "shellbreeders" or "shell dwellers."

Lamprologus ocellatus is a small, intelligent shell dwelling cichlid native to Lake Tanganyika. In an aquarium, they thrive in colonies with one empty aquatic snail shell per individual and a layer of silica sand for natural behavior. They are not aggressive but will defend their territory. Water parameters should mimic Lake Tanganyika's conditions with a pH of 8.0-8.3, kH of 12-14, and a temperature of 23-27°C. They are omnivorous and should be fed a varied diet including flakes, pellets, frozen foods, and live brine shrimp. Avoid high protein diets and overfeeding. Tankmates should be peaceful species from their natural biotope like Julidochromis, Cyprichromis, and Synodontis. Breeding is possible, with males spawning with multiple females near their shells. Fry can be fed baby brine shrimp.

remarks: A small shell-dwelling cichlid from Lake Tanganyika. Very similar to N. multifsciatus but similis has striping from the body continue to the head
description: Neolamprologus similis, also known as Lamprologus similis, is a shell-dwelling cichlid found in Lake Tanganyika in Africa. This fish species is copper-colored with white vertical stripes and can grow up to 5 centimeters in length. In an aquarium, N. similis thrives in a setup that mimics its natural habitat, such as sandy substrate with shells for shelter. They are monomorphic, with males being slightly larger, and form small colonies or harems. Male fry are tolerated until they become competitors, while female fry are eventually courted as mates. Females may attract neighboring males and could be subject to theft. To ensure the well-being of N. similis in a fish tank, providing adequate space, suitable hiding spots, and a compatible group dynamic is essential for their thriving.

Lobochilotes labiatus, commonly known as the "Lobochilotes" is a fish species native to Lake Tanganyika. It can grow up to 36.8 cm (14.5 in) in length and is popular in the aquarium trade. As a Cichlid species, Lobochilotes labiatus is known for its vibrant colors and unique behaviors. In a fish tank, Lobochilotes labiatus would thrive in a large tank with plenty of hiding spots and caves to mimic its natural habitat. It prefers a well-oxygenated environment with a sandy substrate and rocks to explore. This species is territorial, so it is best kept with other fish of similar size and temperament to avoid aggression. Maintaining water quality and providing a varied diet are essential for the health and well-being of Lobochilotes labiatus in a home aquarium.

name: Lyretail cichlid, fairy cichlid
description: Neolamprologus brichardi, also known as Princess cichlid or Fairy cichlid, is a popular aquarium fish originating from Lake Tanganyika in East Africa. This species is a substrate spawner, exhibiting aggressive territorial behavior during nesting but is non-aggressive towards its own kind when not nesting. It can be found in schools of up to 100,000 individuals within a limited territory. N. brichardi engages in a unique collective nursery system where adults, sub-adults, and fry from multiple generations care for each other's offspring. In a fish tank, N. brichardi would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, with rocky biocover for foraging and a moderate territory for nesting. Providing a diverse diet including small crustaceans and plankton would help maintain their health and behavior in captivity.

name: Lemon cichlid
description: Neolamprologus leleupi, also known as the lemon cichlid, is a small cichlid species found in Lake Tanganyika. It is a recess-dweller that thrives in cracks and crevices, feeding on invertebrates in the substrate. This fish species grows up to 10 centimeters in length and comes in a range of colors from bright yellow to deep brown. Neolamprologus leleupi is a substrate spawner, making it a cave spawner. In a fish tank, this species would require a rocky environment with plenty of hiding spots to mimic its natural habitat. It is best kept in a species-specific tank or with other Tanganyikan cichlids that share similar water parameter requirements. The tank should have a sandy substrate and good water quality to ensure the well-being and thriving of Neolamprologus leleupi.

name: Featherfin
description: Ophthalmotilapia ventralis, a cichlid species native to Lake Tanganyika, typically grows up to 15 centimeters in length. In an aquarium setting, these fish are known to be peaceful and social, thriving in a community tank with other non-aggressive species. They prefer a well-oxygenated tank with plenty of hiding spots like rocks and caves to mimic their natural habitat. Providing sandy substrate and maintaining water quality is crucial for their well-being. Overall, Ophthalmotilapia ventralis is a fascinating addition to a freshwater aquarium, adding beauty and tranquility to the tank environment.

The threadfin cichlid, Petrochromis trewavasae, is a cichlid species native to Lake Tanganyika. It thrives in rocky environments where it can feed on algae. In a fish tank, this species would require a setup with plenty of rocks and hiding spots to mimic its natural habitat. It is important to provide a well-oxygenated tank with good water quality. Threadfin cichlids can be territorial, so it is best to keep them in a species-only tank or with other large, robust fish. Additionally, a varied diet including algae-based foods and protein-rich supplements would be essential for their health and vibrancy in captivity.

Pseudosimochromis babaulti is a cichlid species native to Lake Tanganyika, typically inhabiting areas with rock-rubble substrates. It grows up to 11 centimeters long and is occasionally seen in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in an environment mimicking its natural habitat, with plenty of rocks and hiding spots. It is recommended to keep them in a species-specific tank or with other peaceful cichlids of similar size to avoid aggression. Maintaining water quality and providing a balanced diet are crucial for their well-being.

Tropheus duboisi, also known as the white spotted cichlid, is a small cichlid species native to Lake Tanganyika. These fish reach up to 12 cm in length and are typically found in rocky substrates in the northern part of the lake, at depths of up to 30 meters. They primarily feed on algae growing on rocks. T. duboisi is a mouth-brooder, with the mother hatching eggs in her mouth and providing shelter for the young fish post-hatching. In an aquarium setting, these cichlids would thrive in a tank with rocky substrates to mimic their natural habitat. They would require a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots and areas for algae growth. Due to their vulnerable status in the wild, it is important to provide proper care and attention to ensure their well-being in captivity.

Tropheus moorii, also known as the blunthead cichlid, is a colorful species of cichlid native to Lake Tanganyika in Africa. This fish species exhibits over 40 different color morphs, ranging from dark green to flame red and yellow. They primarily feed on filamentous algae found in rocky shallows. In a fish tank, T. moorii would thrive in an environment that replicates their natural habitat, with plenty of rocks for grazing and territorial behavior. They are maternal mouthbrooders, with females carrying eggs and young in their mouths. T. moorii are herbivorous and would require a diet rich in algae. They are known to establish temporary monogamous pair bonds for spawning, with females investing heavily in parental care through buccal feeding. In terms of behavior, T. moorii exhibit territoriality, especially during breeding and feeding. It is important to provide adequate space and hiding spots in the tank to reduce aggression among individuals. Overall, Tropheus moorii is a visually striking fish species that requires a well-maintained tank with suitable algae-rich food sources and space for territorial behavior to thrive.

Tropheus polli is a cichlid species native to Lake Tanganyika, preferring rocky substrates in the central eastern coast. It can grow up to 16.5 cm in length and is occasionally found in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, Tropheus polli would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, with plenty of rocks for shelter and territories. They are known to be territorial and aggressive towards their own species, so it is recommended to keep them in a species-only tank or with other robust fish that can handle their behavior. Maintaining water quality is crucial for their health and well-being.

Astatotilapia elegans, also known as Haplochromis elegans, is a small cichlid species native to Uganda, specifically found in Lake George, Lake Edward, and the Kazinga Channel. They typically grow up to 7.3 centimeters in length. In a fish tank, Astatotilapia elegans would thrive in a setup that mimics its natural habitat, such as rocky structures for hiding spots and territories, sandy substrate, and moderate water flow. They are known to be territorial and may exhibit aggression towards other fish, especially during breeding periods. Providing ample hiding places and maintaining water quality are essential for their well-being in a tank environment.

name: Zebra obliquidens
description: Astatotilapia Latifasciata, formerly known as Haplochromis latifasciatus, is a cichlid species native to Uganda, specifically found in the Lake Kyoga system including Lake Bisina and Lake Nawampasa. This fish species can grow up to 11 cm in length and is popular in the aquarium trade due to its ease of breeding in captivity. In a fish tank, Astatotilapia Latifasciata would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat in Lake Kyoga, which includes sandy substrate, rocks, and plants for hiding spots. They are known to be territorial and may exhibit aggressive behavior towards other fish, so providing enough space and hiding spots is essential for their well-being. Additionally, maintaining water quality and providing a varied diet will help ensure the health and vibrancy of this fish species in a tank setting.

Haplochromis nubilus, also known as the blue Victoria mouthbrooder, is a cichlid species native to the Lake Victoria system in East Africa. It prefers shallow areas near shores and can grow up to 9.3 cm (3.7 in) in length. This omnivorous fish feeds on algae, small crustaceans, and insect larvae. During spawning, males display black bodies with red anal and dorsal fins, while females have dull brown and green colors. Dominant males can be aggressive and territorial during breeding. In a fish tank, Haplochromis nubilus would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, with ample space for swimming and hiding spots. It is important to provide a varied diet to meet its omnivorous needs. Due to their territorial behavior, it is recommended to keep them with compatible tank mates to avoid conflicts.

name: Allauad's haplo
description: Alluaud's haplo is a freshwater fish native to East Africa, commonly found in lakes like Lake Victoria. It grows up to 19 centimeters in length and thrives in swampy waters. This species is omnivorous, with a diet that includes snails, thanks to its strong jaws adapted for crushing shells. In a fish tank, Alluaud's haplo would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. It is recommended to provide a varied diet to ensure its nutritional needs are met. Additionally, maintaining water quality is crucial for the health and well-being of this fish species.

name: Flameback
description: Haplochromis nyererei is a small cichlid species found in Lake Victoria, Africa, named after Julius Nyerere. Females prefer colorful and bright males for mating. In a fish tank, Haplochromis nyererei would thrive in a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and rocks to mimic its natural habitat. They are territorial and may exhibit aggression, so it's best to keep them with similar-sized fish and provide a well-structured environment to reduce conflicts. Maintaining water quality is crucial, as they are sensitive to changes in water parameters.

Haplochromis phytophagus is a small cichlid species found in Lake Victoria, reaching up to 8.6 centimeters in length. In a fish tank, they would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and plants to mimic their natural habitat. They are known to be herbivorous, so a diet rich in plant matter would be essential for their well-being. Additionally, they are territorial fish, so providing enough space and suitable tank mates to reduce aggression is crucial for their thriving in captivity.

name: African butterfly cichlid
description: Anomalochromis thomasi, also known as the African butterfly cichlid, is a small cichlid species found in Sierra Leone, Liberia, and Guinea. It thrives in slightly acidic, oxygen-rich water with other West African cichlid genera in forest streams shaded by dense vegetation. These fish prefer water stained with tannins from decaying organic matter, resembling tea. In a fish tank, they would require a setup mimicking their natural habitat with plenty of vegetation, hiding spots, and subdued lighting. A temperature of around 30°C (86°F) would be ideal. A. thomasi are pair-forming and territorial, with the female selecting a laying site on a leaf or flat rock. They exhibit parental care, with the female mainly caring for the brood. The fry are moved to multiple depressions in the substrate by the parents until they become free-swimming. Overall, to thrive in a fish tank, African butterfly cichlids need a well-maintained environment that replicates their natural habitat conditions.

name: Jewel cichlid, two-spotted jewel cichlid
description: The African jewelfish, also known as jewel cichlid, is a colorful and popular fish among fishkeepers. They can grow up to 15 cm long and have red bodies with blue spots. However, they are unsuitable for typical community aquariums due to their aggressive territorial behavior, especially during breeding. These fish need slightly acidic and warm water to thrive in captivity. It is recommended to keep them alone or with robust species in large aquariums. They are omnivorous and feed on insects, crustaceans, Caridina, and plants like algae. In captivity, they can be fed a varied diet of commercial frozen, live, flakes, and pellets. African jewelfish are bottom feeders and enjoy eating algae and debris in the tank. They are known to practice filial cannibalism and may bite fingers. When breeding, females turn deep red, lay eggs on a flat surface, and fiercely protect them until they hatch.

name: Lionhead cichlid
description: The lionhead cichlid, also known as the African blockhead or humphead cichlid, is a rheophilic species native to the Congo River. In a fish tank, lionhead cichlids would thrive in an environment that mimics their natural habitat, such as rocky caves for spawning and ample swimming space. They can grow up to 10 centimeters in length and are commonly found in the aquarium trade. It is important to provide them with appropriate hiding spots and water conditions to ensure their well-being and encourage their natural behaviors.

name: Lifalili jewel cichlid, blood-red jewel cichlid
description: The Hemichromis lifalili, also known as the blood-red jewel cichlid, is a vibrant fish species that grows up to 8.2–10 centimeters long. They have a striking red-orange color with small blue spots on their body, head, and fins. These fish feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, small fish, and some vegetable matter. In captivity, they are popular aquarium fish known for their simple breeding process. They lay around 400 eggs on a stone, which the male fertilizes, and the fry hatch after 48 hours at a temperature of 25.5°C. The fry swim freely after five and a half days, mainly led by the female. Hemichromis lifalili thrives in rocky and warm watercourses with temperatures between 22-24°C. They prefer oxygen-rich environments and are not typically found in oxygen-depleted waters, rapids, or swampy habitats. In a fish tank, they would require a well-oxygenated and warm environment with plenty of hiding spots and suitable tank mates to thrive.

name: Kribensis, krib
description: Pelvicachromis pulcher, commonly known as kribensis, is a freshwater cichlid native to Nigeria and Cameroon. In an aquarium setting, they thrive in warm, acidic to neutral water with dense vegetation. They are cave spawners and both male and female provide active brood care. The species is known to be secretive and may form polygynous harems in their natural habitat. They mainly feed on diatoms, green algae, and pieces of higher plants. Breeding pairs may adopt similarly aged fry to reduce predation. The species exhibits sexual dimorphism, with males being larger and more colorful than females. An albino form of P. pulcher exists in the aquarium trade, with a unique inheritance pattern. Overall, P. pulcher is a popular and fascinating addition to a well-maintained aquarium with suitable hiding spots and vegetation.

name: Kribensis, krib
description: Pelvicachromis taeniatus is a small cichlid species originating from Benin and Nigeria, commonly found in soft-water rivers. In aquariums, they thrive in environments resembling their natural habitat, with soft water and ample hiding spots like caves and plants. These fish are known for their vibrant color variations, with geographically distinct varieties such as "Nigerian red" or "Moliwe." They can grow up to 7.1 centimeters in length. During courtship, females display a striking purple pelvic fin as a sexual ornament. To ensure their well-being in a fish tank, it is essential to provide them with appropriate tank mates, maintain water quality, and offer a varied diet. Overall, Pelvicachromis taeniatus is a visually appealing and fascinating species suitable for aquarists looking to create a dynamic and colorful aquarium environment.

name: Guenther's Mouthbrooder
description: Chromidotilapia guntheri, also known as Günther's mouthbrooder, is an African cichlid known for its biparental mouthbrooding behavior. This species thrives in lowland environments with slow or still waters containing submerged tree roots and fallen branches for cover. They are bottom-feeding omnivores that sift through the substrate for small invertebrates, algae, and organic detritus. In a fish tank, Günther's mouthbrooder would require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots like rocks or driftwood. They prefer a sandy substrate and a well-maintained environment with stable water parameters. It is essential to provide a varied diet to mimic their natural feeding behavior. Additionally, since they are sexually dimorphic, it is important to keep a balanced ratio of males to females to avoid aggression.

name: Agassiz's dwarf cichlid
description: Apistogramma agassizii, also known as Agassiz's dwarf cichlid, is a small, territorial fish found in the Amazon basin. It is sexually dimorphic, with males being larger and more colorful than females. They prefer habitats with minimal current and plant debris for shelter. In a tank, they require weekly partial water changes, a hardness level of 50-100 mg/L, and a pH of 6.0. They should be housed in at least a 10-gallon tank with decorations to break up lines of sight. It is recommended not to keep them with other dwarf cichlids but rather with small fish like tetras. They are sensitive to increasing water temperatures, deforestation, and copper exposure, which can impact their ability to thrive.

name: Zebra acara
description: The Zebra acara, scientifically known as Nannacara adoketa, is a cichlid species native to the Rio Uaupes and Rio Preto rivers in Brazil. It can grow up to 10 centimeters in length. To thrive in a fish tank, this species requires a pH level between 4.5 and 6.0 and a temperature range of 22 to 28 degrees Celsius. Zebra acaras are known for their vibrant colors and peaceful behavior, making them suitable for community tanks with other non-aggressive fish species. Providing them with plenty of hiding spots and a well-maintained environment resembling their natural habitat will help them thrive and display their best behaviors.

name: Yellow dwarf cichlid
description: Apistogramma borellii, also known as the umbrella cichlid, is a South American dwarf cichlid that can tolerate cooler temperatures. In a fish tank, they would thrive in an environment with caves for spawning and hiding, as they are cave spawners. To simulate their natural habitat, adding indian almond leaves or increasing tannins in the water is beneficial. Feeding them rich foods like bloodworms or brine shrimp is recommended for breeding. The female will guard the eggs closely until they hatch, and then continue to care for the fry. Overall, providing a well-decorated tank with hiding spots and suitable water conditions will help these fish thrive and exhibit their natural behaviors.

name: Cockatoo dwarf cichlid
description: The Apistogramma cacatuoides, also known as the cockatoo dwarf cichlid, is a colorful South American cichlid commonly bred in captivity. The male is larger and more vibrant in color compared to the female. They are found in the Amazon River basin and prefer water temperatures between 24-28°C with hiding spots like leaves. In a fish tank, they require a minimum of 120 liters if more than one pair is kept, as females are territorial. They are best kept in pairs, trios, or harems with peaceful tankmates like tetras. The tank should have plenty of hiding spots, wood, plants, and caves. Water conditions should be maintained in the pH range of 6.5-8.0, and they can tolerate alkaline water. Breeding in a community tank should be done carefully to protect the fry from being eaten by other fish.

name: Panda dwarf cichlid
description: Apistogramma nijsseni is a small cichlid fish species native to black water habitats in southern Peru. It is a popular choice among dwarf cichlid enthusiasts due to its vibrant coloring and manageable size. In a fish tank, Apistogramma nijsseni would thrive in a well-planted aquarium with plenty of hiding spots and subdued lighting to mimic its natural habitat. They prefer soft, acidic water with a slightly lower temperature range. These fish are known to be peaceful but can become territorial, especially during breeding. Providing them with a varied diet and regular water changes will help maintain their health and vibrant colors in a home aquarium.

name: Three-Stripe Dwarf Cichlid
description: The Apistogramma trifasciata, or three-striped dwarf cichlid, is a fish species native to various regions in South America. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a well-planted environment with plenty of hiding spots such as caves or driftwood. They prefer soft, slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 75-82°F (24-28°C). These fish are known to be peaceful but can show aggression, especially during breeding times. Providing a varied diet including live or frozen foods will help maintain their health and vibrant colors. Overall, they would do well in a community tank with other peaceful fish species of similar size.

Apistogramma eremnopyge is a small cichlid species found in the Rio Pintuyacu in Peru. It thrives in acidic blackwater with a pH of around 5. This fish species grows to 26-35 mm in standard length and is distinguished by a dark blotch on the lower part of the caudal peduncle in both sexes. The male displays vibrant colors of blue, red, maroon, orange, and blue on its body. In a fish tank, Apistogramma eremnopyge would require a setup that mimics its natural habitat with acidic water conditions and plenty of hiding spots like plants and caves. It is best kept in a species-specific tank or with peaceful tank mates to prevent aggression. The tank should be well-maintained with regular water changes to ensure the fish's health and well-being.

name: Two-Stripe Dwarf Cichlid
description: The Apistogramma sweglesi, also known as the Banded dwarf cichlid, is a sought-after freshwater fish native to the Amazon Basin in Brazil and Peru. This species is popular among fish enthusiasts due to its vibrant colors and unique behaviors. In a fish tank, Apistogramma sweglesi requires a well-planted environment with plenty of hiding spots such as caves and driftwood. They prefer soft, acidic water conditions similar to their natural habitat. These fish are known to be territorial, especially during breeding, so it is recommended to keep them in pairs or small groups to reduce aggression. Overall, providing a tank with suitable hiding places, soft water, and a peaceful community will help Apistogramma sweglesi thrive and display their natural behaviors.

name: Checkerboard Cichlid
description: Crenicara filamentosa, also known as Dicrossus filamentosa, is a dwarf cichlid fish found in the Rio Negro and Orinoco basins of Colombia, Venezuela, and Brazil. This species lays eggs on leaves or directly on the substrate, with the female taking sole responsibility for caring for the fry. The eggs typically hatch after 3 days. To thrive in a fish tank, Crenicara filamentosa requires temperatures between 24-29°C, pH levels of 4-6.8, and dH levels between 5-8. It is an omnivorous fish that should be housed in a tank of at least 60 liters with ample hiding spaces for their well-being.

name: Blue ram, German ram, German Ramirezi
remarks: These small and colorful fish require precise water parameters, and if you don't meet those parameters, your fish could be severely impacted.[43]
description: The ram cichlid, also known as Mikrogeophagus ramirezi, is a freshwater fish native to the Orinoco River basin in Venezuela and Colombia. In an aquarium setting, ram cichlids thrive in warm, acidic water with temperatures between 25.5-29.5°C and a pH of 5.2-6.7. They prefer slow-flowing water with minimal dissolved minerals and appreciate the presence of aquatic vegetation for cover. Ram cichlids form monogamous pairs and exhibit biparental care when breeding, with both male and female being actively involved in egg-tending and territorial defense. They lay adhesive eggs on stones or in small depressions in the gravel, with clutch sizes ranging from 150-300 eggs. The larvae are not free-swimming for the first five days and are then escorted by one of the parents in a school for foraging. Ram cichlids are suitable for community tanks when kept as a male and female pair. Various color morphs of the species exist in the aquarium trade, but some of these may have lower fertility and health issues compared to wild-type specimens.

name: Bolivian ram
description: Mikrogeophagus altispinosus, also known as Bolivian ram, is a popular aquarium fish native to the southern Amazon River basin. This species thrives in soft, near-neutral, and warm waters. Bolivian rams are omnivorous bottom-feeders that sift through the substrate for food. They are biparental, open-spawning cichlids that exhibit courtship behaviors before laying eggs on a chosen surface. The fry are cared for by both parents and become free-swimming after seven days. Bolivian rams are relatively shy and should be kept in a tank with hiding places like dense plants or bogwood. They prefer a tank environment that mimics their natural habitat with soft, acidic water. These dwarf cichlids can be kept in smaller aquariums with a minimum volume of 80 liters. They are not picky eaters and readily accept various commercially available fish foods.

name: Dwarf flag cichlid
description: The Flag acara, also known as Dwarf flag cichlid, is a peaceful cichlid species originating from slow-moving rivers, streams, ponds, and lakes in the Amazon Basin. They grow up to 10 cm (4 in) and prefer slightly soft, acidic water but can adapt to various conditions. Ideal for community tanks with other peaceful Amazon fish like tetras and apistos, they are known for pairing up early in life and staying together for life. Breeding is easily triggered with good care, warm water, and live food. They lay eggs on flat surfaces or gravel, with parents taking turns to guard and move the fry for protection. In an aquarium, they thrive in a well-maintained environment with suitable tank mates and conditions that mimic their natural habitat for optimal health and breeding behavior.

name: Midas cichlid
remarks: commonly confused with red devil cichlids, but it is an entirely different species [44]
description: The Amphilophus citrinellus, also known as the Midas cichlid, is a large cichlid fish native to the San Juan River in Costa Rica and Nicaragua. In an aquarium setting, they are omnivorous and can be aggressive towards other fish due to their powerful jaws and size advantage. Careful consideration should be taken when choosing tank mates. Their diet consists of plant material, mollusks, and smaller fish. They have a variable coloration in the wild, ranging from grey to olive brown with black dorsolateral bars, while some may exhibit pink, white, yellow, or orange hues. Selective breeding has produced brightly colored forms known as "golds" in the hobbyist trade. To thrive, Midas cichlids require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and territories to establish dominance. It is essential to provide a well-maintained environment with suitable water parameters to ensure their well-being and minimize aggression.

name: Poor man's tropheus
description: The Neetroplus nematopus, also known as the poor man's tropheus, is a small to medium-sized cichlid found in Central America. It prefers hard, alkaline water with a pH of around 7.5 and feeds on algae, plant material, and chironomid larvae. This fish species exhibits behaviors such as scraping algae off rocks, cleaning other fish of parasites, and excavating nests. In a fish tank, Neetroplus nematopus would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, with rocky surfaces for grazing and digging, as well as ample space for swimming. Providing a varied diet rich in plant matter and occasional live food would help maintain its health and vibrant coloration, especially during breeding when its colors intensify. It is important to ensure good water quality and proper tank mates to prevent aggression, as cichlids can be territorial.

name: Red devil cichlid
description: Amphilophus labiatus, also known as the red devil cichlid, is a large cichlid fish native to Lake Managua and Lake Nicaragua in Central America. In the wild, their coloration varies from grey to pink, red, or white, with some having black pigmentation. They exhibit advanced brood care, forming monogamous pairs and spawning on rocks or logs. In aquariums, red devil cichlids are known for their aggressive behavior, sharp teeth, and powerful jaws. They require a large tank with carefully chosen tankmates to thrive. Due to their aggressiveness, they may attack other fish, equipment in the tank, and even their owners. It is important to provide a suitable environment with hiding spots and space for them to establish territories to prevent aggression.

name: Firemouth cichlid
description: The firemouth cichlid is a colorful species native to Central America, known for its bright orange-red coloration under the jaw. In a fish tank, they would thrive in warm water with a temperature range of 73–86°F and a pH of 6.5-8.0. They prefer shallow, slow-moving water and may benefit from caves or rocks for hiding spots. Firemouth cichlids are omnivorous and form monogamous pairs for breeding. They exhibit territorial behavior, especially during spawning, and may become aggressive towards other fish. It is important to provide them with enough space and hiding spots to reduce aggression in a community tank setting.

name: Jack Dempsey cichlid
description: The Jack Dempsey is a cichlid fish native to freshwater habitats in southern Mexico to Honduras, known for its aggressive nature and striking appearance resembling the famous boxer Jack Dempsey. In an aquarium, they thrive in warm water with a pH of 6-7, hardness of 9-20 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-86°F. These carnivorous fish prefer a well-populated tank with plenty of hiding spots like caves. They exhibit parental care, but may eat their fry if disturbed. Males can grow up to 10 inches in length and display vibrant colors. The blue variant, known as the blue Jack Dempsey, is smaller, less aggressive, and more delicate. It is essential to provide a suitable environment with hiding places to ensure the well-being of Jack Dempsey cichlids in a fish tank.

name: Jaguar cichlid, managuense cichlid
description: Parachromis managuensis, also known as the jaguar cichlid, is a large and robust fish native to Central America. In an aquarium setting, this species would require a spacious tank with turbid water, mud or sandy bottoms, and plant debris for hiding spots. They thrive in warm water with a pH of 7.0-8.7, water hardness of 10-15 dGH, and a temperature range of 25-36°C. Being carnivorous and highly predatory, they mainly feed on small fish as adults and macroinvertebrates as juveniles. Due to their aggressive nature and large size, they are best kept with similarly sized tank mates and in a well-decorated tank to provide hiding spots and territories.

name: Mayan cichlid
description: Mayaheros urophthalmus, also known as the Mayan cichlid, is a freshwater fish native to tropical Mesoamerica, commonly found in coastal lagoons, rivers, and marshes. In a fish tank, they would thrive in oxygen-rich environments with submerged vegetation and muddy substrates. They are capable of surviving in a variety of conditions, including extreme hypoxia and salinity levels up to 40 ppt. Mayan cichlids are territorial and aggressive during breeding, exhibiting monogamous behavior with biparental care for their fry. They have a diverse diet, including plant matter, smaller fish, algae, detritus, snails, crustaceans, and insects. To maintain their vibrant colors, live foods and Vitamin A-rich foods are recommended. These fish are site-tenacious and prefer to stay within a home range, making them suitable for tanks with ample space for territorial behavior.

name: Convict cichlid
description: The convict cichlid, also known as the zebra cichlid, is a popular aquarium fish native to Central America. They are known for their aggressive and territorial behavior, especially during breeding. To thrive in a fish tank, convict cichlids require a minimum of a 20-gallon aquarium with rocks and artificial caves for breeding. They are omnivores and will accept most prepared fish foods, but also consume aquatic plants. It is recommended to keep pairs of convict cichlids alone due to their aggressive nature. They are relatively easy to keep and breed, making them suitable for both beginner and advanced aquarists interested in observing pair bonds and brood care. Ideal tank mates include robust, similar-sized fish like T-Bar cichlids, Honduran red points, Green Terrors, and Pictus catfish. It is important to monitor tank mates closely, especially during breeding, as convict cichlids can become territorial.

name: T-bar cichlid
description: The T-bar cichlid, also known as Amatitlania sajica, is a Central American fish species found in freshwater streams and lakes in Costa Rica. This tan-colored cichlid with distinct bars on its body, including a prominent T-shaped mark, prefers rivers with moderate to strong currents and smaller rocks and gravel. Omnivorous in nature, they feed on algal filaments, aquatic insects, seeds, and detritus. When kept in a fish tank, T-bar cichlids exhibit various spawning behaviors, including cave spawning and open substrate spawning. They are known to be good parents, fiercely protecting their eggs and fry. To thrive in a tank, they require suitable hiding spots for spawning, a varied diet, and a peaceful environment to avoid aggression issues, especially during breeding periods.

name: Wolf cichlid
description: Parachromis dovii, also known as the wolf cichlid or rainbow bass, is a large and predatory cichlid native to Central America. In the wild, it thrives in lakes, rivers, and streams in Honduras, Nicaragua, and Costa Rica. This species can grow up to 80 cm long and weigh up to 14 kg, making it one of the largest cichlids. Known for its aggressive behavior and preference for feeding on other fish, it requires special care in an aquarium setting. Due to its high levels of aggression, it is recommended to keep Parachromis dovii alone in a tank with no tank mates. Experienced aquarists may find this species appealing due to its intelligence and long lifespan of up to a few decades. Despite being common in its natural habitat, overfishing and pollution have led to local declines in some areas. It is important to provide a spacious and well-maintained tank environment for Parachromis dovii to thrive.

name: Texas cichlid, Rio Grande cichlid
description: The Texas cichlid, also known as the Rio Grande cichlid, is a freshwater fish native to the United States and northeastern Mexico. It grows over 13 inches and has cream and turquoise spots, with males developing a nuchal hump. In a fish tank, Texas cichlids need a temperature between 68-82°F and prefer water with minimal temperature fluctuations. They exhibit complex reproductive behavior, with monogamous mating pairs aggressively defending their territory. They have an omnivorous diet, feeding on plants, insects, smaller fish, and even small vertebrates. Texas cichlids are known for their high tolerance for salt water and high salinities. In a tank, they can be aggressive towards other fish, especially when breeding. They are commonly found in the aquarium trade due to their iridescent blue and green markings, making them popular among cichlid enthusiasts.

name: Green terror
description: The green terror (Andinoacara rivulatus) is a colorful freshwater cichlid originating from South America. It can grow up to 30 cm in length, with males being larger than females. Known for its aggression, tank mates should be carefully selected, preferably larger, aggressive cichlids. Juveniles are tan with silver-blue flecks, while adults display iridescent blue, green, and orange colors. In an aquarium, they require a pH of 6.5-8.0, water hardness of 25.0 dGH, and a temperature of 20-24°C. A. rivulatus is hardy and visually appealing, making it popular in the aquarium trade. It is important to provide a spacious tank with appropriate hiding spots and territories to prevent aggression and ensure the well-being of the fish.

name: Blue acara
description: The blue acara is a colorful freshwater fish from Venezuela and Trinidad, known for its steel blue-gray body with green lines and sparkling blueish-green scales. It can grow up to 16 cm in length and prefers a tropical environment with a pH of 6.5-8.0, water hardness of 25° dGH, and a temperature of 22–30 °C. In a fish tank, blue acaras would thrive in a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots like rocks and plants. They are relatively peaceful for cichlids but can be territorial during breeding. Providing a balanced diet of high-quality pellets, flakes, and occasional live or frozen foods will keep them healthy and vibrant.

name: Thread-finned acara
description: The threadfin acara, also known as Heckel's thread-finned acara, is a South American cichlid fish found in the Amazon and Essequibo basins. It has a deep-bodied structure with brownish-silver upper body, silvery flanks, and a pale belly. This fish species is laterally-compressed and has distinct markings like a black streak below the eye and black spots on the fins and flanks. In an aquarium, the threadfin acara would thrive in a setup mimicking its natural habitat, with sandy or muddy substrate for sifting and feeding on invertebrates. They prefer a peaceful environment and would do well in a tank with plenty of hiding spots and plants. Breeding pairs should be provided with a suitable breeding chamber for egg-laying and parental care. The male typically defends the territory while the female cares for the eggs and young. Overall, the threadfin acara is a fascinating species that exhibits interesting breeding behaviors and would make a great addition to a community tank with appropriate tank mates.

name: Eartheater cichlid
description: Geophagus altifrons is a freshwater eartheater cichlid native to the Amazon River Basin, Brazil, but also found in Singapore. It thrives in slow-moving streams and reservoirs, where it sifts sand for food. In a fish tank, Geophagus altifrons would behave as a benthophagous fish, constantly sifting through the substrate for edible items. To thrive, it would need a tank with clear or blackwater, as it prefers these environments over turbid white waters. It can grow up to 22.5 cm in length and is commonly found in the pet trade, often mislabeled as Geophagus surinamensis.

name: Demon eartheater
description: Satanoperca jurupari, also known as the demon eartheater, is a cichlid species native to the Amazon basin. It grows up to 18.5 centimeters long and is known for sifting through substrate for food. In a fish tank, demon eartheaters would thrive in an environment with sandy or rocky substrate for foraging. They are peaceful most of the time but can become aggressive during mating season. Providing hiding spots and ample space for breeding behaviors is essential for their well-being. Overall, demon eartheaters require a well-maintained tank with suitable substrate and adequate space to exhibit their natural behaviors.

name: Greenstreaked Eartheater, cupid cichlid
description: The Geophagus cupido, also known as the green-streaked eartheater or cupid cichlid, is a cichlid species found in the Amazon and Essequibo basins in South America. In an aquarium setting, these fish are best kept in a spacious tank with sandy substrate and plenty of hiding spots like rocks and driftwood. They are peaceful but can be territorial, so it's recommended to keep them in small groups. Providing a well-filtered tank with regular water changes and a varied diet consisting of high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods will help them thrive. These fish are known for their vibrant colors and interesting behavior, making them a popular choice for hobbyists.

name: Keyhole cichlid
description: The keyhole cichlid is a popular choice for aquarium enthusiasts due to its peaceful nature and unique appearance. This small tan-colored fish with a black spot on its upper flank is known for its shy behavior and camouflaging tendencies when startled. In a fish tank, it should not be housed with aggressive species but rather in a community setting. To thrive, the keyhole cichlid requires an aquarium environment that mimics its natural habitat, including plants, rocks, and logs for hiding places. It is a monogamous breeder that spawns on flat surfaces and feeds on crustaceans, insects, and invertebrates. This species will accept a variety of prepared fish foods and occasional live prey like beetles.

name: Flag cichlid
description: The flag cichlid, Mesonauta festivus, is a cichlid species found in various river basins in South America. It can grow up to 12.1 cm in length and is occasionally kept in aquariums. In a fish tank, the flag cichlid would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a well-decorated tank with plenty of hiding spots and plants. They are generally peaceful but can be territorial, so providing enough space and territories for each fish is important. It is recommended to keep them with other peaceful fish species of similar size to prevent any aggression. Overall, the flag cichlid would do well in a well-maintained tank with suitable tank mates and proper water conditions.

name: Angelfish
remarks: In an enclosed tank habitat, the fish's territorial, aggressive nature is heightened, so don't house angelfish with shy species that are intimidated by pushy, boisterous fish.[45]
description: The Pterophyllum scalare, commonly known as angelfish, is a popular freshwater species native to the Amazon Basin. In captivity, angelfish thrive in tanks with dense vegetation and clear or silty water. They prefer a pH range of 6.0 to 7.0, water hardness of 3 to 10 °dH, and a temperature of 26 to 30 °C (75 to 86 °F). Angelfish have a varied diet including fish fry, shrimps, worms, larvae, and insects. In aquariums, they readily consume frozen, freeze-dried, and live foods like bloodworms, brine shrimp, and fruit flies. Providing a diverse diet is essential for their health and to mimic their natural feeding habits. Angelfish are not picky eaters and can adapt well to different food types. They are peaceful fish but can be territorial during breeding. It is important to provide them with enough space and hiding spots in the tank to reduce aggression. Overall, angelfish are a beautiful addition to a well-maintained aquarium with suitable water conditions and a varied diet.

name: Altum angelfish
description: The Altum Angelfish, also known as Pterophyllum altum, is a large fish species native to the Orinoco River Basin and Upper Rio Negro watershed in South America. It can grow up to 38 cm in height and has a silver base color with brownish/red vertical stripes and red striations in the fins. This species thrives in well-oxygenated, extremely soft waters with a pH range between 4.5 and 5.8 and temperatures between 78 and 84°F. Altum angelfish prefer to spawn on submerged roots and tree branches in moderate water currents. They are challenging to breed in captivity and are recommended for intermediate to advanced aquarists due to their specific care requirements. To thrive in a fish tank, Altum angelfish need a large tank with soft, acidic water, plenty of hiding spots, and a diet rich in live foods.

name: Spotted angelfish
description: Pterophyllum leopoldi, also known as the teardrop angelfish, is a small angelfish species native to the Amazon River, Essequibo River, and Rupununi River. It is the smallest of the angelfish species, reaching up to 10 centimeters in length. In a fish tank, P. leopoldi would thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of plants for hiding spots and vertical space for swimming. They prefer slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 75-82°F. It is important to provide them with a varied diet including high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods. They are peaceful fish but may become territorial during breeding. It is essential to keep them in pairs or groups to prevent aggression.

name: Common discus, red discus
description: The Symphysodon discus, also known as the red discus or Heckel discus, is a cichlid fish native to the Amazon Basin in Brazil. It thrives in blackwater habitats with temperatures ranging from 26-32°C and a low pH of 4.2-5.2. Growing up to 20 cm in length, this species is popular in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, the red discus would require a well-maintained environment mimicking its natural habitat, including warm water and acidic conditions. They are known to be caring parents, with small fry feeding on the mucus produced by their parents. To thrive in a fish tank, providing suitable water parameters and a peaceful community setting would be essential for the well-being of the red discus.

name: Blue discus, green discus
description: The blue discus, also known as the brown discus, is a cichlid species native to the eastern and central Amazon Basin. It thrives in lentic habitats such as floodplains and flooded forests with high temperatures of 25–32 °C and a pH of 5.2–7.7. In aquariums, it can reach up to 15.2 centimeters in length. This species is commonly kept in aquariums and is known for its disputed taxonomy. In terms of behavior in a fish tank, the blue discus would require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and plants to mimic its natural habitat. It is a peaceful fish that does well in a community tank with other non-aggressive species. Maintaining stable water parameters, especially temperature and pH, is crucial for the health and well-being of the blue discus.

name: Oscar
remarks: Many people that purchase these fish do not realize that the fish could grow to a foot long (30 cm) within a year. Due to their fast growth rate and large size as an adult, they are often kept in aquariums that are too small for them.[46]
description: The oscar (Astronotus ocellatus) is a popular cichlid species native to tropical South America, commonly found in slow-moving white-water habitats. In an aquarium, oscars are omnivores that thrive on a diet of large carnivorous fish food, including crayfish, worms, and insects. They are territorial and aggressive, often claiming an area in the tank and defending it vigorously. Oscars can grow up to 45 cm in length and require a spacious tank with hiding spots like submerged branches. They exhibit ritualized territorial and combat behaviors, and their coloration can change rapidly. Oscars are known for their biparental substrate spawning behavior, with females laying hundreds to thousands of eggs. Various ornamental varieties of oscars are available in the aquarium trade, including red tiger oscars and albino forms. It is important to provide oscars with a well-maintained tank environment, proper diet, and adequate space to thrive in captivity.

name: Chocolate cichlid
description: The emerald cichlid, also known as Hypselecara temporalis, is a small fish species native to South America, specifically Brazil, Colombia, and Peru. It can grow up to 12 inches long and thrives in tropical climates with temperatures ranging between 25 to 30 degrees Celsius. In a fish tank, emerald cichlids would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots such as rocks, caves, and plants to mimic their natural habitat. They are peaceful fish but can be territorial, so it's best to keep them in a tank with other non-aggressive species of similar size. Maintaining good water quality and providing a varied diet will help these fish thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Severum
description: Heros efasciatus, a tropical freshwater cichlid from the Amazon basin, is popular in the aquarium trade, especially in its gold variation. This species is unique as it acts as a frugivore, particularly during the wet season. In a fish tank, Heros efasciatus would thrive in a well-maintained environment with ample space to swim and explore.
