They prefer a diet that includes fruits and vegetables along with regular cichlid food. It is important to provide hiding spots and plants for them to feel secure. Additionally, maintaining water quality and suitable tank mates are crucial for their well-being.

name: Uaru, waroo
remarks: Also known as the Triangle Cichlid.
description: The Uaru amphiacanthoides, also known as the uaru or triangle cichlid, is a species of cichlid found in the Amazon Basin. It can grow up to 25 centimeters in length. In an aquarium setting, Uaru fish are known for their peaceful nature but can be territorial during breeding. They thrive in a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots like rocks and driftwood. A dimly lit environment with soft, acidic water and a sandy substrate mimicking their natural habitat is ideal for their well-being. These fish are omnivores, so a varied diet including vegetables and protein-rich foods is essential for their health and vibrant colors.

name: Zebra Pike Cichlid
description: Crenicichla zebrina, a cichlid species native to South America, specifically the Ventuari River in Venezuela, can grow up to 26.4 cm (10.4 in) in length. In a fish tank, Crenicichla zebrina would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots like rocks and plants. They are territorial and may exhibit aggressive behavior towards other fish, so it's best to keep them with fish of similar size and temperament. Providing a varied diet and maintaining good water quality are essential for their well-being in captivity.

name: Butterfly peacock bass
description: The Butterfly Peacock Bass, also known as Cichla ocellaris, is a large cichlid species native to South America and prized as a game fish. It can reach up to 29 inches in length and is known for its colorful body and fins, with three vertical black lines along its sides. This species thrives in warm, slow-moving bodies of water like lakes, ponds, and canals, preferring temperatures above 60 degrees Fahrenheit and salinities below 18 ppt. In a fish tank, Butterfly Peacock Bass would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like rocks and vegetation. They are aggressive predators that primarily feed on other fish, so tank mates should be chosen carefully to avoid conflicts. Providing a varied diet of live fish and suitable tank conditions would help them thrive.

name: Orinoco peacock bass
description: Cichla orinocensis, also known as the Orinoco peacock bass, is a large cichlid native to the Rio Negro and Orinoco River basins in northern South America. This fish thrives in blackwater rivers, preferring slow-moving and shallow waters. They can tolerate turbid conditions and grow up to about 62 cm in length. Adults are easily identifiable by three large gold-edged dark spots on their body. In a fish tank, C. orinocensis would require a spacious tank with ample hiding spots and a sandy substrate to mimic its natural habitat. It is essential to maintain good water quality and provide a varied diet to ensure the well-being of this species.

name: Speckled peacock bass
description: Cichla temensis, also known as the speckled pavon or three-barred peacock bass, is a large South American cichlid prized for its size and beauty. It can reach up to 1m in length and 13kg in weight, making it one of the largest cichlids in the world. This fish is native to blackwater rivers in South America, specifically the Orinoco and Rio Negro basins. In a fish tank, C. temensis would require a large tank with plenty of space to swim due to its size. It thrives in environments that mimic its natural habitat, such as blackwater rivers, so a tank with dim lighting, soft acidic water, and plenty of hiding spots like rocks and driftwood would be ideal. It is important to note that this fish can be territorial, so it is best kept with other large, robust fish species.

name: Canara pearlspot
description: The Canara pearlspot, also known as banded chromide or Canara pearlspot cichlid, is an endangered freshwater cichlid native to South Karnataka, India. This species, which can grow up to 11.5 centimeters in length, is a rare find in hobby aquariums due to its endangered status. The Canara pearlspot is not typically found in brackish waters like other cichlids in its genus. In a fish tank, it would require a freshwater environment with ample space to swim and hide. Providing suitable plants and rocks for shelter would be beneficial for this species to thrive. It is essential to maintain water quality and temperature within the optimal range for the Canara pearlspot's well-being.

name: Green chromide
description: The green chromide, also known as Etroplus suratensis, is a cichlid fish native to fresh and brackish water habitats in India and Sri Lanka. This species thrives in brackish water environments such as river deltas and feeds on aquatic plants, algae, and occasional animal matter. In a fish tank, the green chromide would require a spacious tank with plenty of plants for hiding spots and territories. They are known for engaging in attentive parental care and prefer to be kept in groups. Providing a varied diet including plant matter and occasional protein-rich foods would help them thrive in a tank environment. Overall, the green chromide is a popular food fish and a delicacy in certain regions, making it a unique and interesting addition to a suitable aquarium setup.

name: Orange chromide
description: The orange chromide, also known as Etroplus maculatus, is a cichlid fish native to southern India and Sri Lanka. It is popular among fishkeeping hobbyists due to its vibrant coloration and small size, reaching up to 8 cm in length. In an aquarium, orange chromides thrive in freshwater or brackish environments mimicking their natural habitat of streams, lagoons, and estuaries. They are known to coexist with the green chromide and play a role in cleaning larger fish by removing parasites. Their diet consists of zooplankton, algae, and even the mucous coating of their parents as young fry. To ensure their well-being, provide them with a suitable tank size, water conditions, and a varied diet to replicate their natural feeding habits and maintain their health and vibrant colors.

name: Pinstripe damba
description: Paretroplus menarambo, also known as the pinstripe menarambo or pinstripe damba, is a cichlid fish species found in the Sofia River system in northwestern Madagascar. It has a deep-bodied structure, reaching up to 12.8–25 centimeters in length, with a brown-gray coloration featuring vertical darker bands and gray fins with reddish-brown borders. This species was once considered extinct in the wild but has been rediscovered in Lake Tseny. In a fish tank, Paretroplus menarambo would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and moderate water flow. It is essential to provide a balanced diet and maintain water quality to ensure the well-being of this species.

name: Blood parrot cichlid
remarks: Not considered a separate species of cichlid but a hybrid.[47]
description: The blood parrot cichlid is a hybrid fish known for its bright orange coloration and various anatomical deformities. Despite its deformities, it is a semi-aggressive fish that can hold its own in a fight and may prey on smaller fish. Blood parrots can grow up to 8 inches in length and live for 10 to 15 years. They are hardy fish that can be housed singly, in schools, or with compatible species in a tank with sufficient lighting and high-volume filtration. Blood parrots are voracious eaters, so regular substrate suctioning and maintenance are necessary to minimize nitrates. An aquarium size of at least 55 gallons is recommended for one blood parrot, with an additional 20 gallons for each extra fish. Overall, blood parrots require a well-maintained tank with appropriate tank mates to thrive and exhibit their natural behaviors.

name: Flowerhorn cichlid
remarks: Not considered a separate species of cichlid but a hybrid.[47]
description: Flowerhorn cichlids are popular ornamental aquarium fish known for their vibrant colors and distinctive head shape. They are hybrids that were first introduced in Malaysia in the late 1990s and have since gained popularity worldwide. In a fish tank, Flowerhorn cichlids are aggressive and can be territorial, so they are best kept alone or with larger, equally robust tank mates. They require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and a sandy substrate. Flowerhorns are prone to diseases like hole-in-head disease and ich, so maintaining good water quality is essential for their health. They thrive in warm water with a pH level around 7.5-8.0. Overall, Flowerhorn cichlids are fascinating fish to keep, but their care requirements and potential aggression should be carefully considered before adding them to a tank.

name: Arulius barb
description: The Arulius barb, also known as Dawkinsia arulius, is a tropical fish native to the Kaveri River basin in southeast India. It has a dark brownish olive color with black vertical blotches on its body and fins. This peaceful and active fish thrives in large streams, rivers, and lakes with a pH of 6.0 – 6.5, dH of 10, and a temperature range of 19 °C to 25 °C. In a home aquarium, it is best kept with other similar-sized, fast-swimming cyprinid species like tiger barbs and rosy barbs. It can also coexist with some cichlid species but may exhibit nippy behavior, which can be reduced by keeping them in groups of 5-6 individuals. The tank should be spacious enough to accommodate their adult size of 4-5 inches (10-12 cm). Smaller fish like neon tetras may be at risk of predation if housed with Arulius barbs.

name: Bigspot barb, Duncker's barb
description: Barbodes dunckeri, also known as the bigspot barb or clown barb, is a cyprinid fish native to the Malay Peninsula. It thrives in clear streams and acidic swamps in its natural habitat. In an aquarium setting, this species would require a well-maintained tank with ample space for swimming and hiding spots. It is important to mimic its natural environment by maintaining clean water conditions and providing plants or decorations for shelter. The bigspot barb is a peaceful fish that can be kept in a community tank with other non-aggressive species of similar size. It is a lively swimmer and would benefit from a varied diet consisting of high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods.

name: Black ruby barb
description: The black ruby barb, native to Sri Lanka, is a colorful fish that grows up to 2-3 inches in length. In a fish tank, they thrive in a tropical environment with cool, shady, and gently flowing water. They prefer a pH of 6.0-6.5, water hardness of 5-12 dGH, and a temperature range of 72-79 °F. These fish are omnivorous, feeding on filamentous algae and detritus. To thrive, they need plenty of room, light, floating plants, vegetation, and a layer of humus at the tank bottom. They are best kept in schools of at least six and are compatible with other barbs and similar fish species.

name: Cherry barb
description: The cherry barb, also known as Puntius titteya, is a small tropical freshwater fish native to Sri Lanka. It is popular in the aquarium trade but is threatened by overcollection and habitat loss. In a fish tank, cherry barbs thrive in a heavily shaded, shallow, and calm water environment with silty substrate and leaf cover. They prefer a pH of 6 to 8, water hardness of 5 to 19 dH, and a temperature range of 73°F to 81°F. Cherry barbs are schooling fish best kept in groups of five or more individuals, with a ratio of at least two females to one male to prevent aggression. They need abundant plant material in the tank for hiding and open space for swimming. Tankmates should include peaceful fish like Rasbora. When breeding, the male becomes aggressive, chasing away rivals while the female scatters 200 to 300 eggs on plants and substrate. The fry hatch in one to two days and become free-swimming after two more days.

name: Clipper barb
description: The clipper barb, also known as Congo barb, is a freshwater and brackish tropical fish native to West Africa. It grows up to 3 inches in length and has a silverish-golden body with red-orange accents on its fins. In a fish tank, clipper barbs thrive in freshwater with a temperature range of 66–77 °F (19–25 °C). They are peaceful and active swimmers, making them suitable for community tanks with other non-aggressive fish of similar size. Providing ample swimming space, hiding spots, and a well-maintained environment will help these fish thrive.

name: Clown barb
description: The Clown barb, also known as Barbodes everetti, is a cyprinid fish native to Borneo and Sumatra. It thrives in clear streams in forested foothills and can adapt to shallow forest floor puddles. This species has a diet that includes small crustaceans, worms, insects, and plant material. In an aquarium, Clown barbs would require a well-maintained tank with ample space for swimming and hiding spots. They are peaceful fish but may exhibit some fin nipping behavior, so it's best to keep them in a group of their own kind or with other peaceful tank mates. Providing a varied diet and maintaining water quality are essential for their health and well-being in a tank environment.

name: Denison's barb, red line torpedo barb
description: The Denison barb, also known as Denison's barb or roseline shark, is an endangered species native to the fast-flowing hill streams and rivers of the Western Ghats in India. This torpedo-shaped fish has silver scales with a distinctive red line running from the snout to the tail, and a black line below it. They grow to about 9-11 centimeters and are active shoaling fish. In an aquarium, Denison barbs thrive in subtropical environments with a pH of 6.8-7.8, water hardness of 5-25 dGH, and a temperature range of 65-79°F. They prefer rocky pools with thick vegetation along the banks. These fish are peaceful but can be slightly aggressive around food if not given enough space. They eat bloodworms, shrimp, meat, fish flakes, and some vegetation. Efforts to breed them in captivity have been successful, offering hope for conservation and the ornamental fish trade in India.

name: Gold barb
description: The Chinese barb, also known as the Gold Barb or Schuberti Barb, is a popular aquarium fish native to the Red River basin in southeast Asia. This species is characterized by its highly arched back, metallic green or yellow-green sides, and a brassy or golden sheen. They are active, mildly aggressive schooling fish that prefer the mid-level and bottom of the tank. The Gold Barb thrives in community tanks and can live for around four to six years in captivity. They are egg-scatterers and breed readily in outdoor pools during the summer. This fish species enjoys a diet of invertebrates and plant matter, but also benefits from occasional live food such as mosquito larvae or daphnia. Providing a well-maintained aquarium with plenty of hiding spots and a varied diet will help these fish thrive and display their vibrant colors.

name: Golden barb
description: The golden barb, also known as the golden dwarf barb, is a small cyprinid fish native to Asia. In the wild, it inhabits rivers and standing water with a silty bottom. To thrive in a fish tank, the golden barb requires a tropical environment with a pH of 6.0 - 6.5, water hardness of 8 - 15 dGH, and a temperature range of 68–77 °F (20–25 °C). This species feeds on crustaceans, insects, and plankton. In an aquarium, they are open water egg-scatterers and do not guard their eggs, often spawning in shallow water. A suitable tank for golden barbs should mimic their natural habitat with plenty of open swimming space and hiding spots.

name: Greenstripe barb
description: The greenstripe barb, also known as Puntius vittatus, is a small tropical freshwater and brackish fish originating from Asia. It grows up to 5 centimeters in length and is an open water, substrate egg-scatterer. In a fish tank, the greenstripe barb would thrive in a tropical environment with a pH of 6.0-6.5, water hardness of 8-15 dGH, and a temperature range of 68-75°F. It prefers ponds, streams, and lakes with filamentous algae and blue-green algae as its main diet. This species is commonly found in rice fields and can adapt to brackish water. The greenstripe barb is commercially popular in the aquarium trade and is also used as bait.

name: Indian Glass Barb
description: The Indian glass barb, found in various countries in South Asia, is a cyprinid fish known for its peaceful nature and schooling behavior. In a fish tank, they thrive in a well-planted environment with plenty of open swimming space. They prefer soft, slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 72-79°F (22-26°C). Providing hiding spots and a varied diet consisting of flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods will help them thrive. It is essential to keep them in groups of at least six to reduce stress and display their natural schooling behavior.

name: Melon barb
description: The melon barb, also known as Haludaria fasciata, is a small cyprinid fish native to rivers in South India. In an aquarium, they thrive in a tropical environment with a pH of 6.0-6.5, water hardness of around 5 dGH, and a temperature range of 22-26°C. These fish grow up to 6 centimeters in length and are commonly found in the aquarium trade. Melon barbs are open water egg-scatterers, with males displaying red coloration and nuptial tubercles on their snouts during breeding. They do not guard the eggs, and the females are induced to release eggs through gentle bumping and rubbing by the males. To ensure the well-being of melon barbs in a fish tank, provide them with ample swimming space and suitable water parameters to mimic their natural habitat in rivers.

name: Odessa barb
description: The Odessa barb is a small, colorful fish species originating from Central Myanmar. In an aquarium setting, it thrives in a community tank environment with open spaces and hiding spots. It is best kept in groups of 5 or more to prevent aggression towards other tank mates. This active and peaceful fish is a voracious eater, accepting various foods including flakes and frozen options. It can coexist with other peaceful species like Tetras, Corydoras catfish, danios, and Ram cichlids. The Odessa barb is known for its striking red stripe in males and plain coloration in females. It is an egg scatterer, laying eggs on plant matter, with no parental care provided. The fry mature within 5-8 months depending on environmental conditions.

name: Onespot barb
description: The onespot barb, also known as Teri barb, is a tropical freshwater fish originating from Asia. It grows up to 4 inches in length and has distinct coloration between males and females. In a fish tank, onespot barbs would thrive in a tropical environment with a pH of 7.0-8.0, water hardness of 15-30 dGH, and a temperature range of 64-82 °F (18-28 °C). They prefer habitats with silt and mud substrates, similar to rivers, canals, and ponds. These fish are commercially popular in the aquarium trade industry.

name: Panda barb
description: The melon barb, a common cyprinid fish species native to South India, thrives in tropical river environments with a pH of 6.0—6.5, water hardness of 5 dGH, and temperatures of 22–26 °C. In a fish tank, they require ample swimming space as they are open water egg-scatterers. Males exhibit vibrant red coloration during breeding and develop tubercles on their snouts to stimulate egg release from females. To ensure their well-being in captivity, provide a spacious tank with suitable water parameters and a peaceful community of fish to mimic their natural habitat.

name: Pool barb
description: The pool barb, also known as the spotfin swamp barb, is a tropical freshwater and brackish fish native to Asia. It belongs to the Puntius genus and can grow up to 18 cm in length. In a fish tank, pool barbs thrive in a well-maintained environment with a temperature range of 20-30°C. They prefer habitats that mimic rivers, streams, and ponds with ample space for shoaling. To breed successfully, females require a GSI of 10.5 units and a body fitness of 1.6-1.7 units. Providing a suitable tank setup with appropriate water conditions and space for social interaction will help pool barbs thrive and exhibit their natural shoaling behavior.

name: Partipentazona barb
description:
The Dwarf Tiger Barb, scientifically known as Puntigrus partipentazona, is a small cyprinid fish native to Southeast Asia. In the wild, it thrives in streams and impoundments with dense weed growth in basins of Thailand, the Malay Peninsula, and coastal streams of southeast Thailand and Cambodia. This species can reach a length of 4 centimeters and has a silver to brownish yellow body with three broad black vertical stripes and a distinctive black blotch at the base of the dorsal fin. 

In a fish tank, Dwarf Tiger Barbs would thrive in a well-planted aquarium with ample open swimming space. They are open water egg-scatterers that do not guard their eggs, so dense plant growth is essential for successful spawning. The fish prefer a peaceful environment with other small, non-aggressive tank mates. It is important to provide a varied diet to meet their nutritional needs and maintain water quality to ensure their health and well-being.

name: Rosy barb
description: The rosy barb is a colorful freshwater fish species native to southern Asia, growing up to 6 inches in length. In an aquarium, they thrive in a community setting with other small fish but can be aggressive and nip fins. They prefer a tank with a minimum length of 30 inches, dark-colored gravel to enhance their colors, and a group of 5 or more individuals. Rosy barbs are hardy, active, and peaceful, making them suitable for beginners. They require a pH of 6 to 8, water hardness of 5-19 dGH, and a temperature range of 64–72 °F. Their diet consists of worms, insects, crustaceans, and plant matter. During mating, males display vibrant colors and females appear swollen with eggs. Spawning occurs in the early morning, resulting in several hundred eggs deposited in groups of plants. The young hatch in 24 to 36 hours and can be fed newly hatched brine shrimp.

name: Shortfin barb
description: The shortfin barb, also known as Enteromius brevipinnis, is a small cyprinid fish native to southern Africa. It thrives in well-vegetated headwater streams in the Sabie-Komati and Steelpoort-Limpopo river systems. In an aquarium setting, the shortfin barb would require a tank with ample vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. It is a peaceful species that can be kept in a community tank with other non-aggressive fish of similar size. Providing a well-filtered tank with a steady water flow and regular water changes would help this fish thrive. The shortfin barb typically grows up to 4.5 centimeters in length and is a popular choice in the aquarium trade.

name: Snakeskin barb
description: The snakeskin barb, scientifically known as Desmopuntius rhomboocellatus, is a cyprinid fish native to Borneo. It can grow up to 8.8 centimeters in length and is characterized by rhomboid ocellus markings on its flanks, hence the name "Snakeskin barb." In a fish tank, the snakeskin barb would thrive in a well-planted environment with plenty of swimming space. They are peaceful fish that do well in schools, so it is recommended to keep them in groups of 6 or more. They prefer slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 72-79°F (22-26°C) and a pH level between 6.0 and 7.0. Providing a varied diet consisting of flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods will help keep them healthy and vibrant.

name: Spottedsail barb, dwarf barb
description: The spottedsail barb, also known as the dwarf barb or pygmy barb, is a tropical freshwater fish native to Asia. It grows up to 3.1 inches in length and has a silvery body with three blotches and pale orange fins. This fish thrives in clear or muddy streams, rivers, and standing waters with a silty bottom. In an aquarium, the spottedsail barb would do well in a tropical environment with a temperature range of 72–75 °F. It feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. This species is of commercial importance in the aquarium trade industry. The spottedsail barb is an open water, substrate egg-scatterer that spawns near dawn between plants close to the water's surface. The eggs hatch in two days at 75 °F.

name: Swamp barb
description: The swamp barb, also known as chola barb, is a tropical freshwater fish found in Asia. It grows up to 6 inches long and weighs up to 60 grams. This species thrives in shallow waters of streams, rivers, marshes, and ponds in a tropical climate. In a fish tank, swamp barbs would require a pH of 6.0-6.5, water hardness of 8-15 dGH, and a temperature range of 68–77 °F. They feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. Swamp barbs are open water egg-scatterers and do not guard their eggs. During breeding, males display prominent red bands for around two days, while females display red stripes for about 5 hours. They are commercially important in the aquarium trade and fisheries industry. To thrive, they need a well-maintained tank with suitable water parameters and plenty of space to swim.

name: Ticto barb
description: The ticto barb is a subtropical freshwater fish native to various basins in Asia. In an aquarium, they thrive in a well-planted environment resembling their native still, shallow waters with muddy bottoms. They are active schooling fish that prefer to be kept in groups and are peaceful towards other species when in large groups. Ticto barbs require water with a pH of 6.0-7.0, water hardness up to 10 dGH, and a temperature range of 14–22 °C. Their diet consists of small crustaceans, insects, and plankton. They are egg-layers that spawn among coarse gravel, laying around 150 eggs at a time. It is essential to separate the fish from the eggs after spawning to prevent them from being eaten. The eggs hatch in about a day, and the fry become free-swimming the following day.

name: Tic-tac-toe barb
description: Pethia stoliczkana is a small freshwater tropical fish found in various river basins in Asia. It has a silver-green body with distinct black markings and red dorsal fins in males. This fish, growing up to 5 centimeters in length, is popular in the aquarium trade and is used to create hybrid variants with other barbs. In a fish tank, P. stoliczkana would thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of plants for hiding spots and swimming space. They are peaceful and social fish that do well in small groups, so a tank size of at least 10 gallons would be suitable. It is important to provide them with a varied diet and maintain good water quality to ensure their health and well-being.

name: Tiger barb, sumatra barb
remarks: Keep in shoals of 8 or 10 to prevent aggression[48]
description: The tiger barb, a tropical cyprinid fish, is native to Southeast Asia and is commonly found in Indonesia, Borneo, and other parts of Asia. In a fish tank, tiger barbs thrive best in groups of six or more, as they are active shoaling fish. They are known to be aggressive and fin nippers, especially in smaller numbers. Tiger barbs prefer soft, slightly acidic water with a pH of 6.0-7.5, a water hardness of 5-19 dGH, and a temperature range of 77-82 °F. They require a well-lit tank with ample vegetation, as they are omnivorous and greedy eaters. Tiger barbs are not recommended to be kept with slower, more peaceful fish due to their aggressive nature. They do well with fast-moving fish like danios and platys. When provided with enough space, clown loaches make good tankmates for tiger barbs. Overall, tiger barbs are best suited for an active and well-populated aquarium environment.

name: Spanner barb, t-barb
description: The Spanner Barb, also known as T-barb, is a cyprinid fish native to the Malay Peninsula and Borneo, reaching up to 18 centimeters in length. In the wild, they inhabit clear mountain streams with boulders and rocky beds. Their diet includes insects, worms, crustaceans, and plant material. In aquariums, they thrive in water with a pH up to 7.2 and slightly harder than their natural habitat. They are peaceful when kept in schools of at least five but may not be suitable for communities with small fish due to their size. Spanner barbs scatter their eggs in the substrate and abandon them.

name: Fiveband barb, pentazona barb
description: The six-banded tiger barb is a Southeast Asian fish species found in blackwater streams and peat swamps in regions like the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, and Borneo. In captivity, this fish would thrive in a well-maintained aquarium with plenty of plants for hiding spots and areas to explore. They are known to be active and social fish, so it is recommended to keep them in groups of at least six to reduce aggression. Providing a diet of high-quality flakes, pellets, and occasional live or frozen foods will help them thrive. Additionally, maintaining stable water conditions with a slightly acidic pH and warmer temperatures around 75-80°F (24-27°C) will mimic their natural habitat and promote their well-being.

name: Checker barb
description: The checker barb is a small cyprinid fish native to Sumatra, Indonesia, also found in Colombia. It grows up to 5 centimeters long and has red fins with black tips. This species thrives in tropical climates with water pH of 6.0-6.5, hardness of 10.0 dGH, and temperatures of 68–75 °F. In an aquarium, they are peaceful, schooling fish suitable for community tanks. They prefer warm, soft to medium-hard water and feed on small worms, crustaceans, insects, and plants. Checker barbs are omnivores and can be easily bred in captivity due to their prolific egg-scattering behavior. They occupy the medium to lower levels of the tank and do well on processed foods.

name: Tinfoil barb
description: The tinfoil barb, a tropical freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia, is a large species that can grow up to 14 inches in length and live for 10 to 15 years. In a fish tank, they thrive in a spacious environment with strong water currents, similar to their native streams. They prefer to be kept in schools with their own kind or with fish of similar size. Being herbivorous, they feed on aquatic plants, algae, insects, and occasionally small fish. They are active, peaceful fish that spend most of their time in the mid-level and bottom of the tank. Tinfoil barbs are greedy eaters and will consume almost any food provided to them. Due to their large size, it is important for aquarists to be aware of their growth potential before adding them to their tank.

name: Bala shark
remarks: Grows large, needs lots of swimming room and is a schooling fish so a 125 gallon would be good for 3-4[49]
description: The bala shark, also known as the tricolor shark, is a torpedo-shaped fish with a silver body and black margins on its fins. It grows up to 35 cm and is found in rivers and lakes, feeding on small crustaceans and insects. In an aquarium, bala sharks are peaceful and can coexist with other tropical fish, but they require a large tank (at least 150 cm or 5 ft) due to their size and schooling behavior. They prefer soft to medium water hardness, a pH of 6.0-8.0, and a temperature of 22-28°C. Bala sharks should be kept in groups of two or more and need a covered tank to prevent jumping. They are considered vulnerable in the wild and are mostly bred in captivity for the aquarium trade.

name: Black shark
description: The black sharkminnow, also known as the black shark or black labeo, is a large freshwater fish that can grow up to 90 cm in length and weigh up to 7 kg. This species is native to the Mekong and Chao Phraya river basins, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Java, and Borneo. While sometimes found in the aquarium trade, it is generally not suitable for home tanks due to its territorial and aggressive behavior. In a fish tank, the black sharkminnow would require a large tank with plenty of space to swim and establish territories. It would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, with ample hiding spots and a varied diet to keep it healthy and active.

name: Siamese algae eater, fringe barb
remarks: Many other fish in the order Cypriniformes are also sold under this name. Very likely to jump out of the aquarium especially after reaching adult size. Very useful for getting rid of algae when it is young but prefer fish food upon reaching adulthood.[50]
description: The Siamese algae-eater is a bottom-dwelling freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia, commonly found in streams and rivers. In an aquarium, they thrive in a community tank with a water temperature of 24–26 °C, pH of 6.5–8.0, and water hardness of 5–20 dH. They are effective at controlling tank algae, particularly red algae, and prefer heavily planted tanks with strong lighting. Siamese algae-eaters are active swimmers that may school together but can also live solo. They can grow up to 15 centimeters and live over 10 years. It's important to provide them with driftwood, rocks, and plants for resting and hiding spots. They may display territorial behavior as they mature, so it's recommended to monitor their interactions if kept in pairs.

name: Flying fox (fish)
description: The flying fox (Epalzeorhynchos kalopterus) is a freshwater fish commonly found in Southeast Asia and popular in the aquarium trade. It is known for its algae-eating habits and distinctive appearance, with a long body, olive to dark brown dorsal area, and yellowish-white lower half. In a tank, flying foxes thrive in a 40-gallon or larger setup with fine gravel or sand substrate, broad-leaved plants, rocks, and driftwood for hiding. They prefer a pH of 6 to 7.5, water hardness of 2 to 12 dH, and temperatures between 23 to 27°C. Flying foxes are compatible with various fish species but may exhibit territorial behavior in groups. They live around 8 to 10 years and feed on algae, flakes, vegetables, and live foods. Sexing them is challenging, and they do not breed in captivity.

name: Red-tailed black shark
description: The red-tailed black shark, a freshwater fish native to Thailand, is critically endangered in the wild but common in aquariums. It is prized for its striking black body and vibrant red or orange tail. In a fish tank, this species would require a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots like caves or plants to mimic its natural habitat. Red-tailed black sharks are known to be territorial, so providing enough space and suitable tank mates is crucial to prevent aggression. They prefer clean, well-oxygenated water with stable water parameters. Due to their endangered status, captive-bred specimens are the only ones available in the aquarium trade, and efforts are being made to conserve and protect this species.

name: Rainbow shark
description: The rainbow shark, also known as the ruby shark, is a popular semi-aggressive aquarium fish native to Southeast Asia. It thrives in a tank with a minimum of 55 gallons of water, a neutral pH range, temperatures between 24-27°C, and water hardness maintained at 5-11 dH. Rainbow sharks are bottom and mid-level dwellers that feed on algae and plankton. They are picky eaters but primarily consume algae in the form of flakes and also eat live foods like insect larvae and aquatic insects. Rainbow sharks can be housed with barbs, rainbowfish, danios, loaches, plecos, rasboras, and gouramis but should be kept away from smaller, more timid fish as they may become aggressive and territorial. Providing hiding places and decor like plants or caves can help minimize aggressive behavior. Breeding rainbow sharks in an aquarium setting is challenging due to their aggressive nature towards their own kind and other fish.

name: algae eater
remarks: This species may be sold under a variety of common names, including Siamese algae eater, Chinese algae eater, golden algae eater, or sucking loach. A gold colored form also exists.
description: Gyrinocheilus aymonieri, also known as the Chinese algae eater or honey sucker, is a freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia. In the wild, it is found in large rivers and occasionally flooded fields, where it attaches itself to rocks using its unique mouth structure. In an aquarium setting, G. aymonieri is often purchased as an algae eater but may require a varied diet as it ages, including meat. It is important to provide a suitable environment with smooth surfaces for attachment and plenty of algae or alternative food sources to prevent them from feeding on other fish's body slime. Breeding in home aquariums is challenging, and sexing can be difficult. This species does not typically thrive in captivity if not provided with proper care and diet variety.

name: Chili rasbora
remarks: Should be kept in acidic water which can be difficult to maintain for most beginners in the aquarium hobby.[51]
description: Boraras brigittae, also known as chili rasboras, are small fish native to the swamps of South West Borneo, Indonesia. They thrive in blackwater streams and peat swamp forests of Southeast Asia. In a fish tank, these fish would require a setup resembling their natural habitat, with dim lighting, soft acidic water, and plenty of plants for cover. They are peaceful and should be kept in schools of at least six individuals. Feeding them a varied diet including pellets, frozen food, flakes, brine shrimp, and worms will help them thrive. With proper care, they can live up to 8 years.

name: Espei rasbora
description: The espei rasbora, also known as the lambchop rasbora, is a ray-finned fish found in Thailand, Cambodia, and Vietnam. It is named for the dark band resembling a lamb chop along its body. In a fish tank, espei rasboras are peaceful and social, thriving in a well-planted aquarium with dim lighting. They prefer soft, slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 75-82°F (24-28°C). Providing hiding spots and a school of at least six rasboras will help them feel secure and exhibit their natural schooling behavior.

name: Harlequin rasbora
remarks: Also known as Harlequin tetra or Harlequin barb.
description: The harlequin rasbora is a popular and widely kept fish known for its striking appearance with an orange-pink body and a distinctive black triangular patch. In an aquarium, they thrive in a shoal of at least six individuals and prefer a well-planted tank with open swimming spaces. They are peaceful and can coexist with other small, peaceful fish species. The water should have a pH of 6.0 to 7.8, hardness from zero to 15°dH, and a temperature range of 22°C to 27°C. Breeding requires soft, acidic water and the presence of plants like Cryptocoryne. The fish deposit adhesive eggs on plant leaves, and the fry need very fine food initially. With proper care, they can live for five to eight years. Overall, the harlequin rasbora is adaptable in aquarium settings but requires specific conditions for breeding success.

name: Glowlight rasbora
description: The glowlight rasbora, scientifically known as Trigonostigma hengeli, is a small cyprinid fish that is popular among aquarium enthusiasts. This species is known for its vibrant orange and iridescent silver coloration, making it a visually striking addition to a fish tank. Glowlight rasboras are peaceful and social fish that thrive in schools, so it is recommended to keep them in groups of at least six individuals. They prefer a well-planted aquarium with subdued lighting to mimic their natural habitat in slow-moving forest streams. Providing them with plenty of hiding spots and a gentle water flow will help them feel secure and exhibit their natural behaviors. Overall, the glowlight rasbora is a hardy species that can adapt well to a well-maintained tank with suitable tank mates and water conditions.

name: Red-striped rasbora
remarks: Range: Sumatra
description: The redstripe rasbora, a small cyprinid fish native to Southeast Asia, thrives in freshwater environments. In a fish tank, they would do well in a peaceful community setting with plenty of plants for hiding spots. They are schooling fish and should be kept in groups of at least six to display their natural behavior. A well-maintained tank with stable water parameters and a varied diet will help these fish thrive.

name: Dwarf rasbora
description: The Dwarf Rasbora, also known as Boraras maculatus, is a small fish species native to freshwater habitats in Southeast Asia. It typically grows to a size of 10-20mm (0.4-0.8 inches) in adulthood, with a maximum length of around 25mm (1 inch). In a fish tank, Dwarf Rasboras are peaceful and social fish that thrive in a well-planted aquarium with subdued lighting. They prefer a heavily planted environment with plenty of hiding spots and gentle water flow. These fish are best kept in groups of at least 6 individuals to promote their natural schooling behavior. Providing them with a diet of small live or frozen foods will help them thrive and showcase their vibrant colors. Overall, the Dwarf Rasbora is a beautiful and active fish species that can bring life to a community tank with similarly sized peaceful tank mates.

name: Eyespot rasbora
description: The eyespot rasbora is a small, elongate fish native to Malaysia and Sumatra, popular in aquariums for its metallic silver color and distinctive eye-like marking on its dorsal fin. This species thrives in acidic, mineral-deficient water with a pH of 6.0 to 6.5 and a hardness range of 0 to 12°dH, similar to blackwater rivers. In an aquarium, they should be kept in groups of at least 6 individuals in well-filtered water with a temperature range of 20°C to 25°C. They are peaceful shoaling fish but may nip fins if kept with slow-moving species. Ideal tank mates include active fish like small characins, barbs, danios, and Corydoras catfish. The aquarium should have open swimming areas with planted sections and floating plants for cover. They feed on small worms, crustaceans, and insects in the wild but readily accept aquarium foods. Breeding requires soft, acidic water and fine-leaved aquatic foliage for egg deposition. Successful breeding is contingent on precise water chemistry adjustments. The species is relatively easy to breed once optimal conditions are met, with fry requiring special care and very fine food initially. Overall, the eyespot rasbora is a visually striking and active fish that can thrive in a well-maintained aquarium environment.

name: Brilliant rasbora
description: The brilliant rasbora, scientifically known as Rasbora einthovenii, is a small ray-finned fish native to the Malay Peninsula and Borneo. This species typically reaches a maximum size of 5 cm (2 inches) in adulthood. In a fish tank, brilliant rasboras are known to be peaceful and social fish that thrive in a well-planted aquarium with subdued lighting. They prefer a habitat with plenty of hiding spots and open swimming areas. It is important to keep them in schools of at least six individuals to ensure their well-being and reduce stress. Additionally, maintaining stable water conditions with a slightly acidic to neutral pH level and a temperature range of 73-82°F (23-28°C) is crucial for their overall health and vitality.

name: Clown rasbora
description: The clown rasbora (Rasbora kalochroma) is a vibrant and colorful fish species belonging to the genus Rasbora. In a fish tank, clown rasboras are known to be peaceful and social creatures, thriving in a community setting with their own species or other non-aggressive fish. They prefer a well-planted tank with dim lighting and gentle water flow, mimicking their natural habitat of slow-moving streams and rivers in Southeast Asia. Providing them with ample hiding spots and open swimming areas is essential for their well-being. Clown rasboras are omnivores and should be fed a varied diet of high-quality flake food, live or frozen insects, and vegetation to ensure their optimal health and vibrant colors.

name: Scissortail rasbora
description: Rasbora trilineata, also known as scissortail rasbora, is a ray-finned fish native to Southeast Asia, reaching up to 15 cm (6") in length. This species is an omnivore that readily adapts to typical aquarium diets. In a fish tank, Rasbora trilineata would thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of swimming space and hiding spots. They prefer a densely planted tank with subdued lighting and slightly acidic water conditions. These fish are peaceful and do well in community tanks with other non-aggressive species of similar size.

name: Volcano rasbora
description: Rasbora vulcanus is a species of ray-finned fish native to Sumatra. In a fish tank, Rasbora vulcanus would thrive in a well-planted aquarium with plenty of open swimming space. They are peaceful and social fish that do best in schools of 6 or more. They prefer slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 75-82°F (24-28°C). Providing a balanced diet of flake foods, live or frozen insects, and occasional vegetables will help them thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Blackline rasbora, red-tailed rasbora
description: The blackline rasbora, also known as Rasbora borapetensis, is a streamlined silver fish with a dark brown or black mid-lateral stripe and a bright red caudal fin. It grows to about 2.5 inches in length and is found in Asia in various basins and the Malay Peninsula. In an aquarium, this fish thrives in slow-moving water and a heavily planted tank. It prefers a pH range of 6.5 to 7.0, water hardness of 5 to 12 dH, and temperatures between 22 and 26°C. The blackline rasbora is a peaceful schooling fish that swims from the midwater level to the surface, often observed in a tight school racing back and forth in the middle and upper levels of the tank. It can coexist with other peaceful species like loaches, tetras, livebearers, plecos, and rainbowfish.

Sundadanio axelrodi is a small fish species originating from Borneo, Bangka, and Sumatra. It was initially classified as a rasbora but later found to be more closely related to danios. This fish, reaching a maximum size of 1.7 cm, was named after Herbert R. Axelrod, who discovered it in a Singapore aquarium. In a fish tank, Sundadanio axelrodi would thrive in a well-planted environment with plenty of hiding spots and gentle water flow. They are peaceful and social fish that should be kept in groups to prevent stress. Providing them with a varied diet and maintaining stable water conditions would help them thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Pearl danio
remarks: subspecies:blue-redstripe danio, Kedah danio
description: The pearl danio, also known as Danio albolineatus, is a tropical fish originating from Sumatra, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam. It grows up to 2.6 inches and lives for about five years. This fish has a brownish-yellow, pink, or silver body with iridescent qualities and two light yellow/white or blue/red stripes. In the wild, they are found in small, clear rivers and hill streams. In an aquarium, they thrive in a tropical environment with a pH of 6.0-8.0, water hardness of 5-19 dGH, and a temperature range of 68-77°F. They feed on exogenous insects and zooplankton. The pearl danio is an egglayer and prefers a tank with plenty of swimming space and vegetation for hiding.

name: Celestial Pearl danio
description: The Celestial Pearl Danio, also known as Galaxy Rasbora, is a small, colorful fish species native to Myanmar and Northern Thailand. In a fish tank, they thrive in well-planted environments with abundant water weed, stones, and wood for hiding spots. They prefer direct daylight and shallow, well-lit tanks. A group of six individuals, half males and half females, will exhibit natural behavior. They are not very active swimmers and do not require large shoals. Celestial Pearl Danios are peaceful but may nip fins, so they should not be kept with larger or aggressive fish. Tankmates should be small, swarming species with similar water requirements. Maintaining slightly alkaline water conditions similar to their natural habitat is crucial for their well-being. Overall, they are undemanding fish if their basic needs are met and can be successfully bred in captivity.

name: Bengal danio, Sind danio
description: The Bengal danio, also known as the Sind danio, is a subtropical fish native to South Asia. It is a popular choice for community tanks due to its small size, reaching up to 4 inches in length. In a fish tank, Bengal danios thrive in a subtropical environment with a pH of 6.0–8.0, water hardness of 5.0–19.0 dGH, and a temperature range of 59–79 °F (15–26 °C). They are active swimmers and prefer a well-planted tank with open swimming areas. Their diet includes annelid worms, small crustaceans, and insects. Being oviparous, they reproduce by laying eggs. Overall, Bengal danios are peaceful fish that do well in a community tank setting with similar-sized, non-aggressive tank mates.

name: Giant danio
description: The giant danio is a tropical fish native to Sri Lanka, Nepal, and the west coast of India, known for its torpedo-shaped body with blue and yellow colors. In a fish tank, they thrive in clear water with a pH of 6-8, water hardness of 5.0-19.0 dGH, and a temperature of 72-81°F. They prefer a substrate of small gravel and appreciate water movement to mimic their natural river habitat. Giant danios are somewhat aggressive and tend to bully other fish, so they are best kept in a species-specific tank or with larger, more aggressive fish like cichlids. They are social fish and prefer to school, making them ideal dither fish in cichlid aquariums. Breeding can be induced in captivity by increasing water temperature and creating artificial rain. Juveniles resemble adults after 65 days, with females being larger and having a more rounded abdomen. Overall, giant danios are a popular choice in the aquarium trade due to their striking appearance and active behavior.

name: Malabar danio
description: The Malabar danio is a tropical fish that grows up to 6 inches but usually stays around 4 inches in home aquariums. It is a schooling fish that thrives in groups and prefers flowing waters. This active species feeds on insects and plant matter. In an aquarium, they should be kept in a group and provided with ample swimming space and plants for hiding and spawning. They are oviparous and lay around 200 eggs that hatch in one to two days. The fry become free-swimming after five days. To prevent the parents from eating the eggs, they should be removed from the tank.

name: Queen danio
description: The queen danio, also known as Fowler's danio, is a small freshwater tropical fish native to Southeast Asia. It is a peaceful species that can be kept in community tanks. To thrive in a fish tank, the queen danio requires a well-oxygenated environment with sandy substrate and plenty of swimming space. It prefers water temperatures between 73-77°F (23-25°C) and a diet of annelid worms, small crustaceans, and insects. This fish species is best suited for aquariums with fast-moving water conditions resembling its natural habitat in rivers.

name: Spotted danio
description: The spotted danio, also known as the dwarf danio, is a small tropical fish originating from northern Myanmar. It grows up to 1.5 to 1.6 inches in length and is often found in community tanks. This fish thrives in a tropical climate and prefers water with a pH of 6.5-7.0, hardness of 5.0-12.0 dGH, and a temperature range of 75-82°F. Being an egg-layer, the spotted danio requires a well-maintained tank with plenty of plants for hiding spots and open swimming areas. It is a peaceful and active fish that does well in a school of its own kind or with other peaceful species in a well-filtered aquarium.

name: Turquoise danio
description: The blue danio, also known as Kerr's danio, is a tropical fish with a blue coloration and pinkish/gold lines. It is a peaceful and active schooling fish that thrives in a well-planted aquarium with ample space to school. Blue danios prefer water with a pH of 6.5-7.0, hardness of 8-12 dGH, and a temperature range of 73-77°F. They are egg-scatterers that spawn over coarse gravel beds and typically spawn at dawn. To thrive, they need a group environment and suitable water conditions as mentioned above.

name: Zebra danio
remarks: there are many variations of this fish: leopard danio, the spotted colour morph, and GloFish, the genetically modified fluorescent fish.
description: The zebrafish (Danio rerio) is a popular freshwater aquarium fish known for its playful disposition and rapid breeding. In a fish tank, zebrafish thrive in schools of six or more, interacting well with other fish species. They prefer a moderately flowing to stagnant clear water environment with some vegetation and sandy, muddy, or silty substrate. Zebrafish are omnivorous, primarily feeding on zooplankton, phytoplankton, insects, and insect larvae. They can also eat worms and small crustaceans. Zebrafish are hardy and suitable for beginner aquarists but are susceptible to diseases like Oodinium and Mycobacterium species. They typically live around two to three years in captivity but can live longer in ideal conditions. Zebrafish are known for their unique striped pattern and can grow up to 4-5 cm in length. They are commonly used in scientific research due to their genetic similarity to humans and their ability to regenerate tissues like heart and retinal cells. Additionally, zebrafish are used in studies related to drug discovery, cancer research, bone metabolism, and environmental toxicology.

name: Goldfish
remarks: variations: Black Moor, Bubble Eye, Butterfly Tail, Calico, Celestial Eye, Comet, Common, Fantail, Lionchu, Lionhead, Oranda, Panda Moor, Pearlscale, Pompom, Ranchu, Ryukin, Shubunkin, Telescope eye, Veiltail.
description: The goldfish is a popular freshwater fish known for its colorful varieties and schooling behavior. In an aquarium, goldfish thrive in a spacious tank with ample oxygen and filtration due to their high waste production. They are coldwater fish and prefer temperatures between 68-72°F. Goldfish are social and can be trained to recognize their owners, displaying learned behaviors like begging for food. They are generally friendly towards each other but may compete for food, so it's best to keep similar body types together. Goldfish have a memory span of at least three months and can be trained to perform tricks. In the wild, they feed on crustaceans, insects, and plant matter. Goldfish should not be kept in fishbowls due to their high oxygen needs and waste production. They can live over 10 years with proper care. Goldfish are hardy pond fish and can survive in various climates, even in partially frozen ponds. Overfeeding can be harmful, so a balanced diet is essential. Goldfish are not suitable for swallowing or as carnival prizes due to animal welfare concerns. In various cultures, goldfish symbolize luck and fortune, making them a cherished part of celebrations.

name: Koi, common carp
description: The common carp, also known as the Eurasian carp, is a widespread freshwater fish found in lakes and large rivers in Europe and Asia. It is considered an invasive species in many regions due to its ability to out-compete native fish. In a fish tank, common carp prefer large bodies of slow or standing water with soft, vegetative sediments. They are tolerant of various conditions but thrive in groups of five or more. Common carp are omnivorous, feeding on aquatic plants, insects, crustaceans, and fish eggs. They prefer temperatures between 23 to 30°C and can survive in frozen-over ponds. Common carp can grow to large sizes and have a robust build with a dark gold sheen. They are popular in aquaculture and are farmed for food in many areas. In terms of behavior, they feed intensively at night and around sunrise, with females capable of laying up to 300,000 eggs in a single spawn. In the wild, they are preyed upon by various birds and mammals. In a fish tank, common carp may require careful monitoring to prevent overpopulation and potential habitat destruction.

name: Bitterling
description: The European bitterling is a freshwater fish found in Europe, growing up to 10 cm in size. It thrives in shallow waters with plants over sandy or muddy bottoms. In a fish tank, it would require a similar environment with plants and a mix of plant-based and protein-rich diet. They are known to feed on plants, worms, crustaceans, and insect larvae. When breeding, they deposit eggs inside freshwater mussels, where the male fertilizes them. The young hatch and are protected within the mussel before becoming actively swimming larvae. To thrive in a fish tank, the European bitterling would need a well-planted tank with sandy or muddy substrate, slow-running or still water, and freshwater mussels for breeding.

name: White Cloud Mountain minnow
description: The White Cloud Mountain minnow is a hardy freshwater fish native to China, now practically extinct in the wild due to pollution. It is a small fish, growing up to 4 cm in length, with silver-green coloration and bright red fins. This species is an opportunistic omnivore, feeding on aquatic plants, insect larvae, and even fruits and nuts. In an aquarium, they are forgiving in terms of water quality and temperature, thriving in unheated tanks with temperatures ranging from 5-22°C. They are peaceful shoaling fish, best kept in groups of at least five to prevent timidity and maintain their bright colors. White Cloud Mountain minnows are ideal for beginners and can coexist with other peaceful fish species. They are top to middle-level swimmers and prefer a well-covered tank to prevent jumping. Breeding is relatively easy, with males attracting females through fin displays, and eggs hatching within 48-60 hours. The fry can be fed powdered fish food or infusoria. Overall, this species is a great choice for a coldwater aquarium environment with a temperature range of 5-22°C, water hardness (dH) of 5-19, and pH levels between 6.0-8.0.

name: Red shiner
description: The red shiner, a North American freshwater fish, is deep-bodied, reaching about 3 inches in length. They are omnivorous, feeding on invertebrates and algae. In a fish tank, red shiners would thrive in a spacious environment with sand and silt substrates, as well as rocks or vegetation for spawning. They prefer areas with low acidity and tolerate high turbidity. Red shiners are adaptable to various environmental conditions, including degraded habitats, making them suitable for tanks with diverse water qualities. However, caution should be taken as they have been known to eat the eggs of other fish species. Overall, they are hardy and can live up to three years, making them a common choice for aquariums.

name: Common dace
description: The common dace is a freshwater and brackish water fish native to Europe but found in other parts of the world. It has a distinct appearance with a yellowish iris, silvery scales, and a forked caudal fin. In a fish tank, common dace would thrive in a spacious environment with a strong water flow, as they are surface-dwelling fish that prefer fast-flowing water. They are social and often gather in shoals, so it's recommended to keep them in groups. Providing ample hiding spots among cavities and roots would mimic their natural habitat. Common dace primarily feed on small invertebrates, so a varied diet rich in protein is essential for their health. Overall, a well-maintained tank with suitable water conditions and appropriate tank mates would ensure the well-being of common dace in captivity.

name: Rosy red minnow, fathead minnow
description: The fathead minnow, a freshwater fish native to North America, is known for its tolerance to various environmental conditions, making it suitable for tanks with turbid, low-oxygen water. This species is an omnivore, feeding on insects, crustaceans, algae, and zooplankton. In an aquarium, fathead minnows are social, active, and moderately hardy, thriving in schools of at least 5 or 6 individuals. They are not aggressive towards other fish but can be territorial. These fish prefer a temperature range of 10–21 °C (50–70 °F) and a pH of 7.0 – 7.5. The fathead minnow is one of the few cyprinids that protect their eggs in a nest, with males caring for the eggs until they hatch. Overall, they make a fascinating addition to a community tank, especially for those interested in observing unique breeding behaviors.

name: Rainbow shiner
description:
The rainbow shiner, also known as Notropis chrosomus, is a North American fish species that typically grows to a length of 5 to 8 centimeters. It has a translucent body ranging from pink to golden with a silver-black stripe along its flanks and reddish fins. During mating, adult males display vibrant colors on their fins, head, and nose. In the wild, rainbow shiners are found in small, clear rivers with gravelly bottoms in the Mobile River system, particularly in Alabama, Coosa, and Black Warrior rivers, as well as in Tennessee.

In an aquarium setting, rainbow shiners would thrive in a setup that mimics their natural habitat, such as a tank with gravel substrate, plants, and rocks to create riffles and pools. They prefer low-turbidity water with temperatures between 16-25°C (61-77°F). Rainbow shiners are insectivorous and not very selective feeders, so a varied diet of small live or frozen foods like insects and larvae would be suitable for them.

These fish are relatively small and sensitive to disturbances, so a peaceful community tank with other small, non-aggressive fish would be ideal. Providing ample hiding spots and maintaining good water quality are essential for their well-being. Overall, creating a stable and natural environment in the aquarium will help rainbow shiners thrive and exhibit their vibrant colors and natural behaviors.

name: European minnow
description: The Eurasian minnow, also known as the common minnow, is a small freshwater fish found throughout Eurasia in cool streams, well-oxygenated lakes, and ponds. It is a gregarious species that shoals in large numbers. In a fish tank, Eurasian minnows require cold, well-oxygenated water with a gravel bottom, good plant life, and clean water. They thrive in environments with a reasonable current and benefit from the presence of air bubblers for oxygenation. Breeding occurs in late May, with males displaying vibrant colors and chasing females. The fertilized eggs sink to the bottom and are guarded by the male. It is crucial to provide plant cover for the fry to hide in, as adult fish may try to eat them. The fry initially feed on infusoria and algae, then transition to small organisms like daphnia or cyclops as they grow. Overall, Eurasian minnows are hardy fish that can thrive in a well-maintained aquarium with suitable conditions for breeding and growth.

name: Southern redbelly dace
description: The southern redbelly dace is a small freshwater fish found in North America, particularly in flowing pools of creeks and streams. It has a distinctive red belly in males during the breeding season and feeds on algae, diatoms, and invertebrates. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a well-maintained environment with clear, flowing water and a varied diet. They prefer habitats with clear, unpolluted water for optimal health and use their vision to find food. Providing a habitat that mimics their natural environment with ample swimming space and suitable hiding spots would be ideal for these fish to thrive in a tank setting.

name: Tench
description: The tench, also known as the doctor fish, is a freshwater and brackish water species found across Eurasia. It thrives in slow-moving freshwater habitats like lakes and lowland rivers with a clay or muddy substrate and abundant vegetation. The tench tolerates low oxygen levels and feeds at night on the bottom of waters, preferring animals like chironomids, snails, and pea clams. Breeding occurs in shallow waters among aquatic plants during the summer, with females capable of reaching weights of around 7 kg. In a fish tank, tench would require a spacious environment with a muddy substrate, ample vegetation, and low oxygen levels. They are bottom feeders and would benefit from a diet of maggots, sweetcorn, pellets, bread, and worms. Tench are also popular ornamental fish for ponds due to their ability to help keep waterways clean.

name: Golden orfe
description: The ide, also known as orfe, is a freshwater fish found in rivers, ponds, and lakes across Northern Europe and Asia. It is popular as an ornamental fish and can grow up to 50 cm in length. In a fish tank, the ide would thrive in clear, warmer water with good oxygenation. They are sociable in smaller sizes but form smaller groups as adults. They prefer to feed on insects, snails, and other small fish. Due to their size, they are not suitable for indoor tanks and are best kept in outdoor ponds with other fish species like koi or goldfish. The ide is a migratory species that spawns in shallow waters in the spring, making them active and lively during this period.

name: Chinese high fin banded shark
description: The Chinese high-fin banded shark is a popular freshwater aquarium fish that can grow up to 1.35 m (4 ft 5 in) long. However, it is unsuitable for most home aquariums due to its large size. This species is native to the Yangtze River basin in China and is facing endangerment due to various factors. In a fish tank, the Chinese high-fin banded shark would require a spacious environment with fast-flowing water and ample swimming space. They prefer shallow headwaters for spawning but spend most of their time in main river sections. It is important to provide them with a suitable diet and water conditions to ensure their well-being.

name: Saddle-back Loach
remarks: The Saddleback Loach will thrive in an aquarium with a good amount of water flow and aeration, considerable amounts of hiding places formed by rocks or driftwood and smooth pebbles and stones to graze on.[52]
description: Homaloptera orthogoniata, also known as the Homaloptera, is a ray-finned fish species native to Thailand, Laos, and Indonesia. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a well-maintained environment that mimics its natural habitat. They prefer a tank with plenty of hiding spots like rocks, caves, and plants to mimic their natural riverbed habitat. The water should be well-oxygenated and clean, with a moderate to strong water flow. Homaloptera orthogoniata is a peaceful and social fish that does well in small groups, so it is recommended to keep them in a small school. Providing a varied diet of sinking pellets, algae wafers, and live or frozen foods will help them thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Fork-tailed loach
description: Vaillantella maassi, also known as the forktail loach, is a species of loach native to Southeast Asia. It is distinguished by its long dorsal fin and deeply forked caudal fin. In the wild, it is found in forest streams with soft substrates and acidic, tannin-stained water. This species prefers shaded areas with piles of leaf litter to hide among. Vaillantella maassi is a predatory fish that feeds on insects, small crustaceans, and small invertebrates. It is known to be territorial, with territories centered around hiding places. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as soft substrates, ample hiding spots, and slightly acidic water conditions. It would do well in a tank with minimal water flow and a diet of small live or frozen foods.

name: Horseface loach
description: The Acantopsis dialuzona, also known as the horseface loach, is a species native to Southeast Asia, particularly found in swift, clear streams, rivers, and flooded fields. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in an environment with sand or gravel substrate where it can burrow itself. Live plants should be potted to prevent uprooting, and floating plants are recommended for subdued lighting. The horseface loach is not picky when it comes to food but enjoys live food like tubifex. It is most active at night, reaches up to 30 centimeters in length, and prefers to keep to itself. This species has not been successfully bred in captivity and was first imported into Europe in 1929.

name: Weather Loach[53]
remarks: Sensitive to changes in barometric pressure[55]
description: The Betta fish, also known as Siamese Fighting Fish, is a vibrant and colorful species that is popular in home aquariums. Betta fish are known for their long, flowing fins and aggressive behavior towards other male Bettas. In a fish tank, Betta fish should ideally be kept alone or with peaceful tank mates like snails or shrimp to avoid conflict. They require warm water temperatures between 75-80°F, a well-filtered tank, and plenty of hiding spots like plants or caves to explore and feel secure. Betta fish are labyrinth breathers, meaning they breathe air from the water's surface, so the tank should have access to open air. Providing a varied diet of high-quality Betta pellets, frozen or live foods will help keep them healthy and thriving. Overall, a Betta fish would behave best in a tank with a peaceful environment, proper filtration, and suitable tank mates to ensure their well-being and happiness.

Pangio anguillaris, also known as the eel-like loach, is a slender fish native to freshwater habitats in Indochina, the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, and Borneo. This species grows up to 12 cm in length and is typically brown with faint dark lateral stripes. In a fish tank, Pangio anguillaris would thrive in a setup that mimics its natural environment, with still or slow-moving water, soft substrate like mud or sand for burrowing, and plenty of hiding spots. Due to its slow-moving nature, it would be best kept with peaceful tank mates in a well-maintained aquarium with stable water parameters.

name: Kuhli loach, coolie loach
remarks: The natural habitat of the kuhli loach is the sandy beds of slow-moving rivers and clean mountain streams. They are a social fish and are typically found in small clusters (they are not schooling fish but enjoy the company of their species), but are cautious and nocturnal by nature and swim near the bottom where they feed around obstacles. Kuhli loaches are scavengers, so they will eat anything that reaches the bottom.[citation needed]
description: The Kuhli Loach, also known as Pangio kuhlii, is a small eel-like freshwater fish originating from Java, Indonesia. This nocturnal and slender fish prefers a sandy bottom in slow-moving rivers and clean mountain streams. In an aquarium, they thrive in a tropical environment with a pH of 5.5-6.5, water hardness of 5.0 dGH, and a temperature range of 75-86°F (24-30°C). Kuhli Loaches are social but cautious bottom-dwellers that enjoy burrowing into soft places. They are scavengers and feed at night, making hiding spaces and consistent water quality essential for breeding in captivity. These fish can live up to about 14 years and reach a maximum length of 4 inches (10 cm).

name: Java loach
description: The Java loach, also known as Pangio javanicus, is a tropical freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia. It has an eel-like body, small eyes, and a unique coloration ranging from red-brown to near black. In an aquarium, Java loaches thrive in groups of five or more and prefer a meaty diet of Mysis shrimp, brine shrimp, and bloodworms. They are social and will scavenge for food in soft substrate. These fish are known to dart into the substrate when threatened. To thrive, they require a tank with soft substrate, a pH level between 6.2 to 7.0, and a temperature range of 76° to 82°F (24° to 28°C), mimicking their natural streambed habitat. Breeding in captivity may require specific conditions or hormones, but it has been achieved in home aquaria.

name: Clown loach
description: The clown loach, also known as the tiger botia, is a colorful freshwater fish native to Indonesia. It is popular in the aquarium trade due to its vibrant colors and unique behaviors. In a fish tank, clown loaches prefer clear water with a temperature range of 77 to 86°F, a pH between 5.0 and 8.0, and water hardness between 5 and 12 dH. They thrive in environments with good water flow, areas of shade or cover, and subdued lighting. Clown loaches are social and should be kept with non-aggressive tank mates. They may exhibit erratic swimming patterns, but this is usually normal behavior. It's important to provide a soft substrate to prevent damage to their barbels. Clown loaches are susceptible to white spot disease and should be fed a varied diet including live, freeze-dried, and frozen foods. They are long-lived, reaching up to 30 years in captivity, and are best bred when they are between two and four centimeters in size. Conservation efforts are in place due to over-exploitation, with a focus on artificial propagation techniques.

name: Green tiger loach
description: The tiger loach, also known as Syncrossus hymenophysa, is a freshwater fish native to fast mountain streams and large rivers in Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo, and Sumatra. It can grow up to 10 inches long and is distinguishable by the direction of stripes in front of its dorsal fin. This species is aggressive, especially during feeding times. In an aquarium, only one tiger loach should be kept per tank unless there is ample space for a group of five or more. The tank should have neutral to slightly acidic pH levels and temperatures between 77-86°F. To thrive, the tiger loach needs a tank with breaks in sight lines and enough space for each fish to establish a natural hierarchy within the group. It is recommended to feed them live or frozen foods.

name: Banded tiger loach
description: Syncrossus helodes, also known as banded loach or tiger botia, is a freshwater fish native to rivers in Southeast Asia. It is the largest member of the tiger botia group and can grow up to 25-30 cm long. This species is aggressive and should be kept in groups of five or more to spread aggression and establish a natural hierarchy. It is not suitable for community aquariums. Banded loaches prefer water with a pH below 7.0, soft and slightly acidic hardness, and temperatures between 77-86°F. They thrive in environments with 10-12 bars on the body without blue borders and irregular dark markings on the lower body. Breeding has not been observed in captivity, suggesting it may be a seasonal spawner in the wild.

name: Redfin tiger loach
description: Syncrossus berdmorei is a freshwater fish from Thailand, Burma, and northeastern India, belonging to the loach family Botiidae. It grows up to 10 inches and features striking red fins and body coloration. In an aquarium, it is recommended to keep only one specimen unless the tank is large enough for a group. They should be fed live or frozen foods. To reduce aggression, having a larger group and breaks in sight lines across the tank can help disperse aggression, but peaceful interactions are not guaranteed. Syncrossus berdmorei thrives in an environment with soft substrate, boulders, and submerged trees, mimicking its natural habitat in streams and rivers.

name: Dwarf botia
remarks: Formerly named Botia sidthimunki.
description: The Botia sidthimunki, also known as the dwarf loach, is a freshwater fish native to Thailand. It can grow up to 6 cm in length and prefers water temperatures between 25-30°C with a pH of 6.5 to 6.9. This endangered species is omnivorous, feeding on live crustaceans, insects, and snails. In a fish tank, the dwarf loach would thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots like plants, rocks, and driftwood. They are social fish and should be kept in groups of at least 6 to reduce stress. Due to their small size and peaceful nature, they can be housed with other small, non-aggressive fish species. Regular water changes and a varied diet will help keep them healthy and active.

name: Yoyo loach
description: The yoyo loach, also known as Almora loach or Pakistani loach, is a freshwater fish native to the Ganges basin in northern India and possibly Nepal. It can grow up to 14-16 cm in length and is characterized by its dark and pale patterns that resemble the word "yoyo." In aquariums, yoyo loaches are active and social fish that thrive in groups. They prefer a well-planted tank with plenty of hiding spots and smooth substrate. Yoyo loaches are peaceful but can be territorial, so it's best to keep them with similar-sized non-aggressive tank mates. They enjoy scavenging for food at the bottom of the tank and should be fed a varied diet including sinking pellets, frozen foods, and live foods to ensure their optimal health and vibrancy. Maintaining good water quality and providing adequate filtration are essential for the well-being of yoyo loaches in a home aquarium.

name: Bengal loach
remarks: Also known as the Queen loach.
description: Botia dario, also known as Bengal loach or queen loach, is a fish species found in the Brahmaputra and Ganges basins in Bangladesh, Bhutan, and northern India. It is threatened by pesticides in Bangladesh but is overall widespread. In an aquarium setting, Botia dario is a good addition as it helps control pest snail populations and is less shy than some other loach species. They grow up to 6 inches and thrive in groups of 4 or more. They are omnivores and should be fed sinking pellets, algae wafers, fresh vegetables like cucumber and zucchini, and frozen foods like bloodworms and brine shrimp. To thrive in a fish tank, Botia dario requires a tropical environment with ample hiding spots, clean water, and a varied diet to ensure their health and well-being.

name: Polka-Dot Loach
description: The Burmese Border loach, also known as Botia kubotai, is a popular freshwater aquarium fish originating from the Salween River system in Myanmar. This bottom feeder grows up to 15 cm but typically reaches around 10 cm in length. Its coloration changes with age, displaying gold, black, and grey patterns. In an aquarium, it thrives in groups and requires water temperatures of 25-30°C, pH levels of 6.5-6.9, and dGH of 0-8.0. Providing numerous hiding spots is essential for their well-being. It is recommended to treat them for internal parasites upon purchase. Being omnivorous, they enjoy a varied diet including snails, small shrimp, sinking pellets, bloodworms, and black worms.

name: Gangetic loach
description: Botia rostrata, also known as the Gangetic loach or ladder loach, is a freshwater fish found in the lower Ganges and Brahmaputra basins in Bangladesh and north India. It grows up to 11-12 cm in length and thrives in groups of five or more to establish a pecking order. When kept singly, it tends to hide and may not be visible. This fish species displays dominance behavior by darkening its body during fighting or feeding times. To thrive in a fish tank, Botia rostrata requires plenty of hiding spots like rocks and wood to explore and cram into. It prefers calmer water pool areas in highland streams, mimicking its natural habitat for optimal health and behavior in captivity.

name: Zebra loach
description: The zebra loach, a freshwater fish native to India, thrives in a tropical climate with temperatures between 21-26°C and a pH of 6.0-7.5. Peaceful and suitable for community tanks, they may display aggression towards smaller bottom feeders. It's best to keep them in groups of at least five to prevent stress. Providing caves for hiding is essential as they are shy. They accept various foods, including live and commercial sinking fish foods.
