Zebra loaches spend most of their time hiding and may attack smaller fish when stressed. Due to their endangered status in the wild, aquarists should ensure they purchase captive-bred specimens. Breeding in home aquariums is rare, but commercial breeding with hormones is practiced.

name: Redtail loach
description: The blue botia, also known as Yasuhikotakia modesta, is a tropical freshwater fish native to large rivers in Southeast Asia. In an aquarium, blue botias thrive in a setup with a muddy substrate, neutral pH of 7.0, and a temperature range of 26 to 30°C. These fish have a long, compact body with bluish-gray coloration and red, orange, or yellow fins. They are active schooling fish when young but tend to become more solitary as they age, often hiding in caves or under rocks. Blue botias are nocturnal and feed on a diet rich in meat, including krill, bloodworms, and live insects. They may exhibit hierarchical behavior in groups. To ensure their well-being in a tank, provide hiding spots, a varied diet, and maintain suitable water conditions.

name: Skunk loach
remarks: Formerly named Botia morleti
description: The skunk loach, also known as skunk botia or Hora's loach, is a small fish species found in the Mekong River basin in Indochina and other river basins in Thailand. It grows up to about 10 centimeters in size and thrives in medium to large rivers with temperatures ranging from 26-30°C, pH levels between 6.0 to 8.0, and water hardness of 5.0 to 12.0. In a fish tank, skunk loaches would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like caves or plants. They are omnivores, feeding on live crustaceans, insects, snails, and other invertebrates. To thrive, they need a well-maintained tank with clean water and a varied diet to mimic their natural habitat.

name: Borneo hillstream loach
remarks: Eats mainly algae. High oxygen level and water quality are greatly appreciated in addition to a strong current (but not needed as many sources claim)[56]
description: Gastromyzon is a genus of gastromyzontid loaches found in Borneo, with 36 recognized species. These fish are known for their unique appearance and behavior. In a fish tank, Gastromyzon species would thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots like rocks, caves, and plants. They prefer clean, well-oxygenated water with a moderate to strong water flow. Providing a sandy substrate and a diet rich in algae and small invertebrates would help simulate their natural habitat and ensure their well-being. These fish are peaceful but can be territorial, so it's important to provide enough space and hiding places to prevent aggression among tank mates.

name: Tiger hillstream loach
remarks: Eats mainly algae. High oxygen level and water quality are greatly appreciated in addition to a strong current (but not needed as many sources claim)[56]
description: Sewellia lineolata, also known as the reticulated hillstream loach, is a fish species native to fast-flowing, oxygen-rich tributaries in Vietnam. In an aquarium, they require strong currents, abundant oxygen, rocky hiding spots, and smooth surfaces for grazing. Lighting should be bright to promote algal growth. Plants are not essential, but Anubias and Microsoreum are suitable choices. These fish have smaller mouths and feed on benthic algae, micro-organisms, and may consume insect larvae. They exhibit a unique behavior of "gliding" on currents and are more comfortable foraging on sand or fine gravel surfaces. Their diet can include fish flakes, mini pellets, algae wafers, bloodworms, brine shrimp, and daphnia. Maintaining excellent water quality is crucial for their well-being.

name: Butterfly hillstream loach
remarks: Eats mainly algae. High oxygen level and water quality are greatly appreciated in addition to a strong current (but not needed as many sources claim)[56]
description: Beaufortia kweichowensis, also known as the Chinese hillstream loach, is a popular aquarium fish native to China. These loaches thrive in fast-flowing, highland streams and require a tank environment that mimics their natural habitat. They need high oxygen levels, excellent water flow, adequate aeration, and hiding places. Lighting is essential for promoting algal growth. Live plants like Anubias species and Microsorum pteropus can be beneficial. They prefer water temperatures between 68-75°F, pH levels of 7.0-8.0, and medium water hardness. A tank size of at least 36" is recommended for a group of three to seven loaches. They are not aggressive but can be territorial. Feeding them high-quality food like flakes, pellets, algae wafers, and frozen bloodworms is essential. While breeding in captivity is rare, they may reproduce in tank settings resembling riverine conditions.

name: Guppy
remarks: Many color and tail pattern varieties exist. They generally need a ratio of 1 male to 2 females or more. All guppies and mollies are hardy fish that tolerate lower oxygen levels and temperatures than most aquarium fish, give birth to live young, and readily breed in home tanks.[58] can live in full sea water[59]
description: The guppy, also known as Poecilia reticulata, is a popular freshwater aquarium fish species known for its vibrant colors and live-bearing nature. Guppies are highly adaptable and thrive in various environmental conditions. In a fish tank, guppies prefer hard water with a temperature between 25.5 and 27.8°C and can tolerate salinity levels equivalent to one tablespoon per 19 liters of water. They are generally peaceful but may exhibit nipping behavior, especially among males or towards other top-swimming fish. Guppies should be kept in groups as they are social fish and prefer shoaling. They are prolific breeders, and pregnant females can give birth to batches of two to 200 fry. To care for guppy fry, providing hiding spots and a continuous supply of live food is recommended. Guppies are susceptible to various diseases like ich, fin rot, columnaris, velvet, and swim bladder disease, which can be prevented by maintaining a clean tank, balanced diet, and regular monitoring. Overall, guppies are a colorful and lively addition to a community aquarium, best kept in groups to thrive and exhibit their natural behaviors.

name: Endler's livebearer
description: Poecilia wingei, also known as Endlers or Endler's livebearer, is a small and colorful fish species native to Venezuela. In an aquarium setting, they are hardy and undemanding, making them suitable for beginner aquarists. To thrive, they require a well-aquascaped tank with a varied diet, suitable water parameters, and compatible tank mates. They are prolific breeders, giving birth to live young every 23 days. The fry are vulnerable to predators initially but can be fed powdered fry food, baby brine shrimp, and crushed flake food. Males display intense colors and may develop swordtail-like extensions, while females have less vibrant coloring. It's important to maintain proper male to female ratios and avoid hybridization with other guppy species to preserve pure strains. Overall, Endlers are active and colorful fish that can add vibrancy to a community tank.

name: Black molly
remarks: Can live in full sea water[59]
description: The molly, scientifically known as Poecilia sphenops, is a popular fish species in the aquarium trade. They are mildly aggressive and can be slightly larger and more energetic than their livebearer cousins like platies and guppies. Mollies thrive in freshwater streams, coastal brackish, and marine waters from Mexico to Colombia. In a fish tank, mollies require a well-maintained environment with ample space to swim and explore. They prefer slightly brackish water conditions with a pH level between 7.5 and 8.2 and a temperature range of 75-82°F (24-28°C). Mollies are omnivores, so they need a varied diet including high-quality flake food, live or frozen brine shrimp, and algae-based foods. Providing plants and hiding spots in the tank is essential as mollies appreciate places to hide and explore. Overall, with proper care and suitable tank conditions, mollies can thrive and display their vibrant colors and active behavior in a home aquarium.

name: Sailfin molly
remarks: Gold and silver varieties commonly found; also thrive in brackish water/ full sea water[59]
description: The sailfin molly is a livebearer fish found in freshwater and brackish water habitats along the East Coast of the United States and the Gulf of Mexico. In a fish tank, sailfin mollies thrive in brackish water conditions with a mix of oceanic minerals and freshwater sources. They prefer coastal marshes, mangrove swamps, estuaries, and tidal areas. Sailfin mollies are euryhaline, tolerating salinities up to 87 ppt and breeding in brackish waters. They are small, with males displaying enlarged dorsal fins, and females being larger and plainly colored. Sailfin mollies primarily feed on algae and plant materials, occasionally consuming aquatic invertebrates. They reproduce internally, giving birth to live young in broods of 10-140 after a gestation period of 3-4 weeks. Sailfin mollies are of interest to aquarists for their color variations and are valued as feeder fish. In a tank, they should be provided with ample vegetation, hiding spots, and a mix of salt and freshwater to mimic their natural habitat.

name: Dalmatian molly
remarks: The dalmatian molly is a hybrid color variation that can be generated by crossing some species of Poecilia, like P. sphenops and P. latipinna. The variety "Dalmatian" is spotted alike to a Dalmatian dog. Can live in full sea water[59]
description: The Poecilia sphenops, commonly known as the molly fish, is a popular species in the aquarium hobby. Mollies are mildly aggressive and can be slightly larger and more energetic than other livebearer fish like platies and guppies. They thrive in freshwater streams, coastal brackish, and marine waters from Mexico to Colombia. In an aquarium, mollies require a well-maintained tank with plenty of plants for hiding spots and open swimming areas. They prefer slightly brackish water conditions and a varied diet including algae-based foods. Mollies are known for their high reproductive rate, so providing ample space and suitable tank mates is essential for their well-being.

name: Lyretail Molly
remarks: Lyretail Mollies are available in all of these species, can be cross bred with any species of Molly. Can live in full sea water[59]
description: The molly, scientifically known as Poecilia sphenops, is a popular fish species in the aquarium hobby. They are mildly aggressive and can be slightly larger and more energetic than their livebearer cousins like platies and guppies. Mollies thrive in freshwater streams, coastal brackish, and marine waters from Mexico to Colombia. In a fish tank, mollies require a well-maintained environment with plenty of vegetation for hiding spots and swimming space. They prefer slightly alkaline water with a temperature range of 75-82°F (24-28°C). Mollies are known for their high growth rate, reproduction, and brood number, making them a favorite among aquarists. It is important to note that male mollies can exhibit territorial behavior, so providing ample space and suitable tank mates is crucial for their well-being.

name: Southern platy
description: The southern platyfish, also known as the common platy or moonfish, is a small freshwater fish native to North and Central America. It grows up to 6.0 centimeters long and comes in various color varieties. In an aquarium, platies are easy to care for and thrive in community tanks with a pH of 7.0-8.0, water hardness of 9.0-19.0 dGH, and a temperature range of 18-25°C. They are omnivorous and breed readily, with females giving birth to 20-40 young at a time. To thrive, platies need plants and gravel for hiding spots, as well as excellent water quality. They are known for their adaptability and hardiness, making them a popular choice for hobbyists.

name: Variable platy
description: The variable platyfish, also known as Xiphophorus variatus, is a freshwater fish native to Mexico and popular in the aquarium trade due to its prolific breeding. In a fish tank, they thrive in cooler waters between 16-24°C and prefer slow-moving waters with vegetation. They are omnivorous, feeding on plants, small crustaceans, insects, and worms. Males have a more pointed anal fin, while females have a triangular one. They grow up to 7.0 cm in length and have olive coloration with black marbling. This species is known for its colorful patterns and adaptability to various environments, making it a favorite among aquarium enthusiasts.

name: Green swordtail
description: The green swordtail is a freshwater/brackish fish native to North and Central America, known for its elongated lower caudal fin in males. It grows up to 14-16 centimeters in length and comes in various colors due to captive breeding. This species thrives in heavily vegetated rivers and streams with swift-flowing water. It is omnivorous, feeding on plants, small crustaceans, insects, and worms. In a fish tank, green swordtails require a well-planted environment with ample hiding spots for fry. They are prolific breeders, so a ratio of one male to three or four females is recommended to prevent overbreeding. Males can be distinguished by their gonopodium, a modified anal fin used for breeding. Overall, green swordtails are hardy, suitable for community tanks, and popular among aquarists due to their ease of breeding and vibrant colors.

name: Largescale four-eyed fish
description: Anableps anableps, also known as the largescale four-eyes, is a unique fish species found in fresh and brackish waters of northern South America and Trinidad. It has a distinctive feature of split eyes that allow it to see above and below the water simultaneously. In a fish tank, Anableps anableps would thrive in a spacious environment with both water and land areas. They require a mix of floating and submerged vegetation to mimic their natural habitat. It is important to provide a varied diet of insects, small invertebrates, algae, and small fish to meet their feeding habits. Additionally, they prefer brackish water conditions and a well-aerated tank to thrive. This fish species also exhibits interesting behaviors such as feeding on mudbanks and using a combination of biting and suction to capture prey. Overall, Anableps anableps is a fascinating fish that would require specific tank conditions to ensure its well-being and natural behaviors.

name: Pike topminnow
description: The pike topminnow, also known as pike killifish, is a specialized predator found in Mexico to Nicaragua and introduced to Florida, USA. It is the only member of its genus and has a unique ability to consume large prey due to its flexible upper jaw. This fish typically grows up to 9.7 cm but can reach 20 cm in length. It has an elongated body with an upturned lower jaw, large eyes, and a dorsal fin set far back. The pike topminnow is light olive/brown with green iridescence, black spots on the flanks, and a lighter belly with a dark spot at the base of the caudal fin. It is a livebearing fish. In an aquarium, the pike topminnow is not an easy resident, especially compared to other poeciliids, due to its specialized predatory behavior. To thrive, it would require a tank with ample space for swimming, hiding spots, and a diet that includes live prey to mimic its natural feeding habits.

name: Cuban lima
description: The Cuban limia, also known as banded limia, is a livebearing freshwater fish native to Cuba and introduced to Hawaii. It has an olive-green body with black-edged scales, yellow patches on females, and colorful fins on males. Females grow larger than males, reaching up to 10 centimeters. In the wild, it inhabits streams, lakes, estuaries, and mangrove swamps in freshwater, brackish, or saline water. The Cuban limia feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and plants, often forming mixed shoals with other fish species. It is a prolific breeder, with a single female capable of producing up to 50 fry every 4-6 weeks. This species is popular in the aquarium trade, with various color variations bred. In a fish tank, Cuban limias would thrive in a well-maintained environment with ample space for swimming and hiding spots. They prefer water with a neutral pH and moderate hardness, along with a varied diet including live and frozen foods. It is important to provide appropriate tank mates and monitor breeding to prevent overpopulation.

name: Knife livebearer
description: The knife livebearer, Alfaro cultratus, is a tropical freshwater fish native to Central America. It is known for its unique knife-shaped rows of scales and olive-gray body with blueish or green hues on the flanks. In an aquarium, this species thrives in a temperature range of 24-28°C and requires a well-oxygenated environment with moderate water flow. It is essential to maintain water quality by regularly changing about 30% of the aquarium water to prevent bacterial infections. Providing aquatic plants can help reduce the fish's skittishness. Knife livebearers are best kept in a single species tank and should be fed small live foods like daphnia for adults and brine shrimp nauplii for fry. They reproduce ovoviviparously, with females giving birth to 10-30 young after a short gestation period of 24 days. This species is a powerful swimmer and will benefit from a tank setup that mimics its natural habitat of slow to moderately fast-flowing creeks and ditches.

name: Least killifish
description: Heterandria formosa, also known as the least killifish, is a small livebearing fish native to the southeastern United States. It is one of the smallest fish species, with males growing up to 2 centimeters and females up to 3 centimeters. This fish is olive-colored with a dark stripe along its body and is known for its unique breeding strategy of releasing fry over a period of 10-14 days. In an aquarium, Heterandria formosa thrives in vegetated, slow-moving freshwater habitats and can also adapt to brackish waters. They primarily feed on aquatic invertebrates and plant matter. To ensure their well-being in a tank, provide ample vegetation, slow-moving water, and a varied diet to mimic their natural habitat. It's important to note that inbreeding can negatively impact their reproductive behavior and overall health, so care should be taken to avoid this in captivity.

name: Tanganyika killifish
description: The Tanganyika killifish is a species of fish found in Lake Tanganyika, known for forming large schools near rocky shores. In a fish tank, they would thrive in an environment that mimics their natural habitat, with plenty of rocks and hiding spots. They are egglayers that deposit their eggs in narrow crevices, so a tank with suitable breeding spaces would be ideal. They can grow up to 15 centimeters in length and are commonly kept in aquariums. It is important to provide them with a well-maintained tank with appropriate water parameters to ensure their health and well-being.

name: Norman's lampeye
description: Poropanchax normani, also known as Norman's lampeye, is a small fish species native to Central and Western Africa. It is named for the bright markings on its eyes and can grow up to 4 centimeters in length. In a fish tank, Norman's lampeye would thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of plants for hiding spots and swimming space. They prefer soft, slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 72-78°F. This species is peaceful and can be kept in a community tank with other small, non-aggressive fish. Providing a varied diet including live or frozen foods like Artemia, Daphnia, and bloodworms, along with small pellets and crushed flakes, will ensure their health and vitality in captivity.

name: Wrestling halfbeak
remarks: Wrestling Halfbeaks are best kept in groups, composed of either a single male with several females, or, in more spacious quarters with ample visual barriers, larger mixed groups containing at least six males.
description: The wrestling halfbeak, also known as Malayan halfbeak, is a small viviparous fish native to South-East Asia. It thrives in fresh and brackish waters, feeding on small invertebrates like mosquito larvae and flying insects. In a fish tank, wrestling halfbeaks are surface feeders and prefer a stable environment with gradual changes in pH and hardness. They are adaptable to various water conditions, from soft freshwater to slightly brackish water. These fish can be timid initially but become lively once acclimated to their surroundings. It's important to provide them with enough space to swim and hide, as well as a diet rich in small invertebrates to mimic their natural feeding habits.

name: Blue Lyretail
description: The blue lyretail, also known as Gardner's killifish, is a colorful species of killifish native to Nigeria and Cameroon. Males are more vibrant with red spots and yellow-tinted fins, while females are less colorful with brown spots. They grow up to 6.5 centimeters long and prefer freshwater habitats in tributary streams and marshes of the Benue and Cross River basins. Blue lyretails are territorial, with males being larger and more colorful than females. They have a unique breeding strategy that allows their eggs to survive both drying periods and permanent submersion. In an aquarium, blue lyretails are easy to maintain and breed, but males can be aggressive towards slower-moving species. It is recommended to keep them in a species-only tank to prevent sexual frustration and potential mating attempts with other tankmates.

name: Clown Killifish, rocket killifish
remarks:
However, for natural behaviour, a dozen individuals kept in an aquarium of at least 50 litres will be ideal. Compose your group with a ratio of one male to two or three females.
For maintenance with other species, choose small, peaceful fish that like stagnant water (no Cory doras!).[61]
description: The clown killi, also known as the banded panchax, is a freshwater fish native to West Africa. It belongs to the family Nothobranchiidae and is found in countries like Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone. The species was first described in 1915. In a fish tank, clown killifish are known to be peaceful and can thrive in a well-planted aquarium with plenty of hiding spots. They prefer slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 72-75°F (22-24°C). Providing them with a varied diet of live and frozen foods will help them thrive. Clown killifish are known for their vibrant colors and active behavior, making them a popular choice for hobbyists looking to add some life to their aquarium.

name: Bluefin Notho, Rachow's Notho, Rainbow Notho
description: The Bluefin Notho, also known as Nothobranchius rachovii, is a freshwater annual killifish species from Mozambique. It is popular among killifish enthusiasts and can grow up to 6 cm in length. These fish prefer to stay at the bottom of the water, feeding on zooplankton and small organisms. They are found in flat plains or water depressions that dry up annually and lay their eggs in mud to preserve them until the water returns. Bluefin nothos mature in about twelve weeks and live for up to a year or year and a half, dying at the end of the breeding season. In an aquarium, they can be housed in a 40–60 litre tank and are best kept in a community tank with similar-sized peaceful freshwater tropical fish. Males can be aggressive towards other males of the same species. It is important to provide a suitable environment that mimics their natural habitat to ensure their well-being and reproduction.

name: Striped panchax, Golden Wonder
description: The striped panchax, also known as Aplocheilus lineatus, is a species of killifish native to India and Sri Lanka. It thrives in fresh and brackish waters like streams, rivers, swamps, and paddy fields. This fish can grow up to 10 cm in length and has a unique parietal eye that helps it spot prey and predators above the water's surface. In an aquarium, the striped panchax would require a well-maintained environment with plenty of space to swim and hide. It is recommended to provide plants and rocks to mimic its natural habitat. Due to its jumping ability, a secure lid is essential to prevent escape. This fish species is relatively hardy and can adapt to various water conditions, making it suitable for intermediate fish keepers.

name: American Flagfish
remarks: Native to SE United States
description: The flagfish, also known as the American flagfish, is a small and robust fish species native to Florida. In an aquarium setting, flagfish thrive in shallow, well-vegetated freshwater habitats with occasional brackish water. They are known for their unique coloration, with males resembling the flag of the United States. Flagfish are omnivorous micropredators that feed on small invertebrates, zooplankton, and algae. They are used to naturally control hair algae in aquariums. During courtship, females encourage males to chase them before laying a small number of eggs, which the male guards but may sometimes eat. Overall, flagfish are hardy and colorful fish that can make an interesting addition to a well-maintained aquarium with plenty of vegetation and suitable tank mates.

name: Golden Toppminnow
description: The golden topminnow, a small surface-feeding fish native to the southeastern United States, primarily feeds on small organisms near vegetated areas. In a fish tank, it would thrive in a well-vegetated environment with ample space to swim near the surface. It prefers a diet of aquatic invertebrates and can tolerate a range of salinity levels. Breeding in late spring to early summer, the golden topminnow has a short lifespan of around 2 years and reaches maturity quickly. It is not currently endangered and does not have a specific management plan.

name: Northern Studfish
description:
The northern studfish, also known as Fundulus catenatus, is the largest of the killifish species native to the southcentral United States. Adult northern studfish typically measure between 3 to 6 inches in length. Males display bright orange spots on a light blue background with an orange tail margin during breeding season, while females have more cryptic colors in shades of beige and olive. They prefer clear, shallow pools and rocky creeks with a mixed sand/gravel substrate and constant, sluggish flow in their natural habitat. 

In a fish tank, northern studfish would thrive in an environment that replicates their natural habitat, including clear water, rocky structures, and a mix of sand and gravel substrate. They do not build nests but stake out territories and defend them. Females lay a clutch of 28 to 245 eggs without providing parental care. Their diet mainly consists of insects and occasionally snails. To ensure their well-being in a tank, it is essential to maintain water quality by controlling sediment and stabilizing streambanks to mimic their natural habitat.

name: Arabian Killifish
description: The Arabian toothcarp, also known as the Arabian pupfish or mother-of-Pearl fish, is a species of killifish found in various water bodies from the Red Sea to India. This fish species displays extreme sexual dimorphism, with brightly colored males and brownish-silver females. They prefer hard alkaline water and are highly adaptable to a wide range of salinities. In a fish tank, Arabian toothcarp would thrive in a setup with ample hiding spots and vegetation to mimic their natural habitat. They are omnivores, feeding on algae, crustaceans, and insects. However, they are threatened by water pollution, habitat degradation, and competition from invasive species like the mosquitofish. Conservation efforts are needed to protect this species from further decline.

name: Javanese ricefish
description: The Javan ricefish, also known as Oryzias javanicus, is a small fish species found in Peninsular Thailand, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, and various Indonesian islands. It thrives in both brackish and freshwater environments such as ponds, ditches, mangroves, swamps, streams, and canals. This fish can reach a maximum length of 4.5 cm. In a fish tank, the Javan ricefish would require a well-maintained environment with a mix of freshwater and possibly some salt content. They prefer densely planted tanks with hiding spots and open swimming areas. It is essential to provide them with a varied diet and ensure water quality is consistently monitored to keep them healthy and thriving.

name: Ceylonese combtail
description: Belontia signata, also known as the Ceylonese combtail, is a gourami species native to Sri Lanka. It thrives in shallow, slow-flowing clear-water streams and can grow up to 18 centimeters in length. This fish has a unique labyrinth organ that allows it to breathe atmospheric air, making it adaptable to poorly oxygenated waters. In a fish tank, the Ceylonese combtail should be kept alone as it tends to be aggressive towards other fish, potentially causing harm or even death. They have a varied diet, accepting foods like maggots, bloodworms, flakes, pellets, and vegetables. To ensure the well-being of the Ceylonese combtail in captivity, it is essential to provide a tank environment that mimics its natural habitat with ample space and hiding spots.

name: Siamese fighting fish (sometimes Betta, esp. US)
remarks: Betta is the name of the genus that includes more than 60 species other than the Siamese fighting fish.
description: The Siamese fighting fish, also known as Betta splendens, is a popular freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia. They are known for their vibrant colors and long fins, making them a favorite in the aquarium trade. Bettas are highly territorial, especially males, and can be aggressive towards each other if housed together. They have a unique labyrinth organ that allows them to breathe air from the surface, making them tolerant of low oxygen levels. In the wild, bettas thrive in shallow bodies of water with abundant vegetation. To thrive in a fish tank, bettas need a minimum tank size of 5 gallons, with a temperature range of 75-82°F and a neutral pH level. They require hiding spots, live plants, and decorations for enrichment. Bettas can cohabit with certain fish species, preferably non-territorial ones like tetras, but compatibility varies based on individual temperament. Proper nutrition, including a protein-based diet, is crucial for their health. Bettas can live up to 3-5 years in captivity with proper care. They are susceptible to diseases, so maintaining good water quality is essential. Bettas exhibit complex behaviors, including aggression, courtship rituals, and unique sleep patterns. They are also being studied as model organisms for research on aggression and pigmentation genetics.

name: Frail gourami
description: The frail gourami, also known as the noble gourami, is a mouth brooding species native to northeastern India and Bangladesh. It grows up to 10 cm in length and is sensitive to shipping stress, making it rare in the aquarium trade due to its aggression towards other fish. In a fish tank, this species would require a peaceful and spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. They prefer slow-flowing waters with temperatures ranging from 59-90 degrees Fahrenheit. Due to their aggressive nature, it is recommended to keep them in a species-only tank or with very peaceful tank mates. The males of this species exhibit mouth brooding behavior, where they carry and protect the eggs until they hatch into free-swimming fry. Overall, the frail gourami is an intelligent and adaptive species that requires specific care to thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Paradise fish
description: The paradise fish, also known as the paradise gourami, is a colorful and aggressive species of gourami native to East Asia. In a fish tank, paradise fish require a minimum tank size of 20 gallons for a single male or 20-30 gallons for a community tank. The tank should be well planted, covered, and include hiding spots like bogwood and rockwork. Paradise fish are best kept with suitable tankmates such as giant danios, large tetras, and some less aggressive cichlids. They are known to be aggressive towards each other, especially males, so it's recommended to keep males separate or with females. Paradise fish are carnivorous and should be fed a high-protein diet, including mosquito larvae, black worms, brine shrimp, and small flies. They are adaptable to a wide range of water conditions but thrive in shallow waters with dense vegetation. Breeding involves bubble nest building, and the male can become aggressive towards the female and other tankmates during this time. Overall, paradise fish are hardy and colorful additions to a well-maintained aquarium.

name: Ornate paradisefish
description: The ornate paradisefish, also known as the spotted gourami, is a small carnivorous fish native to Sri Lanka. It thrives in shallow, slow-flowing streams with abundant vegetation and leaf litter. In an aquarium, this species is known to be exceedingly shy. To thrive, they would require a tank with plenty of hiding spots, live plants, and a peaceful environment. Providing a diet of plankton, fish fry, and insect larvae would be essential for their well-being. It is crucial to recreate their natural habitat as closely as possible to ensure their comfort and health in a tank setting.

name: Eyespot gourami
description: The eyespot gourami is a small fish species native to Myanmar, typically found in muddy streams and lakes with dense vegetation. It grows up to 5 cm (2 inches) in length. In a fish tank, the eyespot gourami would thrive in a setup that mimics its natural habitat, including plenty of plants for cover and hiding spots. It is recommended to maintain stable water parameters and provide a peaceful environment as this species can be shy and easily stressed. Additionally, a well-maintained tank with a gentle water flow and regular water changes would be ideal for the eyespot gourami to thrive and display its natural behaviors.

name: Brown Spike-tailed paradisefish
description: Pseudosphromenus dayi, also known as the Indian spiketail betta, is a freshwater fish found in Kerala, India. It thrives in still or slow-flowing waters like lakes, ditches, and swamps, including both fresh and brackish environments. This species is a bubble nester, with the male creating a nest of bubbles where the female lays eggs. Both parents care for the eggs and offspring. In a fish tank, Pseudosphromenus dayi would require a well-planted aquarium with gentle water flow and hiding spots. It is essential to provide them with floating plants or leaves for bubble nest building. Maintaining stable water parameters and a peaceful community tank environment is crucial for their well-being.

name: Honey gourami
description: The honey gourami is a small fish species native to India and Bangladesh, typically found in rivers and lakes with thick vegetation and soft, poorly mineralized waters. In an aquarium, they are non-aggressive community fish best kept in small planted tanks with cover for hiding. Male honey gouramis can be territorial, so it's recommended to keep them separate unless the tank is large enough for territories. They prefer water temperatures between 22-28°C and are bubble nest builders. During breeding, the male displays vibrant colors to attract the female, then guards the nest and cares for the eggs and fry. Tankmates should be non-fin nipping species like tetras, barbs, corydoras, platys, or other peaceful gouramis. The environment should mimic their natural habitat with plants and hiding spots to ensure their well-being and comfort.

name: Dwarf gourami
remarks: Suitable for small to mid-sized aquariums but cannot compete with more aggressive fish and males kept together may fight. Several color varieties available. Massive inbreeding has led to high rates of Dwarf gourami iridovirus (DGIV) in pet store fish.[63]
description: The dwarf gourami is a small fish species native to South Asia, specifically Pakistan, India, and Bangladesh. In the wild, they inhabit slow-moving waters with abundant vegetation. In an aquarium setting, dwarf gouramis are peaceful but slightly territorial, best suited for community tanks of at least ten gallons with other docile fish. They prefer swimming in the middle or top regions of the tank and are labyrinth fish, utilizing their labyrinth organ. These fish are timid and should not be housed with large or aggressive tank mates. They thrive in temperatures around 27°C (81°F) and require a varied diet of algae-based and meaty foods. Male dwarf gouramis build bubble nests for breeding, incorporating plant material and debris. The male protects the eggs and fry, and the fry should be fed infusoria initially, then brine shrimp and finely ground flakes as they grow. It is important to provide vegetation in the breeding tank for successful reproduction.

name: Thick-lipped gourami
description: The thick-lipped gourami is a popular freshwater aquarium fish native to Southeast Asia. It is sexually dimorphic, with males displaying red and blue stripes. This species is peaceful and suitable for a tropical community tank with soft, acidic water and temperatures between 22°C to 28°C. They prefer hiding spots among plants and are known to build bubble nests for breeding. It feeds on various foods and should not be housed with aggressive tank mates that may damage its delicate fins. The fish is known to breed well in captivity, with males building bubble nests and exhibiting good parental behavior. Care should be taken with tank filtration to avoid damaging the bubble nest. Crossbreeding with other gourami species has resulted in hybrids with unique color patterns like gold, red, and green.

name: Moonlight gourami
description: The moonlight gourami is a peaceful and popular aquarium fish known for its silvery color with a greenish hue resembling moonlight. This species thrives in a tank with plenty of aquatic vegetation and shallow, sluggish water. They have a special lung-like organ that allows them to breathe air, making them adaptable to low oxygen situations. Moonlight gouramis are oviparous and use bubble nests for reproduction, with the male carefully preparing the nest and engaging in a courtship dance with the female before spawning. They feed on insects, crustaceans, and zooplankton. To keep moonlight gouramis healthy and happy in a fish tank, it is important to provide a well-planted environment with space for them to swim and explore, as well as ensuring good water quality and proper filtration.

name: Snakeskin gourami
description: The snakeskin gourami is a large gourami species native to Southeast Asia, commonly found in rice paddies, shallow ponds, and swamps with abundant aquatic vegetation. In a fish tank, they are peaceful and suitable for community tanks with other peaceful species like barbs, tetras, and angelfish. They are bottom and middle dwellers, requiring a tank of at least 36 inches in length. The ideal water conditions include a pH of 5.8 to 8.5, water hardness of 2 to 30 dH, and a temperature of 72 to 86°F. They are omnivores and will eat a variety of foods including live food, flakes, pellets, and vegetables. Breeding them is relatively easy, and they can produce a large number of fry. The males are nonaggressive, and the parents do not eat their fry. Fry can be raised with progressively larger flake foods and occasional live foods like brine shrimp. During breeding, they exhibit territorial behavior and may vocalize sounds.

name: Pygmy gourami, Sparkling gourami
description: The pygmy gourami, also known as the sparkling gourami, is a freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia. It is a small fish that reaches a length of about 4 centimeters and displays red, green, and blue hues. This species is known for its ability to produce a croaking noise using a specialized pectoral mechanism. In an aquarium, pygmy gouramis thrive in a heavily planted tank with subdued lighting and no strong currents. They require space between the water surface and tank cover to gulp moist air. These fish prefer a temperature of 25°C or above and a pH below 7. While they are not schooling fish, they can be kept peacefully in small groups. Pygmy gouramis are hardy and tolerant of less-than-ideal water conditions but do not compete well with aggressive tank mates. They feed on zooplankton and aquatic insects and readily accept flake, live, or frozen foods. Breeding can be induced by adjusting temperature and water level, with the male guarding the eggs in a bubble nest until they hatch. Clean water and proper feeding are crucial for the health of these fish.

name: Malay combtail
description: The Malay combtail, also known as Belontia hasselti, is a gourami species native to southeast Asia. It can grow up to 20 centimeters in length and is commonly found in peat swamps of the Malay Peninsula and the Greater Sunda Islands. This fish is commercially important and popular in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, the Malay combtail would thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of vegetation and hiding spots. They prefer slightly acidic water conditions and a peaceful community tank with other non-aggressive fish species. Providing a varied diet and regular water changes are essential for their health and well-being.

Betta albimarginata, also known as the white-edged betta, is a small species of betta fish native to Borneo. It thrives in shallow forest streams with vegetation and debris along the shores. This fish grows to about 2.8 cm in length and is known for mouthbrooding. In a fish tank, Betta albimarginata would require a well-planted environment with hiding spots and gentle water flow to mimic its natural habitat. It is essential to maintain stable water parameters and provide a balanced diet to ensure the well-being of this species.

Betta brownorum, a species of betta found in Borneo, Indonesia, and Malaysia, thrives in peat swamps with very shallow waters. Growing up to 2.6 cm (1.0 in) in length, this fish would do well in a fish tank with a similar environment. Providing a tank with ample vegetation, soft acidic water, and hiding spots mimicking its natural habitat is crucial for Betta brownorum to thrive. Due to its small size, it is best kept in a species-only tank or with peaceful tank mates to prevent aggression.

The Betta burdigala, a species of gourami found in peat swamps on Bangka Island in Indonesia, typically grows to a length of 2.5 cm. In a fish tank, Betta burdigala would require a setup that mimics its natural peat swamp environment. This includes soft, acidic water with plenty of hiding spots like plants and driftwood. Due to its small size, it is best kept in a species-only tank or with very small, peaceful tank mates to prevent aggression. Providing a well-maintained environment with proper water parameters and suitable tank mates is crucial for the Betta burdigala to thrive in captivity.

Betta channoides, also known as the Borneo betta, is a small fish species native to the island of Borneo in Indonesia. It thrives in the shallow acidic brown-water forest streams of the Kalimantan Timur province. This fish grows up to 5.0 cm (2.0 in) in length. In a fish tank, Betta channoides would require a setup that mimics its natural habitat, including soft and acidic water conditions. Providing plenty of hiding spots with plants and driftwood is essential for their well-being. Due to their territorial nature, it is recommended to keep them in a species-only tank to prevent aggression towards other fish. A well-maintained environment with suitable water parameters will help Betta channoides thrive and display their natural behaviors.

name: Scarlet betta
description: Betta coccina, also known as the Peninsular Malaysia Betta, is a small fish species native to Peninsular Malaysia and Sumatra, Indonesia. Growing up to 5.6 cm (2.2 in) in length, it is a popular choice in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, Betta coccina would thrive in a well-maintained environment with dense vegetation for hiding spots and territories. They prefer slow-moving or still water conditions with a temperature range of 24-28°C (75-82°F) and slightly acidic water with a pH level around 6.5-7.0. Due to their territorial nature, it is advisable to keep Betta coccina either alone or with peaceful tank mates to prevent aggression. Providing a balanced diet and a suitable habitat will help these fish thrive and display their vibrant colors and natural behaviors.

Betta foerschi, a gourami species native to Borneo, specifically the southern region, thrives in creeks within rainforests. Growing up to 7 cm (2.8 in) in length, this fish is popular in the aquarium trade. In a fish tank, Betta foerschi would require a well-maintained environment mimicking its natural habitat, including ample vegetation and hiding spots. It is essential to provide a tank with a steady flow of clean, oxygenated water and maintain suitable water parameters to ensure the well-being and vibrancy of Betta foerschi.

Betta hendra, a species of gourami native to Asia, particularly found in the Sabangau River basin in Central Kalimantan on the island of Borneo in Indonesia. In its natural habitat, it thrives among plants in peat swamp forests with shallow, still waters and no current. In an aquarium, Betta hendra would require a similar environment with plenty of plants for shelter and a calm water surface. This species is known to build bubble nests and is a facultative air-breather, so providing access to the water's surface is essential for their well-being. Betta hendra typically grows up to 4.2 cm (1.7 inches) in length and would behave well in a peaceful tank setting with minimal water flow.

name: Crescent betta
description: The Betta imbellis, also known as the peaceful betta, is a species of gourami native to Southeast Asia. It has a unique labyrinth organ that allows it to extract oxygen from air, enabling it to thrive in extreme conditions. In a fish tank, Betta imbellis would require a peaceful environment with slow-moving water, leaf litter, and mud substrate to mimic its natural habitat. Males may exhibit aggression towards each other, especially during breeding season. They can be fed live or frozen food like Daphnia, Artemia, or bloodworms. Males are more colorful than females, with blue hues in their brownish bodies. Breeding involves the male building a bubble nest and caring for the eggs and fry. It is important to prevent hybridization with other betta species in captivity. Overall, Betta imbellis is a fascinating fish species suitable for aquariums with proper care and attention to its unique needs.

Betta mandor, a species of gourami native to Borneo, specifically the Kapuas basin in Indonesia, thrives in shallow waters of forested swamps, streams, and pools. It typically feeds on insects and small invertebrates, reaching a length of about 5.7 centimeters. In an aquarium, Betta mandor would require a well-planted tank with ample hiding spots and gentle filtration. They are known to be territorial, so it's best to keep them alone or with peaceful tank mates. Providing a varied diet consisting of live or frozen foods will help mimic their natural feeding habits and ensure their well-being in captivity.

Betta miniopinna is a small gourami species native to Bintan Island in Indonesia. It thrives in acidic blackwater habitats with a pH of 4.9–6, found in densely forested peat swamps and streams. In a fish tank, Betta miniopinna would require a setup mimicking its natural environment, including soft mud substrate, submerged leaf litter, branches, and roots. This fish species is known for its paternal bubble-nesting behavior during mating. Due to its specific habitat requirements and conservation concerns related to habitat degradation, providing a well-maintained tank with appropriate water conditions and hiding spots is crucial for the well-being of Betta miniopinna.

Betta persephone is a small labyrinth fish native to Malaysia, specifically Johor. The males have a blue-black coloration, while the females are more brown-toned. This species thrives in soft, acidic waters with temperatures ranging from 23 to 28°C. In its natural habitat of closed-canopy forests, Betta persephone lives among submerged tree roots in blackwater streams and peat swamps. It feeds on insects and small invertebrates and is a bubble nester, creating bubble nests among submerged vegetation. Due to habitat loss from deforestation for oil palm cultivation, Betta persephone is listed as "Endangered" on the IUCN Red List. While delicate and not easily kept in aquariums, successful breeding in captivity has been achieved. To thrive in a fish tank, Betta persephone would require a well-planted aquarium with soft, acidic water and a temperature range of 23 to 28°C, mimicking its natural habitat as closely as possible.

name: Toba betta
description: The Toba betta, also known as Betta rubra, is a small gourami species native to Sumatra, Indonesia, specifically found in peat swamps. Unlike the popular Betta splendens, the Toba betta is a mouthbrooding fish, meaning it carries its eggs and young in its mouth for protection. In an aquarium setting, Toba bettas would thrive in a well-maintained tank with plenty of hiding spots like plants or caves to mimic their natural habitat. They prefer slightly acidic water conditions and a diet consisting of small live or frozen foods. Due to their small size, they are best kept in a species-only tank to prevent aggression from other fish species.

Betta rutilans, also known as the "reddish Betta," is a small gourami species native to Indonesia. These fish thrive in blackwater streams and peat swamp forests with minimal sunlight. Typically growing up to 3.5 centimeters in length, they are predominantly red in color, with males displaying more intense hues and distinct fin shapes compared to females. Betta rutilans feed on small invertebrates like insects and are known to build bubble nests for their fry, with some exhibiting mouthbrooding behavior. In an aquarium setting, they require a community tank with ample hiding spots and a suitable tank size based on the number and species of fish present. To ensure their well-being, Betta rutilans should be kept in warm, filtered water reminiscent of their natural blackwater habitat.

Betta uberis is a small gourami species native to Asia, specifically found in peat swamp forests in Indonesia. It reaches a size of 3.6 cm (1.4 inches) and is known for being a facultative air-breather. In a fish tank, Betta uberis would thrive in a well-planted environment with access to the water's surface for occasional air-breathing. They prefer slow-moving water and a diet of small insects and invertebrates. It is important to provide hiding spots and gentle filtration to mimic its natural habitat. Overall, Betta uberis would do well in a peaceful tank with suitable tank mates and proper water conditions.

name: Giant pikehead
description: The Luciocephalus pulcher, also known as the pikehead, is a gourami species that is native to the Malaya Peninsula, Sumatra, and Borneo. This fish has a yellowish-brown color with dark brown longitudinal bands and stripes, reaching up to 20 centimeters in length. In an aquarium setting, the pikehead can be challenging to keep as it requires extremely soft and acidic water, and prefers live foods over dead ones. It thrives in habitats like flooded forests, streams, and peat swamps with abundant vegetation. The pikehead is an ambush predator that remains still near plants or cover, waiting for prey to approach. When hunting, it can extend its jaw to about one-third of its body length to catch smaller fish. This species is a paternal mouthbrooder. To ensure the pikehead thrives in a fish tank, it is essential to replicate its natural habitat with soft, acidic water, live food options, and ample vegetation for cover.

name: Peppermint pikehead
description: Luciocephalus aura, also known as the green-spotted pikehead, is a freshwater fish endemic to Sumatra. It is typically found in forested swamps and prefers faster flowing habitats. This species is an ambush predator and paternal mouthbrooder, reaching up to 10.5 cm in length. Luciocephalus aura has a distinctive line of bright green spots along its flanks. In a fish tank, it would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, with plenty of hiding spots and moderate water flow. It is important to provide ample space for swimming and suitable tank mates to avoid aggression. Additionally, maintaining good water quality and offering a varied diet will help this species thrive in a home aquarium.

The licorice gourami, also known as Parosphromenus deissneri, is a freshwater fish native to Bangka in Indonesia. It thrives in slow, flowing streams with black waters found in peat swamp forests. In a fish tank, licorice gouramis require a well-planted environment with dim lighting to mimic their natural habitat. They are peaceful fish that prefer to be kept in small groups and are best suited for a species-only tank due to their shy nature. Providing them with soft, acidic water and a diet of small live or frozen foods will help them thrive. Overall, licorice gouramis are a unique and beautiful species that require specific care to ensure their well-being in a home aquarium.

name: Chocolate gourami
description: The chocolate gourami is a small fish native to Southeast Asia, known for its chocolate color with golden bands. In an aquarium, they thrive best in well-planted tanks with soft, acidic water and a temperature range of 25-27°C. These fish are challenging to keep due to their specific water requirements and are susceptible to infections without optimal conditions. Chocolate gouramis are omnivorous but primarily feed on insects, preferring live or frozen foods over flakes. They are best kept alone due to their sensitive nature and should be provided with a peaceful environment to thrive.

name: Crossband chocolate gourami
description: Sphaerichthys selatanensis, also called the crossband chocolate gourami, is a small gourami species native to the Kalimantan region of Borneo in Indonesia. This fish reaches up to 4 cm in length and is known for its facultative air-breathing behavior and male mouthbrooding. In a fish tank, S. selatanensis would thrive in a well-planted aquarium with soft, acidic water. They prefer dim lighting and peaceful tank mates as they are shy and easily stressed. Providing hiding spots and gentle water flow mimicking their natural habitat is essential for their well-being.

name: Samurai gourami
description: Vaillant's chocolate gourami, also known as Samurai gourami, is a small fish species native to Asia, specifically the Kapuas river in Borneo, Indonesia. It is a mouthbrooder that mimics dead leaves for camouflage in its natural habitat. In a fish tank, they require a 10+ gallon aquarium with soft, acidic water, minimal flow, and a pH of 3.5-6.8. Decorate the tank with wood, botanicals, and a sandy substrate to replicate their natural environment. They are omnivores, feeding on plant matter, algae, daphnia, and worms. It is recommended to keep a group of 6+ fish to establish a pecking order and a peaceful society. They are intelligent, peaceful, and inquisitive fish that need live foods initially but can be weaned onto processed foods gradually. Regular water changes of 10-15% are essential, and peat-filtration is recommended due to their sensitivity to water quality.

name: Pearl gourami
description: The pearl gourami, also known as Trichopodus leerii, is a species of gourami originating from Southeast Asia. It grows up to 12 centimeters in length and has a brownish-silver body with a pearl-like pattern and a distinctive black line running from its head to the caudal fin. Male pearl gouramis are larger and more colorful than females, displaying bright orange coloring, especially around the throat during breeding. They are commonly found in lowland swamps with acidic water in countries like Thailand, Malaysia, and Indonesia. In a fish tank, pearl gouramis require a well-planted environment with plenty of hiding spots and subdued lighting. They are peaceful fish but can be territorial during breeding. Maintaining stable water parameters, such as temperature and pH levels, is crucial for their well-being.

name: Three spot gourami
description: The three spot gourami, also known as opaline gourami, blue gourami, and gold gourami, is a freshwater fish native to southeastern Asia. In an aquarium, they are hardy and can coexist with similar-sized and tempered tank mates. While males can be territorial with each other, they become timid around more aggressive fish. They are omnivores and require a diet of algae-based and meaty foods. The male builds a bubble nest for the eggs and protects them aggressively. It is important to provide them with enough room to swim and hide to reduce aggression. They thrive in a tank with stable water conditions, proper nutrition, and room for swimming. The fish can change color when under stress or in poor conditions, with healthy individuals displaying two vivid black spots on each side of their bodies.

name: Croaking gourami
description: The croaking gourami is a small freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia, known for its ability to produce a "croaking" noise using its pectoral fins. In a fish tank, croaking gouramis are peaceful and shy, making them suitable for community aquariums. They require a tank of at least 40 liters with plenty of hiding spots, plants, and a shaded surface area. These fish can breathe atmospheric oxygen, so proper air ventilation is crucial. Croaking gouramis prefer a darker substrate and a varied diet including flake foods, bloodworms, brine shrimp, and algae-based flakes. They are sensitive to noise and should not be kept with large, aggressive fish or male Bettas. When breeding, males build bubblenests under leaves, and the water level should be reduced during spawning. The fry should be fed infusoria, baby brine shrimp, and finely ground flakes. Overall, croaking gouramis require a well-maintained tank with suitable tankmates, proper diet, and breeding conditions to thrive.

name: Giant gourami
description: The giant gourami is a large freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia, known for its voracious herbivorous appetite and ability to breathe moist air. In an aquarium, they prefer dark bottoms, densely planted edges, and space to swim. They thrive in the company of similar-sized and tempered fish. Giant gouramis are easy to care for and can grow rapidly with sufficient food and space. They prefer algae-based foods but will also eat meaty foods. Breeding involves both male and female building nests, with the male taking a more prominent role. The male guards the eggs aggressively, requiring the female to be removed after spawning. The eggs hatch within 24 hours. Giant gouramis are popular in aquaria and are prized as a food fish in Southeast Asian cuisines due to their thick flesh, pleasant texture, and tasty flavor. They are rich in protein and minerals, making them highly valued in markets and cuisines of Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand.

name: Kissing gourami
description: Kissing gouramis, also known as kissers, are medium-sized tropical freshwater fish originating from Mainland Southeast Asia. In an aquarium, they require a roomy tank with large-diameter gravel and stones for substrate to prevent digging and provide algae growth. These territorial fish can be aggressive towards similar-sized tank mates, especially during sparring matches where they "kiss" by pressing their mouths together. They are omnivores and need a diet of both plant and animal matter, accepting live food and vegetables. Water parameters should be maintained between 5-30 dGH for hardness, pH 6.8-8.5, and a temperature of 22-28°C. Kissing gouramis are long-lived, with an average lifespan of 5-7 years but can live much longer, even exceeding 25 years. They are popular for their unique behavior and are exported worldwide for their kissing interactions.

name: Climbing perch
description: The climbing perch, also known as Anabas testudineus, is a freshwater fish native to Far Eastern Asia. It is euryhaline and can grow up to 25 cm in length. This species is amphibious and can survive out of water for 6-10 hours by crawling on land with its pectoral fins. In a fish tank, the climbing perch would require a partially aquatic environment with access to both water and land areas. It is important to keep the tank moist to mimic its natural habitat. The climbing perch is a food fish in South Asia and Southeast Asia, where its ability to survive out of water has improved its marketability. In Thailand, it is believed that releasing this fish can help ward off disease, earning it the nickname "physician fish."

name: Leopard bush fish
description: The leopard bush fish, a member of the Anabantidae family, is a freshwater fish native to the Congo River basin in Middle Africa. In the wild, it can grow up to 20 cm but reaches around 15 cm in captivity. This slow-growing species is popular in the aquarium trade as a beginner oddball fish. In a tank, leopard bush fish are hardy but somewhat aggressive predators, preying on small fish and insects. They should not be housed with large aggressive cichlids. Suitable tank mates include medium-sized gouramis, bala sharks, silver dollars, Corydoras, and Plecostomus species. A 55-gallon tank with ample hiding spots and good filtration is recommended. They can be fed with live or dead alternatives like bloodworms and sinking pellets, as they may not readily accept flake foods. Observing their unique stalking behavior is a highlight for many aquarium enthusiasts.

name: Ornate ctenopoma
description: Microctenopoma ansorgii, also known as the ornate ctenopoma, is a small freshwater fish with an elongated and rounded body featuring red and black striped fins. In the aquarium trade, it is recognized for its colorful appearance and is commonly referred to as the orange ctenopoma or rainbow ctenopoma. This species is native to the slow-flowing forest streams of the Congo Basin, where it feeds on worms, insect larvae, and other aquatic invertebrates. In a fish tank, the ornate ctenopoma is known to be shy and easily intimidated, requiring a peaceful environment with smaller dither fish to help it feel secure and come out of hiding. It thrives on live or frozen foods and benefits from a well-maintained tank with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. Overall, providing a calm and well-fed environment is essential for the ornate ctenopoma to thrive in captivity.

name: Blue badis
description: Badis badis, also known as the blue perch, is a small predatory fish found in Asian freshwater habitats. In an aquarium, they would require a well-planted tank with plenty of hiding spots to mimic their natural environment. They prefer slow-moving waters and a diet of tiny invertebrates. Males are larger and more colorful than females, displaying blue fins and dark vertical bands when excited. It is important to provide a peaceful tank environment as they can be territorial towards their own species. Overall, Badis badis would thrive in a calm and well-decorated aquarium setting.

name: Scarlet badis
description: The scarlet badis, a tiny tropical freshwater fish, is a micropredator that feeds on small aquatic crustaceans, worms, and insect larvae. It is one of the smallest percoid fish species, with males not exceeding 2 cm and females even smaller at around 1.3 cm. These fish are known for their vibrant colors and prominent fins, making them easy to distinguish by sex. In an aquarium setting, scarlet badis thrive in shallow, clear water streams with sand or gravel substrates and dense vegetation. They prefer a well-planted tank with hiding spots and a peaceful environment. It is essential to provide them with a varied diet to mimic their natural feeding habits and ensure their well-being in captivity.

name: Malayan leaffish
description: The Malayan leaffish, scientifically known as Pristolepis fasciatus, is a fish found in various regions including Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam, Myanmar, the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, and Borneo. It can reach up to 20 cm in length and prefers slow-flowing waters with abundant vegetation such as rivers, lakes, ponds, and swamps. In a fish tank, the Malayan leaffish would thrive in a setup that mimics its natural habitat, with plenty of plants and hiding spots. It is important to provide a varied diet including algae, plants, fruits, insects, and small crustaceans to ensure its well-being. Additionally, maintaining stable water conditions and suitable tank mates is crucial for the Malayan leaffish to thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Forest snakehead
remarks: Illegal to possess live in the USA without a permit[65]
description: The forest snakehead, also known as Channa lucius, is a species of snakehead fish found in Southeast Asia and parts of southern China. It typically inhabits forest streams and can grow up to 40 cm (16 in) in length. This fish has distinct port-hole markings on its side and a more tapering head compared to other snakeheads. Juveniles are pale with three lateral stripes from head to tail. In a fish tank, the forest snakehead would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like rocks, plants, and driftwood. It is a predatory fish that may show aggression towards smaller tank mates, so it is best kept with fish of similar size and temperament. Providing a varied diet of live or frozen foods will help this species thrive in captivity.

name: Dwarf snakehead
remarks: Illegal to possess live in the USA without a permit[65]
description: Channa gachua, also known as the dwarf snakehead, is a small fish species native to freshwater habitats in southern Asia. It belongs to a species complex with closely related taxa. This fish can reach up to 28 cm in length but is usually smaller. It feeds on small fish, insects, and crustaceans and is a mouthbrooder, with males caring for the eggs and juveniles in their mouths. In a fish tank, the dwarf snakehead would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. It is important to provide a varied diet to meet its predatory nature. Due to its attractive coloration, it is valued in the aquarium trade and has been studied for aquaculture operations.

name: Emperor snakehead
remarks: Illegal to possess live in the USA without a permit[65]
description: The emperor snakehead, also known as Channa marulioides, is a fish species native to Indonesia, Thailand, and Malaysia. It can grow up to 65 cm in length and is currently listed as Least Concern by the IUCN. In a fish tank, the emperor snakehead would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. They are carnivorous and aggressive, so tank mates should be chosen carefully to avoid conflicts. Providing a varied diet consisting of live or frozen foods would be essential for their health and well-being.

name: Giant snakehead
remarks: Illegal to possess live in the USA without a permit[65]
description: The Channa micropeltes, also known as the giant snakehead, is a large fish species native to Southeast Asia. It can grow up to 1.5m in length and weigh 20kg. This fish has the ability to breathe air and survive in low-oxygen environments, earning it the nickname "mudfish." In a fish tank, the giant snakehead would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and a secure lid as they are known to be voracious predators. They can be housed with fish of similar size like silver arowanas, clown knifefishes, and oscars. It is important to note that they will chase and eat anything that fits in their mouths, so tank mates should be carefully selected.

name: Ocellated snakehead
remarks: Illegal to possess live in the USA without a permit[65]
description:
Channa pleurophthalma, also known as the ocellated snakehead, is a freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia. It can grow up to 40 centimeters in length and has a cylindrical, laterally flattened body with an iridescent greenish or bluish coloration. This species has distinctive black patches outlined in orange and ocelli on its opercle and tail fin. It is commonly found in areas with black and clear waters in Indonesia, specifically in Sumatra and Borneo. 

In a fish tank, Channa pleurophthalma would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like rocks, driftwood, and plants to mimic its natural habitat. It is essential to maintain clean and well-oxygenated water with a stable temperature. Due to its predatory nature, this fish should be kept with tank mates of similar size to avoid aggression. Providing a varied diet consisting of live or frozen foods will help keep this species healthy and thriving in captivity.

name: African snakehead
remarks: Illegal to possess live in the USA without a permit[65]
description: The obscure snakehead, Parachanna obscura, is a medium-sized carnivorous fish found in central Africa. It has an elongated shape, resembling a snake, with a large mouth and two rows of teeth. This fish thrives in harsh environments like muddy waters, living in streams, ponds, rivers, lakes, marshes, and swamps. It is known to be a bottom dweller and spends much of its time motionless among aquatic vegetation. In a fish tank, the obscure snakehead would require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. It is a carnivorous fish that feeds on other fish and insects, so a diet rich in protein would be essential for its well-being. Reproduction occurs throughout the year, and both male and female fish play a role in protecting the young. The obscure snakehead is being considered for aquaculture due to its high protein content, but there are concerns about unsustainable harvesting practices impacting both the fish population and human consumers.

name: Red rainbowfish
remarks: Almost all rainbowfish species are bred in captivity and wild populations may be protected.[66]
description: The red rainbowfish, also known as the salmon-red rainbowfish, is a species native to Lake Sentani in Indonesia. It is commonly found in the aquarium trade due to its ease of breeding in captivity. The males are bright red while females are olive brown, with colors changing based on mood. They grow up to 15 cm but usually reach around 12 cm. These fish are omnivores and readily eat common aquarium foods. In a fish tank, they would thrive in a well-planted environment with clumps of vegetation for egg scattering. They are slightly more carnivorous than other Australian rainbowfish species. Due to threats in their natural habitat, they are classified as endangered on the IUCN Red List. To ensure their well-being in a tank, it is important to provide a suitable environment resembling their natural habitat with proper food and care.

name: Lake Wanam rainbowfish
description: The Lake Wanam rainbowfish is a critically endangered species endemic to Lake Wanam in Papua New Guinea. Due to competition from non-native tilapias, it has virtually disappeared from its natural habitat. In a fish tank, this species would require a well-maintained environment resembling its natural habitat with ample space to swim and hide. Providing plants for cover and a varied diet would be essential for their well-being. Due to their endangered status, efforts to breed and conserve this species in captivity are crucial for its survival.

name: Threadfin rainbowfish
description: The threadfin rainbowfish, known for its long beautiful fins, is a small and attractive species native to freshwater swamps in tropical northern Australia and New Guinea. In an aquarium, they are peaceful and thrive best in groups of six or more. They should be kept in a tank without fin-nippers and preferably in a "species only" tank. The male courts the female by posturing in front of her, and a male-to-female ratio of about 1:3 is recommended due to their polygamous behavior. They do well in tanks of at least 20 US gallons, with 30 US gallons preferred. Threadfin rainbowfish are best fed live foods like baby brine shrimp and micrometre larval diets. They prefer soft to moderately hard, slightly acidic water with a temperature range of 23–29 °C.

name: New Guinea rainbowfish
description: The North New Guinea rainbowfish, also known as Melanotaenia affinis, is a peaceful and adaptable species of rainbowfish native to New Guinea. It thrives in clear rainforest streams, swamps, pools, and lagoons with abundant vegetation and submerged logs. In a fish tank, this species would require a pH of 7.0, hard water (100-150 mg/L), and a temperature range of 21-28°C (70-82°F). They should be kept in shoals and fed small live foods and prepared diets. To ensure their well-being and happiness, provide a tank environment that mimics their natural habitat with plenty of plants and hiding spots.

name: Western rainbowfish
description: The western rainbowfish, also known as Melanotaenia australis, is a freshwater fish native to Australia's Kimberley and Pilbara regions. It is a common and abundant species with variations in color patterns based on its geographic location. Predation and environmental conditions influence its color pattern, reflectance, and body shape. In a fish tank, western rainbowfish would thrive in a spacious environment with plenty of plants for hiding spots and swimming areas. They prefer a well-maintained tank with clean water, moderate lighting, and a varied diet to stay healthy and vibrant. It is important to provide them with a peaceful community of fish as they are known to be peaceful and social creatures.

name: Boeseman's rainbowfish
description: Boeseman's rainbowfish, also known as the Boesemani rainbowfish, is a colorful and peaceful species endemic to Indonesia. In an aquarium, they thrive in groups with more females than males and can coexist with various fish species like tetras and gouramis. They prefer weakly alkaline pH conditions and need hiding places for smaller freshwater shrimps. Boeseman's rainbowfish are hardy omnivores that enjoy a diverse diet of dry, frozen, and live foods. It's essential to provide appropriate-sized foods to maintain their health. With proper care, they can live for about 5-8 years on average, but some have been reported to live up to 13-15 years.

name: Duboulayi's rainbowfish
remarks: a.k.a. Crimson-Spotted rainbowfish
description: The Melanotaenia duboulayi, also known as the crimson-spotted rainbowfish, is a freshwater fish native to coastal eastern Australia. In an aquarium setting, they thrive in open water environments with submerged logs and vegetation. They are omnivorous, feeding on invertebrates and algae, and can also consume flake food. These fish exhibit vibrant colors, with males displaying intense black markings during spawning. They are known for their mosquito larvae consumption, making them a good candidate for mosquito control. Crimson-spotted rainbowfish are popular among aquarists internationally and are bred to preserve local variants in their native range.

name: Australian rainbowfish
description: The Murray River rainbowfish is a colorful freshwater fish native to southeastern Australia. In an aquarium, they thrive in a group of at least six fish and prefer a peaceful environment with logs or grassy riverbanks to school around. They are omnivorous, feeding on live foods and flakes. Breeding is relatively easy for this species. It's important to avoid keeping them with long-finned fish as they may nip at their fins when stressed. They are adaptable to various freshwater environments, including slow-flowing rivers, wetlands, and ponds, with a preferred temperature range of 22-25°C (72-77°F). Their vibrant colors and peaceful temperament make them a popular choice for aquarium enthusiasts.

name: Lake Tebera rainbowfish
description: The Lake Tebera rainbowfish, scientifically known as Melanotaenia herbertaxelrodi, is a species of rainbowfish native to the Lake Tebera basin in Papua New Guinea. This fish species was named in honor of Herbert R. Axelrod, a renowned pet-book publisher. In a fish tank, the Lake Tebera rainbowfish would thrive in a well-planted aquarium with plenty of swimming space. They are peaceful and social fish that do well in groups, so it is recommended to keep them in schools of at least six individuals. Providing a balanced diet and maintaining water quality are essential for their health and vibrancy.

name: Lake Kutubu rainbowfish
description: The Lake Kutubu rainbowfish, also known as the turquoise rainbowfish, is a species endemic to Lake Kutubu in Papua New Guinea. This fish species thrives in a freshwater environment with a lot of vegetation and hiding spots. In a fish tank, they would require a well-planted aquarium with ample swimming space and a peaceful community of fish. They are known to be peaceful and social fish, so they should be kept in groups of their own kind or with other non-aggressive fish species. Maintaining stable water parameters and providing a varied diet will help them thrive in a home aquarium setting.

name: Lake Kurumoi rainbowfish
description: The Lake Kurumoi rainbowfish is a freshwater rainbowfish native to Lake Kurumoi in West Papua, Indonesia. Due to habitat loss, its wild population may no longer exist in its native range. In a fish tank, this species would thrive in a well-maintained environment that mimics its natural habitat, including clean water with plenty of swimming space and vegetation for shelter. It would do well in a peaceful community tank with other non-aggressive fish of similar size. Regular water changes and a balanced diet would be essential for its health and well-being.

name: Neon rainbowfish
description: The dwarf rainbowfish, also known as Melanotaenia praecox, is a colorful and active species native to the Mamberamo River basin in Indonesia. In an aquarium, they require a tank of at least 15 gallons with a length of 50-60 centimeters to accommodate their energetic nature. It is recommended to keep a school of at least six individuals, with more females than males to reduce aggression. They are peaceful but males may spar, especially in the morning. They can coexist with most tropical freshwater fish that are not large or aggressive. Feeding them a varied diet including live food like mosquito larvae and brine shrimp is recommended. A heavily planted tank with floating plants is ideal for them to feel secure. They thrive in temperatures around 25°C and a pH of 7.

name: Eastern rainbowfish
description: The Eastern rainbowfish, Melanotaenia splendida splendida, is a colorful freshwater fish native to Australia. In an aquarium, this species thrives in a school setting, so it is recommended to keep them in groups. They prefer a well-planted tank with ample swimming space and subdued lighting. Eastern rainbowfish are omnivores, so their diet should include a variety of foods such as algae, insects, and small invertebrates. They are relatively small, reaching up to 14 cm in length, and males display vibrant colors while females and juveniles are more subtle in appearance. Overall, providing a peaceful environment with suitable tank mates and a balanced diet will help Eastern rainbowfish thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Banded rainbowfish
description: The banded rainbowfish, also known as the Jewel rainbowfish, is a colorful species found in northern regions of Australia.
