In an aquarium, they are active shoaling fish that prefer to swim near the surface and mid-level areas. They are seasonal spawners, with males competing for territory and female attention. These fish prefer habitats with strong water flow, sandy substrate, dense vegetation, and submerged logs. Banded rainbowfish are omnivores, feeding on arthropods, algae, and terrestrial insects. They are hardy and peaceful, making them suitable for community tanks with a lid to prevent jumping.

name: Celebes rainbow
description: The Celebes rainbowfish, also known as Marosatherina ladigesi, is a unique species native to Sulawesi, Indonesia. It is the sole member of its genus and is characterized by its slender, transparent body with a distinctive blue stripe. In an aquarium setting, these peaceful fish thrive in a temperature range of 20-28°C, pH of 7.0-7.5, and hardness of 150-200 mg/L. They prefer hiding among plant leaves and feed on small worms, insects, and vegetable debris. Due to their sensitivity to water quality, maintaining high levels of dissolved oxygen is crucial for their well-being. Although they can spawn continuously in favorable conditions, they may consume their own eggs. To ensure their optimal health, providing a suitable environment with ample hiding spots and proper water parameters is essential for the Celebes rainbowfish to thrive in a fish tank.

name: Forktail blue-eye
remarks: These fish need a larger aquarium than their size suggests. Though they only grow to a length of about 2 inches, they are happiest in groups of 8 – 10 or more, and they appreciate lots of swimming space.[67]
description: The forktail blue-eye, a small rainbowfish species native to Papua New Guinea, thrives in rainforest streams. In a fish tank, they would require a well-planted environment mimicking their natural habitat with plenty of hiding spots and subdued lighting. They are peaceful fish that do well in small groups, so a tank size of at least 10 gallons is recommended. Water parameters should be closely monitored, with a pH range of 6.0-7.5 and a temperature of 72-82°F. Providing a varied diet consisting of small live and frozen foods will help them thrive in captivity.

name: Spotted blue-eye
description: The spotted blue-eye, a small freshwater fish native to Papua New Guinea and northern Australia, is an adaptable species that thrives in captivity. With an elongated body reaching up to 3 cm in length, it has a transparent to pale silver-white color with black markings on its rear half and yellow fins. This fish species prefers small, slow-moving streams, pools, and swamps with a pH range of 3.68 to 9.4 in its natural habitat. In a fish tank, the spotted blue-eye would require a small freshwater aquarium with plenty of vegetation, hiding spots, and a well-maintained water quality. They feed on algae and small invertebrates, making their diet relatively easy to replicate in a tank environment. Known for breeding readily in captivity, the spotted blue-eye would thrive in a peaceful tank with suitable tank mates of similar size and temperament.

name: Red neon blue-eye
description: The red neon blue-eye, scientifically known as Pseudomugil luminatus, is a fish species found in swamps near Timika in Papua, Indonesia. This small fish belongs to the subfamily Pseudomugilinae. In a fish tank, the red neon blue-eye would thrive in a well-planted environment with plenty of hiding spots and open swimming space. They are peaceful and social fish that do well in groups, so it is recommended to keep them in schools of at least six individuals. The water quality should be maintained with stable parameters, including slightly acidic to neutral pH levels and temperatures around 72-78°F (22-26°C). Overall, providing a natural habitat with suitable tank mates and proper care will help the red neon blue-eye fish thrive and display their vibrant colors.

name: Pacific blue-eye
description: The Pacific blue-eye (Pseudomugil signifer) is a small fish native to eastern Australia, commonly found in rivers and estuaries. It is recognizable by its blue eye-ring and two dorsal fins. This species forms loose schools and feeds on water-borne and flying insects. In captivity, Pacific blue-eyes adapt well and thrive in aquariums. They prefer a habitat with aquatic plants, gravel, and moss for spawning. These fish can survive in a wide range of water salinities, making them euryhaline. In a tank, they should be provided with a varied diet of water-based and terrestrial insects, flying insects, tiny crustaceans, and algae. Pacific blue-eyes are known to dart in random directions when threatened and exhibit escape responses. They reach sexual maturity at around six months of age and have a lifespan of 1-2 years in the wild and 2-3 years in aquariums. Proper care, a suitable environment, and a diverse diet are essential for the well-being of Pacific blue-eyes in a fish tank.

name: Delicate blue-eye
description: The delicate blue-eye, scientifically known as Pseudomugil tenellus, is a fish species native to northern Australia and Papua New Guinea. This small fish belongs to the subfamily Pseudomugilinae. In a fish tank, delicate blue-eyes thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of vegetation and hiding spots. They prefer a peaceful community tank with other small, non-aggressive fish. Providing a diet rich in small live or frozen foods will help them thrive. It is important to maintain stable water parameters, including temperature and pH levels, to ensure the well-being of delicate blue-eyes in a tank.

name: Madagascar rainbowfish
description: Bedotia madagascariensis, also known as zona, is a fish species endemic to Madagascar, commonly found in rivers and lakes in specific regions of the country. It is a popular choice in the aquarium trade but is threatened by habitat loss in the wild. In a fish tank, Bedotia madagascariensis would thrive in a well-maintained environment that mimics its natural habitat, including ample space to swim, plants for cover, and clean water with moderate flow. They are peaceful fish that do well in a community tank with other non-aggressive species. Providing a varied diet consisting of high-quality flakes, pellets, and live or frozen foods will help ensure their health and vibrancy in captivity.

name: Empire gudgeon
description: The empire gudgeon, scientifically known as Hypseleotris compressa, is a Gobiiform fish native to Australia and south-central New Guinea. It has an elongated body reaching up to 12 cm in length, with males being larger than females. This fish is typically found in freshwater rivers or streams, but can also thrive in still water and tolerate varying salinity levels. In a fish tank, the empire gudgeon would require ample swimming space, aquatic plants, and rocks for hiding and breeding. They are omnivorous, feeding on small crustaceans, insects, algae, and aquatic plants. Breeding occurs in warm weather, with males displaying vibrant colors to attract mates. The male guards the adhesive-coated eggs until they hatch, and the fry then move downstream for development. Due to their unique spawning behavior and small fry size, breeding this species in aquariums can be challenging. The empire gudgeon is efficient at controlling mosquito larvae, making it a valuable addition to a tank ecosystem.

name: Purple sleeper gudgeon
description: The northern trout gudgeon, also known as Mogurnda mogurnda, is a freshwater fish found in northern Australia and New Guinea. This species belongs to the Eleotridae family. In a fish tank, the northern trout gudgeon would thrive in a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots like rocks, driftwood, and plants. They prefer clean water with moderate flow and a sandy substrate. These fish are peaceful and can be kept in a community tank with other non-aggressive species of similar size. It is important to provide them with a varied diet including live and frozen foods to ensure their health and well-being.

name: Peacock gudgeon, Peacock goby
remarks: A little territorial with its own kind but is suitable for many communities of small, peaceful fish. Ideal tankmates are other species from Papua New Guinea, such as Popondetta sp. rainbowfishes; but tetras, rasboras, Corydoras cats and virtually any other small peaceful species are also suitable.[68]
description: The peacock gudgeon, also known as the peacock goby, is a colorful freshwater fish native to Papua New Guinea. It reaches a length of 7.5 cm and displays vibrant blue, pink, yellow, and black markings. In captivity, they feed on insects, larvae, and crustaceans but can also accept Brine Shrimp and Bloodworms. Males exhibit elaborate courtship behavior and parental care, guarding eggs until they hatch. These fish are peaceful and suitable for community tanks of at least 15 gallons, but males can be territorial towards each other. They thrive in environments with low lighting, ample hiding spots, and potential spawning sites like PVC pipes near plants. The more hiding places available, the more active and comfortable these fish will be in a tank setting.

name: Black toraja goby
description: Sarasin's goby, also known as Mugilogobius sarasinorum, is a small fish species native to Lake Poso in Sulawesi, Indonesia. It grows up to 8 centimeters in length and is significant to local fisheries. In a fish tank, Sarasin's goby would thrive in a well-maintained environment mimicking its natural habitat. It prefers a freshwater setup with sandy substrate, plenty of hiding spots like rocks or plants, and moderate water flow. Providing a varied diet including small live or frozen foods would help keep this species healthy and active. It is essential to monitor water quality closely and ensure a peaceful tank community as Sarasin's goby can be shy and may get stressed in aggressive surroundings.

name: Bumblebee goby
description:
The bumblebee goby, scientifically known as Brachygobius doriae, is a small species of goby found in fresh and brackish waters across Southeast Asia. It typically grows up to 4.2 centimeters in length and is considered Least Concern in terms of conservation status. This fish is popular in the aquarium trade due to its striking appearance. 

In a fish tank, the bumblebee goby would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a well-decorated tank with plenty of hiding spots like rocks, caves, and plants. It prefers brackish water conditions and a sandy substrate. The bumblebee goby is a peaceful fish but can be territorial towards its own kind, so it is best kept in small groups or pairs. Providing a varied diet of small live or frozen foods will help keep this species healthy and active in a home aquarium.

name: Knight goby
description: Stigmatogobius sadanundio, also known as the knight goby, is a gray-blue fish native to South Asia. It thrives in freshwater, occasionally in brackish waters, particularly in estuaries and tidal zones of rivers. In an aquarium, it should be kept alone or with mid-level species to avoid territorial conflicts. The knight goby prefers low light and plenty of rocks, caves, and natural boundaries. It feeds on live food but can adapt to commercial formulations. Maintaining a fluctuating temperature and adding a small amount of salt to the water can benefit its well-being. Breeding requires a species tank with a sand substrate, elevated water temperature, and the presence of caves for egg laying. The fry can be easily reared on newly hatched brine shrimp.

name: Barred mudskipper
description: The barred mudskipper, also known as the silverlined mudskipper, is a species of mudskipper found in marine, fresh, and brackish waters across various regions. It thrives in mangrove forests and nipa palm stands, capable of moving across mud surfaces when out of water. In an aquarium setting, the barred mudskipper would require a brackish water environment mimicking its natural habitat with access to land areas for basking. Providing a mix of water and land areas, along with suitable hiding spots and a varied diet including live and frozen foods, would help this species thrive in a fish tank. It is essential to maintain water quality and salinity levels to ensure the health and well-being of the barred mudskipper in captivity.

name: Atlantic mudskipper
description: The Atlantic mudskipper, scientifically known as Periophthalmus barbarus, is a semi-aquatic fish species found in tropical Atlantic coasts of Africa, the Indian Ocean, and western Pacific Ocean. In a fish tank, they would require a brackish water environment with access to both land and water areas for their unique behavior. They are territorial and need space to establish their territory. Atlantic mudskippers are carnivorous and use an ambushing strategy to capture prey, utilizing a 'hydrodynamic tongue' for feeding. They have specific adaptations for both aquatic and terrestrial locomotion, with fins that aid in skipping, crawling, and climbing on land. These fish have a lifespan of around five years and reach sexual maturity at approximately 10-11 cm in length. To thrive, they need a diet of live or frozen food like worms, crickets, flies, small fish, and crustaceans. Additionally, they require a warm and humid environment to support their cutaneous respiration and maintain their body temperature. Overall, providing a suitable habitat with varied diet options and proper care will ensure the well-being of Atlantic mudskippers in a fish tank setting.

name: Bearded worm goby
description: The Bearded worm goby, also known as Taenioides cirratus, is a fish species found in the Indian Ocean and western Pacific Ocean. It can grow up to 30 cm in length and is commonly found in estuaries and coastal waters with mud substrates. In a fish tank, Bearded worm gobies would thrive in brackish water with plenty of hiding spots like rocks or plants. They feed on small crustaceans and invertebrates, so a varied diet is essential for their well-being. They are known to be capable of surviving out of water for a period by breathing air. It's important to note that they are an invasive species in certain areas and can impact the local ecosystem by reducing populations of shrimp and benthic fish.

name: Marbled goby
description: The marble goby, a large gobioid fish, is native to fresh and brackish waters in Southeast Asia. In a fish tank, it would require ample space due to its size, with a minimum tank size of at least 75 gallons for a single fish. The tank should have plenty of hiding spots like caves or plants as the marble goby is a shy and reclusive species. They prefer sandy substrate and clean, well-oxygenated water with a neutral to slightly acidic pH. Feeding them a varied diet of live or frozen foods like shrimp, worms, and small fish is essential for their health. Overall, providing a peaceful environment with suitable tank mates and proper water conditions is crucial for the marble goby to thrive in captivity.

name: Crazy fish
description: The Crazy Fish, also known as Butis butis, is a small sleeper goby native to brackish and freshwater coastal habitats of the Indian Ocean and western Pacific Ocean. They prefer well-vegetated waters such as mangrove swamps. In a fish tank, they would thrive in an environment that mimics their natural habitat with plenty of vegetation and hiding spots. They are predatory and known for their unique behavior of swimming vertically or even upside down while hunting. Crazy fish are territorial, active at twilight and night, and feed on crustaceans, small fishes, and worms. They have the ability to change colors slightly to blend in with their surroundings. They are commonly caught for the aquarium trade and are classified as Least Concern by the IUCN.

Rhinogobius duospilus, a small goby species native to China and Vietnam, thrives in fresh or brackish waters. These fish grow up to 4.5 centimeters in length and primarily feed on larvae and small creatures. In a fish tank, they would require a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation to mimic their natural habitat. Providing a varied diet including brine shrimp and bloodworms would be essential for their health and well-being. Due to their small size and specific dietary needs, they would do best in a peaceful community tank with other small, non-aggressive fish.

name: Striped sleeper goby
description: The fat sleeper fish, belonging to the Eleotridae family, is known for its flat head and can be found in freshwater environments such as lakes, ponds, and rivers. They have a distinctive appearance with two dorsal fins, a flat head, and rounded tails. Their bodies are dark brown with reddish dorsal and anal fins, and a blue spot around their gill covers. Fat sleepers are typically found from the Bahamas to Brazil, living in intertidal areas on muddy bottoms, often in brackish water or freshwater coastal pools and river mouths. In a fish tank, fat sleepers would thrive in a setup that mimics their natural habitat, with sandy or muddy substrate, ample hiding spots like rocks or driftwood, and moderate water flow. They are peaceful fish but can be territorial, so providing enough space and hiding spots for each fish is essential for their well-being. Maintaining water quality and offering a varied diet will help fat sleepers thrive in a home aquarium.

name: West African lungfish
description: The West African lungfish, also known as the Tana lungfish, is a freshwater fish found in various habitats in Africa. It has a long eel-like body with prominent snout and small eyes, growing up to 1 meter long and weighing up to 4 kilograms. This species is an obligate air breather and can aestivate for up to a year during dry seasons. In a fish tank, the West African lungfish would require a spacious tank with sandy substrate for burrowing. It would need access to the surface for breathing air and should be provided with a varied diet of mollusks, crabs, prawns, and small fish. Additionally, the tank should have hiding spots and be kept at a stable temperature to mimic its natural environment for the lungfish to thrive.

name: Spotted lungfish
description: The spotted lungfish, also known as the slender lungfish, is a freshwater fish found in the Congo, Kouilou-Niari, and Ogowe river basins in Middle Africa. It has an eel-like body, primarily brown in color with black spots in its youth. This species is an obligate air-breather capable of aestivation, but typically does not engage in this behavior. During spawning season, females can be found in open water while males create nests buried in mud to guard eggs and larvae. In a fish tank, the spotted lungfish would require a spacious environment with a soft substrate to mimic riverbeds. It would benefit from areas to hide and explore, as well as access to the water's surface for air-breathing. Maintaining good water quality is crucial for their well-being, as they have evolved mechanisms to cope with ammonia toxicity.

name: South American lungfish
description: The South American lungfish, also known as Lepidosiren paradoxa, is a unique fish species found in the swamps and slow-moving waters of South America. This lungfish is an obligate air-breather and can adapt to both droughts and floods. In a fish tank, the South American lungfish would require a large tank with ample space to swim and explore. They prefer muddy substrates and would benefit from hiding spots like caves or plants. Due to their ability to breathe air, the tank should have access to the surface for them to breathe. They are omnivorous, feeding on insect larvae, snails, algae, and shrimp, so a varied diet is essential for their well-being. The tank should be maintained at a stable temperature and water quality to mimic their natural habitat. Overall, providing a spacious tank with suitable hiding spots, access to the surface for air-breathing, and a varied diet will help the South American lungfish thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Australian lungfish
description: The Australian lungfish, also known as the Queensland lungfish, is an ancient fish species endemic to Australia. It is the only surviving member of its family and one of the oldest living vertebrate genera on the planet. This fish species prefers slow-flowing rivers with aquatic vegetation and temperatures between 15-25°C. In a fish tank, the Australian lungfish would require a large tank with ample space to swim and explore. It is primarily nocturnal and carnivorous, feeding on frogs, tadpoles, fishes, and invertebrates. The lungfish is known to be sedentary, spending its life within a restricted area, making it suitable for a calm and peaceful tank environment. It has a unique lung for breathing air and can survive out of water for several days if kept moist. The Australian lungfish is a protected species, and its capture in the wild is strictly prohibited. It is threatened by human activities such as water development, which can disrupt its habitat and population structure.

name: Ocellate river stingray
remarks: has venomous barbs that contain a protein based poison, if you happen to accidentally get stung you should submerge the wound in as hot as water as you can as this breaks down the protein[69]
description: The ocellate river stingray, also known as Potamotrygon motoro, is a freshwater stingray found in South America. It can grow up to 50 cm in disc width and requires a large tank to thrive in captivity. This species has a circular disc shape with beige or brown coloration and yellow-orange spots with dark rings. The exact color and spot arrangement can vary among individuals and locations. Ocellate river stingrays are popular in aquariums but need a spacious environment similar to other Potamotrygon species. They are known to be one of the most widespread freshwater stingrays and can be found in various river basins in tropical and subtropical regions of South America.

name: Black devil stingray
remarks: see above
description: The Xingu River ray, also known as the white-blotched river stingray, is a freshwater fish native to the Xingu River basin in Brazil. It thrives in clear waters with rocky bottoms. In an aquarium setting, this species would require a spacious tank with similar conditions to its natural habitat, including clear water and a rocky substrate. The Xingu River ray can grow up to 40 cm in disc width, with females typically being larger than males. It is closely related to other stingray species like P. henlei and P. albimaculata. This species is venomous, with venom localized in its tail spine. The venom toxicity decreases as the ray matures, while its jaw strength increases, allowing it to consume hard-shelled invertebrates. Overall, the Xingu River ray would need a well-maintained tank with appropriate water parameters and a suitable diet to thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Gray bichir, Senegal bichir, or dinosaur bichir
size: 70.0 cm (27.6 in) maximum length[70]40.0 centimetres (15.7 in) in captivity[71]
remarks: Peaceful but preys on anything smaller than its mouth[72]
description: The Senegal bichir, also known as the dinosaur bichir or dragon fish, is a primitive fish species with a lungfish-like appearance. It is commonly kept in aquariums by hobbyists. In a fish tank, the Senegal bichir requires a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots like caves or plants. They are slow-moving, opportunistic ambush predators that feed on small vertebrates, insects, and crustaceans. Due to their predatory nature, tankmates should be at least half their size to avoid being eaten. They have a pair of primitive lungs and will periodically gulp air from the water's surface. They are known to be able to survive out of water as long as their skin remains moist. Senegal bichirs can live up to 10-15 years in captivity and exhibit social behavior by sometimes following each other. It is important to note that they may bite the fins of other fish if given the opportunity.

name: Ornate bichir
remarks: Peaceful but preys on anything smaller than its mouth[72]
description: The ornate bichir, Polypterus ornatipinnis, is a striking bony fish native to Central and East Africa. It features black and yellow patterning on its body, head, and fins, growing up to 60 cm in length. This fish is well-suited for aquariums due to its attractive appearance and ability to breathe air. In a fish tank, the ornate bichir would thrive in an environment that mimics its natural habitat, such as a large tank with plenty of hiding spots, soft substrate, and moderate water flow. It is important to provide a secure lid as these fish are known to be skilled escape artists. Additionally, maintaining good water quality and offering a varied diet will help ensure the ornate bichir's well-being in a home aquarium.

name: Retropinnis bichir
remarks: Peaceful but preys on anything smaller than its mouth[72]
description: The West African bichir, also known as Polypterus retropinnis, is a primitive freshwater fish found in the central Congo River basin and Ogooué River in Africa. It has a long, slender body that can grow up to 34 cm in length. This species has unique features such as rudimentary lungs and the ability to breathe air when oxygen levels are low in the water. In an aquarium, the West African bichir would thrive in a setup that mimics its natural habitat of swamps and floodplains. They are territorial fish that may exhibit aggressive behavior towards intruders by raising dorsal fin spines and emitting sounds. When kept in captivity, they require a diet of small to medium-sized vertebrates and invertebrates. It is important to provide hiding spots and enough space for the West African bichir to explore and establish its territory in the tank.

name: Barred bichir
remarks: Peaceful but preys on anything smaller than its mouth[72]
description: The barred bichir, also known as Polypterus delhezi, is a unique fish species found in the Congo River. It has a greyish color with hints of yellow or green, and its dorsal fin is distinctive with individual spines. This fish has a primitive swim bladder that functions as a lung, allowing it to survive out of water for some time if kept moist. The bichir has ganoid scales, similar to sturgeons and paddlefishes, and a jaw shape suited for a carnivorous diet. In a fish tank, the barred bichir would thrive in a nocturnal environment with hiding spots during the day. It prefers a carnivorous diet of small fish, insects, and worms, making shrimp, prawn, and mussels suitable food options. The tank should be spacious enough for the fish to move around comfortably and have a secure lid to prevent escape, as they are known to be good jumpers.

name: Saddled bichir
remarks: Peaceful but preys on anything smaller than its mouth[72]
description: Polypterus endlicheri, also known as the saddled bichir, is a large freshwater fish species belonging to the Polypterus genus. It can grow up to 63 cm in length and weigh around 3.3 kg. This fish has a distinctive flattened head with a prominent lower jaw, green and yellow dorsal coloring, and black spots on its head and fins. The saddled bichir is piscivorous, feeding on fish, snails, and crustaceans. It reproduces during the rainy season and is an egg scatterer. In an aquarium, Polypterus endlicheri requires proper maintenance to thrive. It is native to freshwater habitats in Africa, particularly in the Nile River, Chad Basin, Niger River, Volta River, and Bandama River. This species is found in countries such as Cameroon, Nigeria, Burkina Faso, Ghana, Chad, Ivory Coast, Mali, Sudan, Benin, and the Central African Republic. To ensure the well-being of a saddled bichir in a fish tank, it is essential to provide a spacious environment with suitable water conditions and a varied diet to mimic its natural habitat.

name: Reedfish
size: 31.4 cm (12.4 in) at maturity, 37 centimetres (15 in) maximum length[76]
description: The reedfish, also known as ropefish or snakefish, is a unique species native to West and Central Africa. It has the ability to breathe atmospheric air, making it suitable for oxygen-poor waters. In a fish tank, reedfish require slow-moving or standing fresh or brackish water with dense plant growth. They are nocturnal and feed on worms, crustaceans, insects, snails, and small fish. Reedfish are inquisitive and peaceful but may be bullied by other fish. They have a tendency to explore land and can be sensitive to water conditions, such as pH swings and nitrogen chemistry. Reedfish are challenging to keep in captivity as they are known to jump out of tanks and are sensitive to water parameters. They are best kept in a species-specific tank to prevent conflicts with other fish and require a secure lid to prevent escape.

name: Sterlet
description: The sterlet is a small sturgeon species native to Eurasia, found in rivers flowing into the Black Sea, Azov Sea, and Caspian Sea. Due to overfishing and habitat degradation, it is considered vulnerable. In a fish tank, sterlets need large ponds with good water conditions and may require special food like sterlet sticks. They feed on benthic organisms and prefer water temperatures of 12-17°C for spawning. Sterlets can live up to 25 years, with females laying thousands of eggs. To thrive, they need a spacious tank with appropriate water quality and specialized feeding to mimic their natural habitat.

name: Shovelnose Sturgeon
description: The shovelnose sturgeon is a small freshwater fish native to North America, often found in the Missouri River and Mississippi River systems. It has a shovel-shaped snout and a long filament on its caudal fin. In a fish tank, shovelnose sturgeons would require a spacious environment with sand or gravel substrate, swift currents, and ample bottom space for feeding. They are bottom feeders, mainly consuming aquatic insect larvae, crustaceans, worms, and small fish. Due to their slow growth rate and specific habitat needs, they may not be suitable for all aquarium setups. Additionally, their resemblance to the endangered pallid sturgeon has led to their listing as a threatened species under the U.S. Endangered Species Act.

name: American paddlefish
description: The American paddlefish, also known as the Mississippi paddlefish, is a unique freshwater fish with a cartilaginous skeleton and a paddle-shaped rostrum used for filter feeding on zooplankton. In a fish tank, they would require a large, free-flowing environment with ample space to swim and feed. They are long-lived, slow to mature, and primarily feed on zooplankton. American paddlefish are highly mobile and prefer deeper, low current areas in rivers. They are endemic to the Mississippi River Basin and adjacent Gulf slope drainages. Their populations have declined due to overfishing, habitat destruction, and pollution. They are protected under state, federal, and international laws. In a home aquarium, they would need a tank large enough to accommodate their size, with a strong filtration system to maintain water quality.

name: Bowfin
description: The bowfin, a bony fish native to North America, is known for its primitive characteristics and long lifespan of up to 33 years. In a fish tank, bowfins would require a spacious environment with vegetated sloughs, lowland rivers, and ample hiding spots like roots or logs. They are predatory fish that feed on fish and aquatic invertebrates, so a diet rich in protein would be essential for their health. Bowfins have a unique ability to breathe both water and air, making them adaptable to various oxygen levels. They prefer temperatures between 12-26°C and are active in warmer waters. Bowfins are known for their voracious appetite and agile hunting behavior, making them fascinating to observe in a tank setting. However, due to their sharp teeth and strong fighting abilities, careful handling is necessary. Bowfins are not commonly sought after by anglers for sport or commercial purposes, but they can be enjoyed in a tank for their unique characteristics and behaviors.

name: Spotted Gar
description: The spotted gar is a freshwater fish native to North America known for its dark spots and elongated body with needle-like teeth. In a fish tank, spotted gar would require a large tank with clear, slow-moving water and ample vegetation for cover. They are voracious predators, feeding on fish, shrimp, insect larvae, and algae. Spotted gar prefer clear, shallow waters in creeks, rivers, and lakes, occasionally entering brackish waters. They spawn in spring in shallow, vegetated areas, with females laying up to 20,000 eggs. To thrive, spotted gar need a habitat with clear water, abundant vegetation, and minimal pollution. They are threatened by habitat destruction and pollution, impacting their survivability. It is essential to maintain water quality, avoid pollution, and protect their habitat to ensure the conservation of this species.

name: Longnose Gar
description: The longnose gar is a ray-finned fish found in freshwater lakes, brackish waters, swamps, and slow-moving rivers. They have a torpedo-shaped body with ganoid scales, elongated jaws, and sharp teeth. Longnose gars can breathe air and water, allowing them to thrive in low-oxygen environments. In a fish tank, they would require a large tank with ample space to swim and hide among vegetation or structures like rocks and driftwood. They are carnivorous, feeding on small fish, insects, and crustaceans, making them unsuitable for community tanks with smaller fish. Longnose gars are apex predators with few natural predators, but they are vulnerable when young. They have a long lifespan of 15-20 years, with females maturing around 6 years old. Breeding occurs in temperatures around 20°C, with females laying adhesive-coated eggs on substrates. Due to declining populations from overfishing and habitat loss, conservation efforts are crucial to ensure their survival.

name: Florida Gar
description: The Florida gar is a mid-sized gar species found in the US, primarily in Georgia and Florida waters. It can grow over 3 ft long and mainly feeds on fish, shrimp, and crayfish. In a fish tank, Florida gar would require a large tank with plenty of space to swim and hide, as well as sandy or muddy bottoms and underwater vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. They prefer medium to shallow waters with poor oxygen levels, so a well-aerated tank is essential. Florida gar are ambush predators that stalk their prey and strike quickly, so tank mates should be chosen carefully to avoid aggression. Overall, providing a tank environment that resembles their natural habitat and meets their space and oxygen needs is crucial for Florida gar to thrive.

name: Alligator Gar
description: The alligator gar is a large freshwater fish found in North America, known for its resemblance to alligators with a broad snout and sharp teeth. They are ambush predators, primarily feeding on fish but also known to eat waterfowl and small mammals. Alligator gars are euryhaline, adapting to varying salinities from freshwater to brackish waters. In a fish tank, they would require a very large aquarium or pond with ample space. They are popular in public aquaria and zoos but illegal to keep as pets in some areas. Alligator gars are highly prized in the aquarium trade, particularly in Japan, where large specimens can fetch high prices. They are considered good candidates for aquaculture due to their rapid growth, disease resistance, and ability to tolerate low water quality.

name: Cuban Gar
description: The Cuban gar, also known as manjuarí, is a tropical freshwater fish found in rivers and lakes of western Cuba and Isla de la Juventud. They are solitary hunters but form groups during spawning season. They can grow up to 2m in length and are known for their tolerance to high ammonia and nitrate levels in water. In a fish tank, Cuban gars would require a large tank with plenty of space to swim and hide. They are top-level predators and feed on freshwater fishes and birds, so tank mates should be chosen carefully. The tank should have good filtration and aeration to maintain water quality, and they would benefit from a diet of live or frozen foods. Providing a suitable environment with appropriate tank mates and water conditions will help Cuban gars thrive in captivity.

name: Tropical Gar
description: The tropical gar is a fish species found in Central America, known as gaspar in the region. It prefers fresh and brackish water habitats like rivers and lakes but avoids strong currents. This species resembles the longnose gar but has a shorter, broader snout. It feeds on cichlids and other fish. In a fish tank, the tropical gar would require a large tank with plenty of space to swim and hide, as well as a varied diet of live or frozen fish. It is important to mimic its natural habitat with plants and rocks to provide hiding spots. Regular water changes and maintenance are necessary to keep the tank clean and suitable for the tropical gar to thrive.

name: Blunt-jawed elephantnose
description: The blunt-jawed elephantnose, also known as Gnathonemus tamandua, is a species of elephantfish native to rivers in West and Middle Africa. This fish has a distinctive appearance with a long elephant-like snout and a brown or black coloration. It feeds on worms, fish, and insects in its natural habitat. In a fish tank, the blunt-jawed elephantnose would require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and a sandy substrate to mimic its natural environment. Due to its unique feeding habits, providing a varied diet including live and frozen foods would be essential for its health and well-being. Additionally, maintaining stable water parameters and a gentle water flow would help this fish thrive in captivity.

name: Peters' elephant nose
description: Peters's elephant-nose fish, also known as the elephantnose fish, is a unique African freshwater species that uses electrolocation to find prey. In a fish tank, this timid fish thrives in a heavily planted environment with subdued lighting and soft, sandy substrate. It prefers a tank of over 200 liters and benefits from additions like a pipe or hollow log for shelter. The fish feeds on small worms and aquatic invertebrates but can also accept frozen or flake food. It requires water of medium hardness with a pH of 6.8 to 7.2 and a temperature between 26–28°C. While typically docile in captivity, it can be aggressive towards other fish species and territorial towards its own kind, requiring a larger tank if kept with others. Owners should avoid keeping more than one in captivity due to territorial behavior. The species has never been bred in captivity, so specific water parameters must be maintained for it to thrive.

name: African butterflyfish
description: The freshwater butterflyfish, Pantodon buchholzi, is a small fish with large pectoral fins that can grow up to 13 cm in length. It is a carnivorous surface hunter that feeds on aquatic insects and smaller fishes. This fish requires a tank with live plants and floating foliage for cover, as well as a pH of 6.9–7.1 and a KH of 1–10. They thrive in slow to no-current areas with a temperature range of 73–86 °F. Freshwater butterflyfish can be aggressive towards their own kind and other surface-level fish, so it's best to keep them as single specimens in a tank with a tightly closed lid to prevent jumping. They should not be housed with fin-eating or aggressive fish and prefer a diet of live or canned insects and feeder fish. A tank size of at least 20 gallons long is recommended for their well-being.

name: Aba aba
description: The Gymnarchus niloticus, also known as the aba or African knifefish, is a unique electric fish found in swamps, lakes, and rivers in Africa. It has a long, slender body without caudal, pelvic, or anal fins, relying on its elongated dorsal fin for propulsion. This fish grows up to 1.6m in length and 19kg in weight. Gymnarchus niloticus is nocturnal and uses a weak electric field to navigate and hunt for smaller fish due to its poor vision. In a fish tank, it would require a spacious environment with hiding spots and minimal lighting to mimic its natural habitat. Due to its unique hunting behavior and sensitivity to its surroundings, it would thrive in a well-maintained tank with minimal disturbances.

name: Reticulated knifefish
description: The reticulated knifefish is a freshwater fish native to tropical West Africa, growing up to 80 cm in length. It has a unique feather-like dorsal fin and uses its anal fin for propulsion. This fish can breathe air at the water's surface and has adapted swim bladder for this purpose. In a fish tank, the reticulated knifefish would thrive in a spacious tank with hiding spots and gentle water flow. It is important to maintain good water quality and provide a varied diet for their well-being. Due to their electroreceptive nature, it's essential to keep tank mates that are peaceful and won't stress them out.

name: African brown knifefish
description: The African brown knifefish is a unique fish species found in various river basins in Africa. It has a distinctive knife-like body shape with fused caudal and anal fins for precise control in the water. This nocturnal fish relies on its lateral line and large eyes for navigation and hunting. In an aquarium, it thrives in quiet waters with vegetation, but may become aggressive towards its own kind as it ages. It is important to provide hiding spots and keep it with larger tankmates to prevent predation on smaller fish. This species feeds on worms, crustaceans, insects, and snails, and may produce barking sounds while coming to the surface to swallow air.

name: Royal knifefish
description: The royal knifefish, also known as the Indochina featherback, is a ray-finned fish found in the Mekong basin in Southeast Asia. It is sometimes sold in the aquarium trade as the royal clown knifefish. In a fish tank, the royal knifefish would require a large tank with plenty of space to swim as they are active swimmers. They prefer a well-oxygenated environment with clean water and hiding spots like plants or caves. It is important to provide a varied diet for this species to ensure their health and well-being in captivity.

name: Clown knifefish
description: The clown featherback, also known as the clown knifefish, is a nocturnal tropical fish with a long, knife-like body. It is native to freshwater habitats in Southeast Asia but has been introduced to other regions. In an aquarium, this species requires a large tank with caves, plants, and hiding spots due to their shy nature. They are jumpers, so a tightly closed lid is necessary. Clown knifefish are hearty eaters and prefer live foods initially, but can be adapted to commercial food pellets. They are mostly nocturnal and prefer feeding in dim lighting. These fish thrive in water with a neutral pH and temperatures between 75-85°F. They are territorial as they mature and can grow up to 1m in length. Overall, the clown featherback is not suitable for the average home aquarium due to its large size and specific care requirements.

name: Asian arowana
remarks: Preys on anything smaller than its mouth.[77]
description: The Asian arowana, also known as the Asian bonytongue or dragonfish, is a freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia. They are popular aquarium fish with special cultural significance in areas influenced by Chinese culture due to their resemblance to the Chinese dragon. In a fish tank, Asian arowanas require a large aquarium with a tight-fitting cover to prevent escape. They are territorial and should ideally be kept alone or with similar-sized fish. The water should be well-filtered, slightly acidic, and maintained at a temperature of 24–30 °C (75–86 °F). Asian arowanas are carnivorous and should be fed a high-quality diet of meaty foods like shrimp, crickets, and live prey. They are surface feeders and prefer food in the upper parts of the water column. Conservation efforts are crucial as they are listed as endangered, with declining habitat and high demand in the aquarium trade posing significant threats to their survival.

name: Gulf saratoga
description: The Gulf saratoga, also known as the Australian bonytongue, is a freshwater fish native to Australia and New Guinea. It thrives in still clear waters of pools, billabongs, and slow-flowing streams. This species has a long, dark body with pearly spots on its scales and large pectoral fins. It can grow up to 90 cm in length and weigh up to 27 kg. Gulf saratoga is not endangered and is an opportunistic carnivore, feeding on insects, small fish, and crustaceans. In a fish tank, they would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and a varied diet to thrive. It is important to provide them with a well-maintained tank with clean water and suitable tank mates to ensure their well-being.

name: Southern saratoga
description: The southern saratoga, also known as the spotted bonytongue, is a freshwater bony fish native to Australia. It is a carnivorous mouthbrooder belonging to the arowana family. This species thrives in turbid waters and prefers still waters and slow-flowing river sections with shelter like lily pads or fallen timber. In an aquarium, southern saratoga can be aggressive and territorial, preying on smaller tank mates like fish, shrimp, and yabbies. They are primitive, surface-dwelling fish with a compressed body, flat back, and distinctive coloration of dark brown to olive green with red or orange dots on large bony scales. To thrive in a fish tank, southern saratoga would require a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and vegetation to mimic its natural habitat. It is essential to provide a diet rich in carnivorous foods to meet its nutritional needs.

name: Silver arowana
remarks: Preys on anything smaller than its mouth.[77]
description: The silver arowana is a South American freshwater fish known for its large scales, long body, and tapered tail. It requires a very large tank due to its predatory nature. This species is native to the Amazon, Essequibo, and Oyapock basins, thriving in both black- and whitewater habitats, including flooded forests. In an aquarium, the silver arowana will swim near the water surface, waiting to prey on snails, crustaceans, insects, smaller fish, and other surface-dwelling animals. Its drawbridge-like mouth is adapted for capturing prey. This fish is sometimes called 'water monkey' for its ability to jump out of the water. The silver arowana is popular among aquarists and is a suitable alternative to the Asian arowana. It is essential to provide a spacious tank with appropriate hiding spots and a secure lid to prevent jumping. Regular feeding and water quality maintenance are crucial for its well-being.

name: Black arowana
remarks: Preys on anything smaller than its mouth.[77]
description: The black arowana is a predatory freshwater fish native to South America, specifically the Rio Negro basin. In an aquarium, they require a very large tank due to their size and predatory nature. They are sedentary and prefer blackwater habitats, often found in backwaters and flooded forests. Juveniles have black bodies with yellow markings, while adults develop a dark iridescent coloration with yellow and red fins. They are known to jump out of the water to capture prey and mainly feed on shrimps, insects, and smaller fishes. To thrive, they need a tank that mimics their natural habitat with plenty of space to swim near the water surface. The males mouthbrood the eggs, releasing the young when they are about 7 cm long.

name: Pirarucu
description: The Arapaima gigas, also known as pirarucu, is a large freshwater fish native to the Amazon River basin. This species is an obligate air breather, needing to come to the surface regularly to breathe air. In a fish tank, Arapaima gigas would require a large tank with plenty of surface area for them to gulp air. They prefer a habitat that mimics flooded forest areas with ample swimming space and hiding spots. They primarily feed on fish but also consume insects, fish larvae, birds, mammals, fruits, and seeds. Spawning occurs during low water levels, and the male protects the young for about three months. Arapaima gigas has been heavily impacted by overfishing in the past, so it is crucial to ensure sustainable management practices if kept in captivity.

name: African arowana
description: The African arowana, also known as the Nile arowana, is a bonytongue fish species closely related to arapaimas. It has a long body, large scales, and can grow up to 1m long and weigh 10.2kg. This fish is gray, brown, or bronze in color, with juveniles having dark bands. The African arowana is unique for its feeding habits, primarily consuming plankton. It has air-breathing organs allowing it to survive in low-oxygen waters. In a fish tank, the African arowana would require a spacious environment with plenty of room to swim due to its size. It would thrive in water with good oxygen levels and a diet rich in plankton or suitable alternatives. This species is not aggressive and can tolerate crowding, making it suitable for aquaculture.

name: Freshwater moray
description:
The Gymnothorax polyuranodon, also known as the freshwater moray, is a species of moray eel native to the Indo-Pacific region. It can grow up to 1.5 meters but is usually around 1 meter in length. This eel is carnivorous, feeding mainly on fish, shrimp, bivalves, and worms. It has poor vision but an excellent sense of smell and can be aggressive. The freshwater moray prefers shallow marine coastal waters, estuaries, river mouths, and sometimes freshwater environments.

In a fish tank, the freshwater moray requires a minimum tank size of 150 gallons with a sandy or smooth gravel substrate, large rocks for shelter, and low water flow. The water temperature should be maintained between 24-28 degrees Celsius. While it is commonly marketed as a freshwater species, it can actually thrive in pure saltwater, freshwater, or brackish water. This eel is highly individualistic, with different personalities and behaviors. It is best kept with larger fish species or in a species-only tank to prevent aggression and potential predation on smaller tankmates. Feeding should consist of live food initially, but the eel can be acclimated to prepared foods. Target feeding in the evening with small pieces of meat is recommended to prevent confusion. Additionally, caution must be taken with copper-based medications in the tank, as they can be harmful to the eel.

name: Hingemouth
description: The hingemouth is a unique freshwater fish found in west central Africa. It has a distinctive mouth that can extend like a small trunk and only two teeth in the lower jaw. This fish has a specialized swim bladder with two compartments that can function as a lung, enabling it to survive in oxygen-poor environments. In a fish tank, the hingemouth would require a well-oxygenated environment with ample space for swimming. It is essential to provide hiding spots and plants to mimic its natural habitat. The tank should be maintained at stable water parameters and kept clean to ensure the hingemouth's health and well-being.

name: Black ghost knifefish
remarks: Not to be confused with the featherback "knifefish" of the Bonytongue group (see above)
description: The black ghost knifefish is a tropical freshwater fish native to South America, known for its black color with white accents. It grows up to 18-20 inches and requires a large aquarium of at least 100 gallons as it is a nocturnal and territorial species. They are weakly electric fish that use electric signals to locate prey and communicate. In a tank, they need hiding spots like tubes or driftwood, dim lighting, and a secure lid as they may jump. They are intolerant of conspecifics and may eat smaller fish. They are susceptible to parasite infestations and prefer a sandy bottom environment. The fish can reproduce in captivity, and they have unique electrocommunication signals used for navigation and prey detection. It is important to provide a suitable environment with proper care to ensure the well-being and thriving of the black ghost knifefish in a tank setting.

name: Brown ghost knifefish
description: The brown ghost knifefish is a hardy species that thrives in aquariums. They are known to quickly adapt to frozen foods in captivity. These fish are weakly electric and feed on tiny fish, crustaceans, and insect larvae in their natural habitat. They have been found to have negligible brain aging and exhibit indeterminate growth, which may contribute to their minimum senescence. To thrive in a fish tank, brown ghost knifefish require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and a varied diet to mimic their natural feeding habits. They are best kept in a peaceful community tank with other non-aggressive fish species.

name: Glass knifefish
description: Eigenmannia virescens is a freshwater fish from South America known for its weak electric field production. It is popular in the aquarium trade due to its unique features, including black lines on its body and an intense line on the anal fin. In a fish tank, Eigenmannia virescens would require a spacious environment with ample swimming space and hiding spots. Due to its electric field production, it is essential to provide a suitable substrate and tank mates that can tolerate this behavior. Additionally, maintaining water quality and providing a varied diet are crucial for the well-being of Eigenmannia virescens in a home aquarium.

name: Electric eel
description: The Electric Eel, Gymnotus electricus, is a South American freshwater fish known for its ability to produce electric discharges. Despite its name, it is not an eel but a knifefish. In a fish tank, Electric Eels would require a large tank with plenty of space to swim due to their elongated body that can grow up to 2 meters in length. They are obligate air-breathers, so the tank should have access to the surface for them to breathe. Electric Eels are carnivorous and feed on invertebrates, fish, and small mammals, so their diet should be varied. They have the ability to generate electric discharges for hunting and defense, so tank mates should be carefully chosen to avoid conflicts. Overall, Electric Eels need a well-maintained tank with appropriate hiding spots and a suitable diet to thrive in a captive environment.

name: Northern pike
description: The northern pike, also known as Esox lucius, is a carnivorous fish commonly found in fresh and moderately salty waters of the Northern Hemisphere. They can grow to be quite large, with average lengths of 40-55 cm and maximum recorded lengths of up to 150 cm. Northern pike are ambush predators that prefer cold, clear, rocky waters with rich submerged vegetation. In a fish tank, they would need ample space to swim and hide, as well as vegetation for shelter. They are aggressive feeders, primarily preying on smaller fish, frogs, insects, and even small mammals and birds. Pike are known for their distinctive hunting behavior and can be territorial, especially when not given enough space. They have a strong homing behavior and tend to be more active during the day. Pike are popular among anglers for their large size and aggressive nature, but their flesh is considered bony. Catch and release practices are encouraged to preserve their populations. Fly fishing, trolling, and using dead fish as bait are common methods for catching pike. Care must be taken when handling pike due to their sharp teeth and delicate skin.

name: Indian glassy fish
description: The Indian glassy fish, also known as the Indian glassy perch, is a freshwater fish native to South Asia. It has a transparent body, with males developing a dark edge on the dorsal fin. In an aquarium, they thrive in slightly soft to moderately hard water with a pH of 6.5-7.5 and a temperature range of 20-30°C. They swim at middle and lower tank levels, preferring small live or frozen foods over dried options. These fish reproduce by laying eggs, with males fertilizing them. Unfortunately, some Indian glassy fish sold in the aquarium trade have been artificially colored, causing harm and making them more susceptible to diseases. Healthy, unpainted specimens can live three to four years in captivity.

name: Amazon leaffish
description: The Amazon leaffish, also known as Monocirrhus mimophyllus, is a small fish species found in the Amazon basin. In an aquarium, it requires acidic water, low light, and live prey to thrive. This species closely resembles a dead leaf in appearance, with a flattened body and a filament at the tip of its lower jaw. Highly predatory, it feeds on small invertebrates and fish, with larger individuals mainly preying on fish. The Amazon leaffish uses its camouflage to both evade larger predators and ambush smaller prey by swimming slowly in a head-down position, resembling a floating leaf. During breeding, the female lays up to 300 eggs on the underside of a rock or plant leaf, which are fertilized by the male who then cares for the eggs until they hatch. The young are predators from birth, starting with tiny animals like brine shrimp and water fleas.

name: African leaffish
description: The African leaffish, also known as Polycentropsis abbreviata, is a small fish native to freshwater habitats in western Africa. It belongs to the family Polycentridae and can grow up to 8 centimeters in length. This species is sometimes found in the aquarium trade and is the sole member of its genus. In a fish tank, African leaffish would thrive in a setup that mimics its natural freshwater environment with plenty of vegetation and hiding spots. They are known to be shy and prefer a peaceful tank with other non-aggressive fish species. Providing a well-maintained tank with suitable water parameters and a varied diet will help these fish thrive and display their natural behaviors.

name: Nile perch
description: The Nile perch, also known as the African snook or Goliath perch, is a large freshwater fish native to various African river basins. In a fish tank, Nile perch would require a spacious environment with ample oxygen levels. They are fierce predators that feed on fish, crustaceans, mollusks, and insects, so tank mates should be chosen carefully to avoid aggression. Juveniles prefer shallow or nearshore areas, while adults can be found throughout a lake. Nile perch are known to school for protection. Despite being a successful invasive species, they face threats from overfishing, illegal fishing gear, invasive water hyacinths, and prey depletion. To thrive, they need a well-maintained tank with appropriate tank mates and a varied diet resembling their natural prey.

name: Indonesian tigerfish
description:
Datnioides microlepis, also known as the Indonesian tiger perch, is a large freshwater fish species found in the Malay Peninsula and Indonesia. It has a deep body with distinct dark vertical bars on a yellowish-grey background. This predatory fish feeds on crustaceans, smaller fish, annelids, and insects. In the wild, it inhabits large lowland rivers with submerged branches and flooded forests.

In a fish tank, Datnioides microlepis would require a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots such as driftwood or plants to mimic its natural habitat. Due to its predatory nature and potential aggression towards its own species, it is best kept singly or in a large tank with other robust fish species. Providing a varied diet including live or frozen foods will help keep this fish healthy and thriving. It is important to maintain good water quality and ensure a suitable tank size to accommodate its potential growth, as it can reach up to 55 cm in length. Overall, providing a well-decorated tank with ample space and suitable tank mates will help Datnioides microlepis thrive in a home aquarium setting.

name: Silver tigerfish
description: Datnioides polota, also known as the silver tigerfish, is a ray-finned fish found in southern Asia and New Guinea. It belongs to the family Lobotidae and is known for its variable coloration with dark vertical bars on its body. This predatory fish feeds on other fishes, crustaceans, and aquatic insect larvae. In a fish tank, Datnioides polota would need a spacious environment with plenty of hiding spots and a mix of brackish and freshwater conditions to thrive. They prefer areas with minimal water flow and appreciate a diet rich in protein. This species is occasionally seen in the aquarium trade but requires experienced care due to its specific habitat and feeding requirements.

name: Banded archerfish
description: The banded archerfish, known for its unique ability to shoot down prey with a jet of water, is a silvery fish found in brackish waters of the Indo-Pacific and Oceanian regions. In an aquarium, they require warm water between 25-30°C, a large tank with ample swimming space, and a tall canopy to prevent them from jumping out. They prefer live food over flakes and are best kept in small groups of similar-sized individuals to avoid aggression. Despite their attractive appearance, banded archerfish are challenging to care for and not recommended for most home aquariums due to their specialized needs and feeding habits.

name: Seven-spot archerfish
description: Toxotes chatareus, also known as the common archerfish, is a species of fish that typically grows up to 20 centimeters but can reach 40 centimeters in length. They have a sooty coloration and are omnivorous, feeding on insects, fish, and plant matter at the water's surface. In an aquarium, they require a minimum tank size of 100 centimeters deep with brackish water and a tall environment to accommodate their jumping behavior. They are best kept with similar-sized tank mates to avoid aggression. Feeding live food at the surface is essential for their care, making them more suitable for experienced aquarists. They are not considered endangered, but habitat destruction and pollution pose potential risks to their populations in the future.

name: Spotted scat
description: The Scatophagus argus, also known as the spotted scat or butterfish, is a fish species found in the Indo-Pacific region. It comes in two color morphs, green and ruby, and can grow up to 38 cm in length. In an aquarium, they thrive in coastal muddy areas with brackish water, such as estuaries and mangroves. They are omnivorous and adaptable to varying salinities, transitioning from freshwater to saltwater as they mature. This species forms schools and reproduces during the monsoon season. It is important to note that they can sting with small spikes, causing pain and dizziness. Overall, the spotted scat requires a warm environment with temperatures between 21-28°C and a varied diet to thrive in a fish tank setting.

name: African scat
description: The Scatophagus tetracanthus, also known as the scatty or African scat, is a fish species found in eastern Africa, Madagascar, New Guinea, and northern Australia. It has an oval shape with a compact head and reaches up to 30 cm in length. This species prefers living in harbors, estuaries, rivers, and lagoons, feeding on benthic invertebrates and detritus. In an aquarium, Scatophagus tetracanthus would thrive in a spacious tank with plenty of hiding spots and a sandy substrate to mimic its natural habitat. It is best kept in groups due to its shoaling behavior. Additionally, maintaining water quality and providing a varied diet is crucial for the well-being of this species.

name: Silver moony
description: Monodactylus argenteus, also known as the silver moonyfish, is a bright shiny silver fish with black-tipped fins and can grow up to 27 centimeters long. This species is native to the western Pacific and Indian Oceans, thriving in various habitats like open oceans, brackish waters, and freshwater rivers. The silver moonyfish is adaptable to different salinities, making it a great addition to saltwater aquariums. They exhibit territorial behavior but can be kept in captivity and are easy to rear. They can be solitary or form schools, feeding on detritus and plankton. Overall, the silver moonyfish is a hardy species that can thrive in a variety of tank environments, making it a popular choice for aquarium enthusiasts.

name: African moony
description: The African moony, Monodactylus sebae, is a moonyfish species found in fresh, brackish, and marine waters along the eastern Atlantic coast. It typically inhabits mangrove swamps, estuaries, and lagoons. In an aquarium setting, African moonyfish thrive in brackish or saltwater tanks. They are hardy and easy to care for, making them suitable for beginner aquarists. While breeding in captivity is rare, they can adapt well to tank environments. Providing a spacious tank with ample hiding spots and a diet rich in variety will help these fish thrive in captivity.

name: Freshwater pipefish
description: Doryichthys martensii, also known as the longsnouted pipefish, is a freshwater fish found in Indonesia, Malaysia, Brunei Darussalam, and Thailand. It thrives in rivers and streams, feeding on mosquito larvae and reaching a maximum length of 15 centimeters. This species is ovoviviparous, with males carrying eggs and giving birth to live young. In a fish tank, Doryichthys martensii would require a well-established environment with plenty of plants and hiding spots to mimic its natural habitat. It is essential to maintain stable water parameters and provide a varied diet to ensure the health and well-being of this species.

name: African freshwater pipefish
description: Enneacampus ansorgii, the African freshwater pipefish, is a species found in Western Africa's coastal rivers and streams. This pipefish thrives in both slow and fast-flowing waters, ranging from the Gambia River to the Cuanza River in Angola. In a fish tank, Enneacampus ansorgii would require a well-maintained environment mimicking its natural habitat, including plants for cover and ample swimming space. It is important to provide a varied diet rich in small live foods to ensure their health and well-being. Additionally, maintaining stable water parameters and a peaceful tank community would help this species thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Fire eel
description: The fire eel is a large spiny eel native to Southeast Asia, commonly found in the aquarium trade. Despite local declines due to overfishing, it remains common overall. This fish is not a true eel but has a distinctive elongated body with red lateral stripes and spots. It can grow up to 1m in length and prefers slow-moving rivers with muddy bottoms in its natural habitat. In a fish tank, the fire eel would need a spacious environment with soft substrate to mimic its natural habitat. They are bottom-dwellers and spend time buried in the substrate, so providing hiding spots and a varied diet of invertebrates and smaller fish would be essential for their well-being.

name: Tire track eel
description: The zig-zag eel, also known as the tire-track spiny eel, is a freshwater fish native to South and Southeast Asia. In an aquarium, they thrive in tanks with sandy or rocky riverbeds, heavy vegetation, and a capacity of at least 35 gallons for smaller eels and 55 gallons for larger ones. They do well in freshwater or slightly brackish environments with a water hardness of 6 to 25 dH, pH between 6 and 8, and temperatures ranging from 73 to 81°F. Zig-zag eels are nocturnal bottom dwellers that feed on live foods like fish, worms, and shrimp. They are not suitable for tanks with small fish but can coexist with medium to large-sized species with similar care requirements. These eels are aggressive towards their own kind but peaceful towards other fish species. Breeding them in captivity is challenging, and distinguishing between male and female eels is only possible when mature.

name: Spotfinned spiny eel
remarks: They require clean water and are vulnerable to parasites, fungal diseases, and the copper-based drugs used to treat these conditions.[78]
description: The peacock eel, also known as Macrognathus siamensis or spotfin spiny eel, is a freshwater fish native to Southeast Asia. In an aquarium setting, they require a soft substrate like sand or mud to burrow into. They prefer slow-moving backwaters with a sandy or muddy bottom, mimicking their natural habitat in swamps, canals, and ponds. These eels lack scales and can grow up to 30 cm (12 in) in length, with a diet consisting of small crustaceans, annelids, and fish. They breed during the wet season when adjacent forests flood, and larvae reach 8 cm (2 in) in about 60 days. It's challenging to differentiate between male and female peacock eels externally. Overall, providing a suitable environment with soft substrate and appropriate tank mates will help these eels thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Lesser spiny eel
description: The lesser spiny eel, Macrognathus aculeatus, is a Southeast Asian freshwater fish with a unique appearance, featuring a yellow upper body with a black line down the middle and a mix of white and brown on the lower body. They have small spines along the backbone and prominent eyespots on the dorsal fin. These eels can reach up to 14 inches in length but are typically smaller. In an aquarium, they are uncommon due to their nocturnal and burrowing habits. They require a medium to large-sized tank with plenty of hiding spots like caves or plants. The tank should mimic their natural habitat with soft, acidic water and a sandy substrate. They are known to be crepuscular and may prey on small fish, so tank mates should be chosen carefully.

name: Freshwater needlefish
description: Xenentodon cancila, also known as the freshwater garfish, is a needlefish species found in South and Southeast Asia. In an aquarium setting, they are known to be predators but primarily feed on crustaceans. They are oviparous and spawn in the morning, with the fry needing small live foods to thrive. This species is challenging to maintain due to its large size, nervous behavior, and preference for live foods. Despite misconceptions about their diet and water conditions, they thrive well in freshwater tanks without the need for salt. To ensure their well-being, provide a spacious tank with plenty of plants for egg deposition and hiding spots, and offer a varied diet of live foods to mimic their natural habitat.

name: Green spotted puffer
remarks: Pufferfish inflating out of water can cause death.[80]
description: The green spotted pufferfish, also known as Tetraodon nigroviridis, is a species of pufferfish found in South and Southeast Asia. It thrives best in brackish to saltwater environments. In captivity, it can grow up to 10 cm in length and is known for its aggressive nature, making it unsuitable for tank mates. This omnivorous species prefers a pH level of 8 and transitions from brackish to saltwater as it matures. It feeds on snails, mollusks, crustaceans, and some plant material. The green spotted pufferfish has a unique genome and is used as a model organism in genetics research. Its striking green body with black spots makes it a popular choice for aquariums, but caution is advised as its flesh contains a toxic substance. To thrive in a fish tank, this species requires a brackish to saltwater environment with appropriate hiding spots and a varied diet to mimic its natural habitat.

name: Figure 8 pufferfish
description: The Figure 8 puffer, also known as the eyespot puffer, is a colorful freshwater fish found in Southeast Asia. They grow to about 8 cm in length and are relatively peaceful among Tetraodontidae. In a fish tank, they require a 15-gallon tank with temperatures between 24°C and 28°C. They are sensitive to nitrites and nitrates and need a fully cycled aquarium with over-filtration and frequent water changes. The water should have a pH reflecting a brackish environment, with a salinity between 1.005 and 1.008 specific gravity. Providing a complex aquarium setup with hiding spots is crucial for their well-being. They are molluscivores, feeding on benthic organisms like mussels and snails, which help keep their beak trim. It is not recommended to feed them primarily on flake food. With proper care, Figure 8 puffers can live up to 15 years in captivity.

name: Humpback Puffer
remarks: See above
description: Pao palembangensis, also known as the humpback puffer or dragon puffer, is a freshwater pufferfish found in Southeast Asia. It thrives in warm, slow-flowing rivers with an alkaline pH. This species grows up to 19.4 centimeters in length and has a distinct chocolate-brown coloration with orange eyes. It possesses the neurotoxin tetrodotoxin and can inflate its body when threatened. In an aquarium, Pao palembangensis requires a spacious tank with warm water and places to hide. It is an active hunter that preys on sleeping aquatic creatures, displaying nocturnal behavior with increased activity at night.

name: Red-tail dwarf puffer
remarks: See above
description: The red-tail dwarf puffer, Carinotetraodon irrubesco, is a small freshwater pufferfish native to specific regions in South Sumatra and West Kalimantan. In an aquarium setting, they require a soft, fine sand substrate for wallowing, preferably at least 2cm deep. These pufferfish thrive in heavily planted tanks with soft leafy coverage, providing a natural environment for them to feel secure. They are known to wallow at night and seek refuge in dense vegetation during the day. Additionally, moss is essential for their spawning needs.

name: Golden puffer
remarks: See above
description: The Bronze Puffer, also known as Auriglobus modestus, is a small ray-finned fish found in rivers and estuaries in southeast Asia. Growing up to 10.6 cm (4.2 in) in length, it primarily feeds on small invertebrates, seeds, fish scales, and small fish. In a fish tank, the Bronze Puffer would require a well-maintained environment with plenty of hiding spots and plants to mimic its natural habitat. It is important to provide a varied diet to ensure its nutritional needs are met. Due to its small size, it is recommended to keep them in a species-only tank or with peaceful tank mates to prevent aggression. Regular water changes and monitoring water parameters are essential for the health and well-being of the Bronze Puffer in a captive setting.

name: Dwarf pufferfish
description: The dwarf pufferfish, also known as the Malabar pufferfish, is a small freshwater species native to Southwest India. These pufferfish are popular in aquariums due to their vibrant colors and small size, reaching a maximum length of 3.5 cm. In a fish tank, dwarf pufferfish thrive in heavily vegetated environments with gravel or sandy substrates. They are carnivores, feeding on insect larvae, crustaceans, and small animals. In captivity, they benefit from a varied diet including small snails, shrimps, and live foods like mosquito larvae. Dwarf pufferfish are slow-swimming and bottom-dwelling, typically found in large groups rather than solitary. They are known to breed in plants, laying adhesive eggs that are fertilized externally by the male. These fish have a lifespan of around five years in captivity. It's important to provide a suitable environment with plants and hiding spots for these social and active fish to thrive in a home aquarium.

name: Fahaka puffer
description: The Fahaka pufferfish, also known as the Nile puffer, is a tropical freshwater species found in various basins in Africa. It can grow up to 43 cm in length and has the ability to inflate when threatened. This species carries the toxin tetrodotoxin and primarily feeds on benthic organisms like freshwater mussels and snails. In a fish tank, Fahaka pufferfish would require a spacious environment with ample hiding spots, plants, and open swimming areas. They thrive in large tanks with clean water, proper filtration, and a varied diet to mimic their natural habitat. It is important to note that due to their aggressive nature and specialized diet, they are best kept in a species-only tank or with compatible tank mates.

name: Mbu puffer
remarks: This fish also occurs in estuaries. largest freshwater pufferfish, they are very peaceful with most fish except, other Mbu pufferfish,  other fish that will harass them. see above[81]
description: The Mbu pufferfish is a large carnivorous freshwater fish originating from Africa. It grows up to 67 cm long and requires a very large tank with adequate water filtration due to its size. In a fish tank, Mbu puffers need a varied diet including shelled foods to maintain good health and prevent tooth overgrowth. They have labyrinthine skin patterns that become more pronounced as they mature. These fish have the ability to inflate themselves when stressed. To thrive, Mbu pufferfish need a spacious tank with appropriate hiding spots and a diet rich in shelled foods to maintain their health in captivity.

name: Congo pufferfish
remarks: as it is a ambush pufferfish it is best to house it alone as it will attack tank mates.  see above[82]
description: The Congo puffer, also known as the potato puffer, is a freshwater fish found in the Congo River in Africa. It is an inactive fish that spends most of its time buried in sand or substrate, with the ability to change color for camouflage. This species can grow up to 15 cm in length and has various color variations. In a fish tank, Congo puffers require a minimum tank size of 60cm in length, 40cm in depth, and 30cm in height with a soft sand substrate for natural behavior. They are primarily piscivores, feeding on smaller fish and small amphibians. In captivity, they should be fed a diet of 30% frozen freshwater fish and 70% earthworms, cockroaches, and small terrestrial isopods.

name: Amazon puffer
description:
The Colomesus asellus, also known as the Amazon puffer, is a freshwater pufferfish native to the Amazon, Essequibo, and Orinoco basins in tropical South America. It is a popular aquarium species, growing up to 12.8 centimeters in length. This fish has a green upper body, white underbelly, and black transverse bands on its dorsal surface. It can tolerate slightly brackish water but is mainly found in freshwater environments. In the wild, it feeds on benthic crustaceans, fish, planktonic invertebrates, and plants.

In an aquarium setting, the Colomesus asellus requires a tank of at least 109 liters (approximately 29 US gallons). It is unique among freshwater pufferfish for being tolerant of conspecifics but may become nervous if kept alone. This species is known to be a fin-nipper and may attack slow-moving species like angelfish, guppies, and Corydoras. Regular feeding of crunchy foods is essential due to its fast-growing teeth. Breeding this fish in captivity is challenging as their eggs are small and go through a planktonic phase before developing into mature fish.

name: Everglades pygmy sunfish
description: The Everglades pygmy sunfish, Elassoma evergladei, is a small fish species native to North America, specifically found in freshwater habitats from North Carolina to Alabama and from South Florida to the Everglades. In a fish tank, they would thrive in a freshwater environment with a pH range of 7.0 to 7.5 and a temperature range of 10 to 30 degrees Celsius. They prefer habitats with slow currents, fluctuating water levels, and heavy vegetation. These fish are solitary and feed on worms, crustaceans, and other small invertebrates. Males may establish territories in feeding areas and guard the eggs laid by females in aquatic plants. Overall, they are considered common and stable in the wild, making them suitable for aquariums.

name: Blackbanded sunfish
