description: The Black-banded sunfish is a small freshwater fish with black vertical stripes on its body, reaching a maximum length of 10 cm and living for 3-4 years. It prefers shallow, low-velocity, non-turbid waters with aquatic plants for foraging and cover. In a fish tank, it would thrive in a setup mimicking its natural habitat with plenty of plants and hiding spots. This peaceful species enjoys grouping with others of the same kind but can become territorial during spawning. It is a carnivorous fish, feeding on midge larvae, zooplankton, aquatic insects, and crustaceans. Due to its imperiled status, it is crucial to avoid capturing Black-banded sunfish for aquariums to help protect their populations in the wild.

name: Freshwater blenny
description: The freshwater blenny, Salariopsis fluviatilis, is a small fish species found in African rivers and brooks in Algeria and Morocco, as well as in various European countries and parts of Asia. It grows up to 15 centimeters in length. In a fish tank, freshwater blennies would thrive in a well-aerated environment with plenty of hiding spots like rocks, caves, and plants. They are known to be territorial and may exhibit aggressive behavior towards other fish, especially males towards each other. Providing a varied diet consisting of small live or frozen foods will help keep them healthy and active. It's important to maintain good water quality and regular water changes to ensure the well-being of freshwater blennies in a tank setting.

name: Brook stickleback
description: The brook stickleback, a small freshwater fish found in the US and Canada, thrives in clear, cool streams and lakes. It grows up to 2 inches long and feeds on small invertebrates, algae, and insect larvae. In a fish tank, it would require a habitat with high vegetation cover, low water velocity, and a variety of small organisms to feed on. The brook stickleback is an annual species that spawns in midsummer, with males building nests and providing protection for the eggs. To thrive, it needs a shallow, near-shore environment with ample vegetation. The species faces threats from habitat destruction due to dam construction and pollution, making conservation efforts crucial for its survival.

name: Banded darter
description: The banded darter, Etheostoma zonale, is a small freshwater fish found in the eastern United States, particularly in the Mississippi Basin. In a fish tank, they prefer swift riffles with cobble or gravel substrate and water deeper than 25 cm. Their diet consists of midge, mayfly larvae, black flies, and trichopteran larvae. They prefer temperatures between 72 and 76°F. Banded darters are territorial during spawning, attaching adhesive eggs to waterweed. They are preyed upon by larger fish and birds. To thrive, they need a clean environment free from siltation and pollution, with natural water flow. Conservation efforts focus on habitat preservation, such as preventing dam construction and reducing pollution in their streams.

name: Gilt darter
description: The gilt darter (Percina evides) is a freshwater fish species found in the Mississippi River drainage in the United States. It is a benthic fish that primarily feeds on small aquatic insect larvae. Males are more colorful than females and can grow up to 9 cm in length. They form territories during the breeding season in late spring and early summer, with spawning occurring in riffles with sandy and gravelly bottoms. The gilt darter prefers upland cool-water streams with higher velocities and cobble substrates. In a fish tank, the gilt darter would require a well-oxygenated environment with sandy and gravelly substrates, as well as hiding spots like rocks or driftwood. It would thrive in a tank with a consistent water temperature of 16-23°C and a varied diet of aquatic invertebrates. It is essential to maintain water quality to mimic its natural habitat and prevent stress-related issues.

name: Orangethroat darter
description: The orangethroat darter is a freshwater fish native to the central and eastern United States, found in shallow gravel riffles and rocky runs of streams and rivers. In a fish tank, it would thrive in a setup mimicking its natural habitat, with sand, gravel, rubble, or rock substrates, and a moderate water flow. They primarily feed on aquatic larvae and small invertebrates. Breeding occurs in spring in sandy and gravelly bottoms. They are relatively small in size, with males being smaller than females. Orangethroat darters are hardy and adaptable, making them suitable for a well-maintained aquarium with good water quality. They are not aggressive and can coexist with other peaceful fish species. To ensure their well-being, it is essential to monitor water quality and provide a varied diet that includes small live or frozen foods.

name: Rainbow darter
description: The rainbow darter is a small freshwater fish native to North America, commonly found in clean, fast-moving streams and rivers. It grows to 2-3 inches in length and is sensitive to pollution and silt. In a fish tank, rainbow darters would thrive in a setup mimicking their natural habitat, with rocky substrates and swift-moving water. They are insectivorous, feeding on small invertebrates, and prefer creeks with rocky substrates for shelter and feeding. Rainbow darters mate during the spring in areas with water temperatures around 17-18°C. They exhibit territorial behavior during breeding and spawn in groups. To ensure their well-being, it is crucial to maintain water quality and reduce pollution in their environment.

name: Splendid darter
description: The splendid darter, a freshwater fish endemic to the Barren River system in Kentucky and Tennessee, thrives in small rocky pools in creeks and rivers. In a fish tank, it would require a setup mimicking its natural habitat with plenty of rocks and flowing water. This species exhibits specialized reproductive behaviors that rely on specific environmental conditions, making it vulnerable to changes. It is likely insectivorous and may be preyed upon by larger fish. Breeding occurs once a year from March to June, with males establishing territories in deep pools for mating. With an average lifespan of three years, this species is considered rare and faces threats like habitat destruction and invasive species. Conservation efforts are crucial to protect the splendid darter and its unique ecosystem in the southeastern United States.
